PER CURIAM:Â  Emmet Tyrone Kelley was convicted

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Estate of Mary Emma Good Strickland, by and through her Personal Representative, 
        Alexandria B. Skinner,        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
The Estate of Lloyd Joseph Strickland, by and through his Personal Representative, 
        Sandra S. Kelly, and Sandra S. Kelly, Individually,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Berry L. Mobley, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-077
Heard December 8, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  4, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jan L. Warner, of Columbia, for Appellant.
J. Mark Taylor, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from the 
  identification of marital property and apportionment of the marital estate.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTS
Lloyd and Emma Strickland were married in 1966.Â  
  It was the third marriage for both.Â  They remained married and lived together 
  until 1999 when Lloyd suffered a series of falls.Â  As a result of these falls, 
  Lloyd was moved to an assisted living facility near the family home.Â  The decision 
  to place Lloyd in an assisted living facility was made by Sandra Kelly, his 
  daughter and attorney-in-fact.Â  
After Lloyd was placed in the assisted living facility, 
  his daughter contributed $300 per month as support to Emma and continued paying 
  certain bills.Â  By March 2000, Emma was no longer able to care for herself and 
  was moved to a nursing home in Columbia by Alexandria Skinner, her granddaughter 
  and attorney-in-fact.Â  In May of 2000, Kelly had her father moved to a nursing 
  facility near her home in California.Â  
On June 9, 2000 Skinner, as attorney-in-fact for the 
  Wife, filed this action in the family court.Â  She named Kelly, individually 
  and as the Husbandâ€™s attorney-in-fact, as a defendant as well as the Husband.Â  
  Skinner complained that Lloyd was not adequately providing for Emmaâ€™s expenses 
  and sought equitable division of the marital estate.Â  She requested a restraining 
  order to preserve the Husbandâ€™s assets, an order of separate support and maintenance, 
  equitable distribution, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
The Husband died three weeks later on June 30, 2000.Â  
  He was 91 years old.Â Â  The Wife died on June 25, 2001.Â  She was 85.Â Â Â  After 
  the death of the Wife, Lloydâ€™s estate moved for dismissal of the action for 
  lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  The motion was denied.Â  The action proceeded 
  with the estates of the Husband and Wife substituted as parties, with Skinner 
  as the personal representative of the estate of the Wife and Kelly as the personal 
  representative of the estate of the Husband. 
After a complex procedural history, a final hearing 
  was held and the family court heard testimony from Skinner, Kelly, and Mark 
  T. Hobbes, a certified public accountant.Â  The court found assets in the Husbandâ€™s 
  name were valued at $512,251.66 and the assets in the Wifeâ€™s name were valued 
  at $519,309.00 as of the time of the filing of this action.Â  The court determined 
  the entire amount was deemed marital property.Â  It ordered equal equitable distribution 
  of the marital estate, which caused the Wifeâ€™s estate to owe $3,528.50 to the 
  Husbandâ€™s estate.Â  Following the family courtâ€™s denial of her motion to reconsider, 
  the Wifeâ€™s estate appealed to this court.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has 
  authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 
  157 (1996).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard 
  the findings of the family court.Â  Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 335, 
  569 S.E.2d 393, 397 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  We are mindful that the family court judge, 
  who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their 
  credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Miles v. Miles, 
  355 S.C. 511, 516, 586 S.E.2d 136, 139 (Ct. App. 2003).
The family court has broad discretion in determining 
  how marital property is to be valued and distributed.Â  Murphy v. Murphy, 
  319 S.C. 324, 329, 461 S.E.2d 39, 41 (1995).Â  Therefore, the family court may 
  use any reasonable means to divide the property equitably, and its judgment 
  will only be disturbed where abuse of discretion is found.Â  Id. at 329, 
  461 S.E.2d at 41-42.
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Wifeâ€™s estate argues the family court erred 
  in finding all of the assets titled in her name were marital property.Â  We disagree. 
  [1] 
Marital property is defined as all real and 
  personal property acquired by the parties during the marriage that is owned 
  as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation, regardless of 
  how legal title is held.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2004).Â  Generally, 
  property acquired by either party before the marriage constitutes nonmarital 
  property.Â  However, nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital property.Â  
  Â§ 20-7-473(2).Â  Whether property has been transmuted is a matter of intent to 
  be gleaned from the facts of each case.Â  Hatfield v. Hatfield, 327 S.C. 
  360, 368, 489 S.E.2d 212, 217 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The party claiming the property 
  was transmuted must produce objective evidence that during the marriage, the 
  parties themselves regarded the property as common property.Â  Id.Â  This 
  evidence may include:Â  (1) placing the property in joint names; (2) transferring 
  the property to the other spouse as a gift; (3) using the property exclusively 
  for marital property; (4) commingling the property with marital property; (5) 
  using marital funds to build equity in the property; or (6) exchanging the property 
  for marital property.Â  Id.
The Wifeâ€™s estate argues the marital residence in 
  Summerville, South Carolina was not marital property because it was purchased 
  from the proceeds of property the Wife had owned prior to the marriage.Â  The 
  family court determined the residence was transmuted because it had been commingled 
  with the property of the parties.Â  While the marital residence was only titled 
  in the Wifeâ€™s name, we find sufficient evidence to support the family courtâ€™s 
  conclusion that the property was transmuted.Â  See Corbett v. Corbett, 
  313 S.C. 184, 187, 437 S.E.2d 136, 138 (Ct. App. 1993) (stating the manner in 
  which title is held is irrelevant in determining whether property is marital).Â  
  The residence was used exclusively as the marital home for eleven years.Â  
  Additionally, evidence in the form of checks and notations showed that the Husband 
  paid at least $36,000 towards satisfying the note on the house.Â  This evidence 
  demonstrates a specific intent by the parties to treat the marital residence 
  as marital property.
The Wifeâ€™s estate asserts the family court should 
  have excluded the checks showing Lloyd had retired $36,000 of the house debt 
  because the Husbandâ€™s estate failed to produce them during discovery.Â  First, 
  we find this argument is not properly before this court because the Wifeâ€™s estate 
  failed to include this issue in its statement of the issues on appeal.Â  See 
  Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR (â€œOrdinarily, no point will be considered which is 
  not set forth in the statement of the issues on appeal.â€).Â  Furthermore, we 
  find no reversible error in the family courtâ€™s admission of the checks.Â  The 
  decision of what kind and whether to impose discovery sanctions is left to the 
  sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 
  354 S.C. 445, 457, 581 S.E.2d 489, 495 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œIn deciding what sanction 
  to impose, the circuit court should weigh the nature of the interrogatories, 
  the discovery posture of the case, willfulness, and the degree of prejudice.â€Â  
  Id.Â  The burden is on the appealing party to show the trial court abused 
  its discretion in its decision regarding the imposition of sanctions.Â  Halverson 
  v. Yawn, 328 S.C. 618, 621, 493 S.E.2d 883, 884 (Ct. App. 1997).
The attorney for the Wifeâ€™s estate explained that 
  although Kelly had sent him copies of the checks, they were misplaced in a file.Â  
  Additionally, while the checks themselves were not provided prior to trial, 
  an exhibit list was exchanged the day prior to trial listing two checks regarding 
  the marital residence.Â  Although on appeal, the Wifeâ€™s estate argues that it 
  was prejudiced by the failure to produce the copies of the checks because it 
  was not given the opportunity to investigate the authenticity of the checks 
  or whether they were used for the purposes asserted by the Husbandâ€™s estate, 
  it failed to make this argument to the trial court.Â  Accordingly, it is not 
  preserved for our consideration.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 
  S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot 
  be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled 
  upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  Considering 
  the Husbandâ€™s estateâ€™s explanation that his failure to produce was by mistake 
  rather than bad motive and the Wifeâ€™s estateâ€™s failure to demonstrate prejudice, 
  we hold the family court did not abuse its discretion in allowing the copies 
  of the checks into evidence.Â  
We also find that the family court did not err 
  in including the other assets titled in the Wifeâ€™s name in the marital estate.Â  
  Skinner did not dispute that the Husband had given her grandmother an annuity 
  in 1994 in the sum of $277,300.00.Â  The Wife had cashed this and added the proceeds 
  to her assets.Â  The Wifeâ€™s income included increased Social Security payments 
  due to the Husbandâ€™s employment.Â  In addition, as the Wifeâ€™s estateâ€™s expert 
  witness testified, the Wife expended considerable sums on household expenses 
  in support of the marriage over the years.Â  Thus, we conclude the family court 
  did not err in valuing the marital estate at $1,031,561.00.Â  
The Wifeâ€™s estate also argues the family court 
  improperly apportioned the marital estate.Â  We disagree.Â  
The family court must consider fifteen factors 
  and give each weight as it finds appropriate.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 
  2004).Â  â€œOn review, we look to the fairness of the overall apportionment; if 
  the end result is equitable, it is irrelevant that we might have weighed specific 
  factors differently than the family court.â€Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 
  S.C. 88, 100, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
The Wifeâ€™s estate takes particular issue with the 
  family courtâ€™s finding that the husband â€œhad all earned income during the marriage 
  while [the Wife] contributed passive income from alternative sources.â€Â  The 
  Wifeâ€™s estate argues no evidence supports this finding.Â  We hold the Wifeâ€™s 
  estate has mischaracterized this finding.Â  The family court did not belittle 
  the Wifeâ€™s contributions to the marriage.Â  It recognized that the wife had income 
  from passive sources such as investments and social security and also contributed 
  to the marriage as the primary homemaker, but also found she was not a wage-earner.Â  
  Skinner acknowledged that her grandmother had not held outside employment during 
  the course of her marriage to the Husband.Â  
Although the evidence as to the Husbandâ€™s employment 
  is sketchy, there is evidence in the record to support the family courtâ€™s determination 
  that the Husband was the only wage earner.Â  Kelly stated her father worked hard 
  all of his life.Â  The certified public accountant the Wifeâ€™s estate presented 
  as an expert witness, Mark Thomas Hobbs, testified that the Wifeâ€™s social security 
  income probably came from drawing upon the Husbandâ€™s social security.Â  He acknowledged 
  that the Husbandâ€™s higher social security income indicated outside employment.Â  
  In addition, he recognized that the Husband had a pension income, which also 
  indicated past outside employment.Â  
We disagree with the Wifeâ€™s estateâ€™s assertion that 
  the Husband did not contribute to the marriage.Â  Although Kelly recognized that 
  her father was extremely frugal, there is no evidence in the record that he 
  lived off of the Wife during the course of the marriage.Â  Kelly testified the 
  Husband paid certain household bills, including utilities, from his checking 
  account and gave the Wife $300.00 a month for additional expenses.Â  Kelly continued 
  these payments after the Husband went into the assisted living facility.Â  In 
  addition, the Husband paid $36,000 toward the mortgage of the marital residence.Â  
  Furthermore, at the time of the filing of the action, the Husband had assets 
  in his name valued at $512,251.66.Â  There is no indication in the record these 
  assets came from the Wife.Â  Instead, it is undisputed the Husband gave the Wife 
  a $277,300.00 annuity.Â  
In determining the parties were entitled to equal 
  equitable apportionment of the marital estate, the family court carefully considered 
  and set-down in its order its conclusions on the relevant factors.Â  We find 
  no error in this determination.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons discussed, the identification of marital property and apportionment 
  ordered by the family court is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  

 
   
    [1]  We note the unusual procedural history of this case and agree with 
    the family court that the death of the parties does not terminate a proceeding 
    regarding property rights because the courtâ€™s jurisdiction vested at the time 
    the suit was filed.Â  See Hodge v. Hodge, 305 S.C. 521, 524, 
    409 S.E.2d 436, 438 (Ct. App. 1991) (holding that upon the institution or 
    filing of marital litigation, the marital estate vests and with respect to 
    the equitable division of marital property, marital litigation is not abated 
    by the death of a spouse).Â  However, we are disconcerted that this action 
    was initiated and litigated by the partiesâ€™ attorneys-in-fact and then the 
    personal representatives of their estates when the parties themselves had 
    not suffered from marital discord.Â  Considering the aging population and the 
    proliferation of second marriages, the possibility is increasing for marital 
    litigation brought by the children from prior marriages of the parties.Â  As 
    the Wifeâ€™s counsel stated at oral argument, this type of litigation could 
    be used by the children of one spouse to obtain a share of the other spouseâ€™s 
    non-probate assets, which are not eligible for an elective share.Â Â Â  While 
    we question whether such litigation is within the purpose of the family courtâ€™s 
    jurisdiction, we must look to the legislature to place limits on that type 
    of action.

PER CURIAM:Â  Jerry Lewis Canty

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Debra M. Knight,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jack Knight, Jr.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Aphrodite K. Konduros, Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-082
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  4, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard H. Rhodes, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Brendan M. Delaney, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Debra M. Knight (Wife) initiated 
  this domestic relations action against Jack Knight, Jr. (Husband).Â  The family 
  court awarded Wife a divorce on the ground of adultery, ordered Husband to pay 
  alimony, and made an equitable distribution of the partiesâ€™ assets.Â  Husband 
  made a Rule 60(b) motion which was denied.Â  He appeals the denial of this motion.Â  
  We affirm. [1] Â  
FACTS
On October 21, 2002, the family court 
  granted Wife a divorce on the ground of Husbandâ€™s adultery.Â  The courtâ€™s order 
  awarded Wife the marital home and a machine shop located adjacent to the home.Â  
  Additionally, Wife was given responsibility for both mortgages on the residence 
  as well as a $20,000 loan obtained to purchase machinery.Â  The parties agreed 
  the value of the home was $68,000.Â  Husband was ordered to pay $650 per month 
  in permanent, periodic alimony, and Wife was awarded attorneyâ€™s fees.Â Â  
Husband did not appeal.Â  However, on December 20, 
  2002, Husband filed a motion pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  Therein, Husband 
  asserted the following: (1) the valuation of the marital home was erroneous; 
  (2) the valuation of the mortgages on the home was erroneous; (3) the treatment 
  of the loan for business equipment as marital debt was erroneous; (4) the valuation 
  of Husbandâ€™s pension plans was erroneous; (5) the valuation and distribution 
  of the partiesâ€™ personal property was erroneous; (6) Husband should have been 
  given credit for certain payments towards marital debt; (7) the valuation of 
  the machine shop equipment was erroneous; (8) due to Husbandâ€™s psychological 
  condition at the time of the hearing, he was unable â€œto completely comprehend 
  the proceedings and to assist in the presentation of the case as he should have 
  beenâ€; (9) Wife had not yet paid sums she agreed to pay for the appraisals of 
  the home and machine shop equipment; and (10) the division of marital assets 
  was erroneous.
The family court denied Husbandâ€™s Rule 60(b) motion, 
  with the sole exception that Wife was ordered to pay Husband the $100 she owed 
  him for the appraisals of the marital home and the machine shop equipment.Â  
  Husband appeals this order, contending the court should have granted his motion 
  under Rule 60(b). Â We affirm.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Rule 60(b), SCRCP, provides, in pertinent 
  part:
On motion and upon such terms as are just, the court 
  may relieve a party or his legal representative from a final judgment, order, 
  or proceeding for the following reasons:

(1)     mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect;
(2)Â Â Â Â  newly discovered evidence which by due diligence 
  could not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial under Rule 59(b);
(3)Â Â Â Â  fraud, misrepresentation, or other misconduct of 
  an adverse party;
(4)Â Â Â Â  the judgment is void;
(5) Â Â Â  the judgment has been satisfied, released, or discharged, 
  or a prior judgment upon which it is based has been reversed or otherwise vacated, 
  or it is no longer equitable that the judgment should have prospective application.

â€œ[M]otions for relief under Rule 60(b) 
  are addressed to the discretion of the court and appellate review is limited 
  to determining whether the trial court abused its discretion.â€Â  Saro v. Ocean 
  Holiday Pâ€™ship, 314 S.C. 116, 124, 441 S.E.2d 835, 840 (Ct. App. 1994) (citations 
  omitted).Â  â€œA party seeking to set aside a judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b) has 
  the burden of presenting evidence entitling him to the requested relief.â€Â  Perry 
  v. Heirs at Law of Gadsden, 357 S.C. 42, 46-47, 590 S.E.2d 502, 504 (Ct. 
  App. 2003) (citing Bowers v. Bowers, 304 S.C. 65, 403 S.E.2d 127 (1991)).Â  
  An abuse of discretion arises where the trial judge was controlled by an error 
  of law, or where her order is based on factual conclusions that are without 
  evidentiary support.Â  Tri-County Ice & Fuel Co. v. Palmetto Ice Co., 
  303 S.C. 237, 242, 399 S.E.2d 779, 782 (1990). 
Husbandâ€™s Rule 60(b) motion does not specify 
  upon which of the five enumerated grounds for relief his motion is based.Â  Husband 
  fails to demonstrate any error of law or unsupported conclusion in the courtâ€™s 
  final decree.Â  Thus, he has not met his burden.Â  Further, his assertions of 
  error do not come within the ambit of any of the Rule 60(b)â€™s five reasons for 
  granting relief.Â  Accordingly, we hold the family court judge was within her 
  discretion in denying the Rule 60(b) motion.Â  
In his brief, Husband states that â€œ[a] 
  substantial portion of the Appellantâ€™s argument is based on the neglect of his 
  attorney.â€Â  He specifically contends: â€œAppellantâ€™s trial counsel did not present 
  a completed financial declaration on behalf of Appellant.Â  In addition, counsel 
  did not present basic information such as an inventory of the property.Â  Also, 
  Appellantâ€™s counsel stipulated to documents which were not accurate.Â  Finally, 
  counsel failed to present pertinent information relating to equitable apportionment.â€Â  

Initially, we note that Husbandâ€™s Rule 
  60(b) motion did not raise the issue of his trial counselâ€™s performance.Â  Issues 
  not raised and ruled upon in the trial court will not be considered on appeal.Â  
  Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 598 S.E.2d 712 (2004); 
  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000).Â  
  Nevertheless, we find this contention meritless.Â  In Greenville Income Partners 
  v. Holman, 308 S.C. 105, 417 S.E.2d 107 (1992), we held the failure of an 
  attorney to interpose available defenses did not amount to the kind of mistake, 
  surprise, inadvertence, and excusable neglect contemplated by Rule 60(b).Â  Id. 
  at 107, 417 S.E.2d at 108.Â  â€œThe acts of an attorney are directly attributable 
  to and binding on his client.â€Â  Id. (citations omitted).Â  Consequently, 
  we disagree with Husband that his trial counselâ€™s performance justifies reversal 
  on the Rule 60(b) issue.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the family court isÂ  
 AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur. 

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  
  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS 
  PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Beatrice Devore Bing and Theadie Mae Devore White,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Carrie Garvin Devore a/k/a Carrie
        Ceveaux, deceased, Willie Devore, deceased, 
        Catherine D. Wright, deceased, Ruby D. Green, deceased, Althea D.
        Chaneyfield, 
        deceased, Jenetta D. Mackie a/k/a Jenetta D. Garrett, deceased, Clayton 
        Devore, deceased, Bennie Devore, deceased, Clifton Devore, deceased, Moses 
        Devore, deceased, Nathan Devore, deceased, Coretha D. Hamilton, Zevenia 
        D. Dennis, Vilease Devore, Louise Woods Devore, deceased, Badyese Devore,
        Gladys D. Frazier, Mary D. Smith, Cephrus Devore, deceased, John Wesley 
        Devore, Miriam Devore, Barbara Dee Stevenson, Priscilla Bryan, Willie 
        Wright, deceased, Edward Wright, deceased, Junior Mackie, deceased, Dercella 
        M. Johnson, Donald Mackie, Annette Devore, Darius Devore, Annette Michelle 
        D. Wright, Angela Devore, Jamesina D. Goodwin, Wendy Devore, Javis S. 
        Devore, Cephrus A. Devore, Anthony Devore, Betty Devore, Isiah Devore, 
        Cypress Woods Corporation, Henry Lott, Tereather Orr, Harold Garvin, Terry 
        Brice, Lowther Investments, Inc., Emma Jones, and John Doe, representing 
        as a class, any and all unknown adult heirs of the above named DefendantsÂ Â  
        that are deceased, and Richard Roe, representing as a class, any and all 
        unknown minors, persons underÂ  disability and persons in the military 
        service who may have an interestÂ  effected by this lawsuit,       
        Defendants,
        Of Whom Tereather Orr is the        
      
    
  


Appeal From Jasper County
R. Thayer Rivers, Jr., Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-097
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  9, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Deborah Ann Malphrus, of Ridgeland, for Appellants
Kenneth L. Tootle, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this action to quiet title 
  and partition property, Beatrice Devore Bing [1]  and Theadie Mae Devore White (collectively 
  Appellants) appeal from the order of the special referee selling the property 
  to Tereather Orr.Â  We affirm. [2] 
FACTS
Appellants were two of eleven children who inherited 
  two tracts of land, one approximately 8.9 acres and the other approximately 
  17.2 acres.Â  Appellants brought the underlying action to quiet title and partition 
  the property.
Neil Riley, as special referee, issued an order 
  determining the ownership rights in the property.Â  Additionally, he found the 
  property should be sold and the proceeds divided.Â  The order provided for the 
  property to be listed with a realtor for three months for the purpose of seeking 
  a private sale of the property.Â  If a purchaser was not found, the property 
  could be sold at public auction.Â  
Subsequently, R. Thayer Rivers, Jr. was 
  substituted as special referee.Â  The referee presided over a hearing to determine 
  the method of sale for the property.Â  At the hearing, he took into evidence 
  a bid for the 8.9-acre tract of land, letters indicating three realtors had 
  been unable to locate a purchaser for the other tract, letters seeking sealed 
  bids from individuals and entities, and an appraisal of the 17-acre tract.Â  
  Â The appraisal indicated the value of the 17-acre tract was $2,700 per acre 
  or approximately $46,500 for the tract.Â  The hearing was continued and the time 
  for submitting bids was held open.Â  
In a subsequent order, the referee accepted 
  a bid for the 8.9 acres filed by one of the heirs. [3] Â  Additionally, the referee accepted 
  a bid by Orr for the purchase of the 17-acre tract for $26,500.Â  The referee 
  specifically found:Â  â€œIn determining whether these bids were reasonable, I considered 
  the appraisal of the subject properties which was introduced into evidence . 
  . . the Jasper Countyâ€™s Tax Assessorâ€™s assessed value . . . [and] the sales 
  price of several other tracts of land of comparable value in the general vicinity 
  of the subject properties.â€Â  The referee found Orrâ€™s bid was â€œfair, just 
  and equitable,â€ and set forth the specifics of the private sale of both tracts 
  of land. This appeal follows the denial of Appellantsâ€™ motion to reconsider. 

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA partition action is an equitable action, 
  heard by a judge alone and, as such, this Court on review may find facts in 
  accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Anderson 
  v. Anderson, 299 S.C. 110, 113, 382 S.E.2d 897, 899 (1989).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants contend the referee erred in 
  directing a private sale of the property and in finding the bid was fair and 
  reasonable.Â  We disagree.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Private vs. Public Sale
Pursuant to South Carolina statute:

The court of common pleas has jurisdiction in all cases of 
  real and personal estates held in joint tenancy or in common to make partition 
  in kind . . . or, in case partition in kind or by allotment cannot be fairly 
  and impartially made and without injury to any of the parties in interest, by 
  the sale of the property and the division of the proceeds according to the rights 
  of the parties.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-61-50 (1977).
 First, we must address whether the issue 
  of requiring sale by public auction has been preserved for review on appeal.Â  
  In their motion for reconsideration, Appellants argued there was â€œno evidence 
  in the record supporting a finding that the sales price of $26,500.00 is a fair 
  and equitable sales price.â€ The motion further stated that â€œ[t]he Plaintiffs 
  are informed and believe that the (17.22) acre tract of land . . . should be 
  sold at public auction by the Jasper County Clerk of Court.â€Â  While requesting 
  sale by public auction, the motion does not specifically raise the issue of 
  whether the referee erred â€œin ordering a private sale to an individual who was 
  not an heir without the express consent of the plaintiffs and other heirs owning 
  an interest in the propertyâ€ as raised in Appellantsâ€™ brief.Â  Accordingly, the 
  issue is not preserved for review on appeal by this court.Â  See Wilder 
  Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic 
  that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been 
  raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
The issue fails on the merits as well.Â  Appellants 
  sought the sale of the property without specifying the method.Â  Appellants did 
  not appeal the order of the referee on the issue of holding open the time for 
  receipt of private bids.Â  In addition, Appellants specifically solicited private 
  bids from several individuals. 
Appellants cannot now complain of the method used 
  by the court to sell the property when they consented to the method and even 
  sought to take advantage of it by soliciting private bids from parties who were 
  not heirs.Â  Orr filed the bid in accordance with the method and within the time 
  allotted by the referee.Â  Accordingly, we find the referee properly allowed 
  the property to be sold in a private sale as opposed to requiring a public auction.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Amount of Bid
Appellantsâ€™ main contention appears to be that 
  the value received for the property was far below the appraised value, and therefore, 
  the referee was without evidentiary support in finding the bid was fair and 
  equitable.Â  We disagree.
Appellants cite Pruitt v. Pruitt, 298 S.C. 
  411, 414-15, 380 S.E.2d 862, 864 (Ct. App. 1989), for the contention that where 
  there is disparate testimony regarding the value of the property, partition 
  by public sale is appropriate.Â  However, the trial court in Pruitt apportioned 
  the property to one of the parties.Â  Id.Â  In the case sub judice, 
  the property was sold to a private bidder after numerous bids were solicited 
  and no other bid was received.Â  We find the holding in Pruitt to be inapposite 
  to the instant case.
While the appraisal of the property is evidence 
  of the value of the 17-acre tract, it is not the only evidence present in the 
  record, nor must the court find a bid unreasonable if it is below the appraised 
  value.Â  See Freeman v. Freeman, 323 S.C. 95, 105-06, 473 S.E.2d 
  467, 474 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The record also indicates, and the referee specifically 
  noted the fact Appellants contacted individuals soliciting bids on the property 
  without receiving a single response.Â  
Additionally, the referee specifically stated he 
  considered the appraisal, the value of land in the area, and the tax assessed 
  value of the property.Â  Even though we have authority to find all facts with 
  our own view of the preponderance of the evidence, we are not required to ignore 
  the findings of the referee.Â  Id. at 98, 473 S.E.2d at 469-70.Â  Accordingly, 
  we find there is evidence in the record indicating the sole bid received for 
  the property was a fair and reasonable amount for the property and the referee 
  did not err in ordering the private sale to Orr.
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Beatrice Devore Bing passed away during the proceedings and her interest 
    in the property transferred to her children. 

 
   [2]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [3]  The sale and amount received for the 8.9-acre tract are not subject 
    to this appeal.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

Elaine Helms and Linda R. Cowart,

Of Whom Elaine Helms is

Appeal From Horry County
John L. Breeden, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-098
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  10, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
E. Windell McCrackin, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Elaine Helms, of Lancaster, and Susan P. MacDonald, of Myrtle 
  Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In an action for life insurance 
  proceeds, Linda Cowart (â€œCowartâ€) appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of 
  interpleader and summary judgment in favor of United of Omaha Life Insurance 
  Company (â€œUnited of Omahaâ€) and its denial of Cowartâ€™s summary judgment motion.Â  
  We affirm. [1] Â Â  
FACTS
In 1999, United of Omaha issued a life 
  insurance policy in the amount of $30,000 on behalf of William B. Cowart.Â  According 
  to the policy terms, the owner of the policy is â€œ(a) the Insured or, (b) the 
  applicant if a person other than the Insured applied for this policy, or (c) 
  the assignee of record in the case of an assignment of ownership.â€Â  On the application 
  for the policy, Cowart, Williamâ€™s wife, is listed as the primary beneficiary, 
  and the word â€œownerâ€ is handwritten next to her name. 
  [2] Â  Other than this handwritten notation, no evidence suggests William 
  ever assigned ownership of the policy.Â  
After William became ill in November 2001, Cowart 
  moved out of the marital home and William moved in with his sister, Elaine Helms.Â  
  Thereafter, William submitted a change of beneficiary form to United of Omaha 
  and designated Helms as the primary beneficiary.Â  United of Omaha in turn issued 
  a beneficiary endorsement effective January 5, 2002.Â  
After William died on 
  March 24, 2002, both Cowart and Helms submitted claims for the proceeds of the 
  policy.Â  In April 2002, Cowart made a written request to United of Omaha, asking 
  it not to pay the proceeds until a court could determine the matter.Â  Because 
  United of Omaha could only pay one beneficiary, it filed an interpleader action, 
  pursuant to Rule 22, SCRCP.Â  Cowart answered and counterclaimed against United 
  of Omaha, alleging breach of contract and bad faith for failure to pay the proceeds 
  to her.Â  Cowart also cross-claimed against Helms, alleging undue influence.Â Â  

Cowart filed a motion for summary judgment 
  as to her counterclaims.Â  United of Omaha moved to deposit the funds with the 
  clerk of court, to be dismissed from the case, and to dismiss Cowartâ€™s counterclaims.Â  
  The court denied Cowartâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  The court determined 
  that United of Omaha was entitled to deposit the policy proceeds with the clerk 
  of court and to be relieved from liability pursuant to Rule 22, SCRCP.Â  The 
  court further found that United of Omaha was entitled to summary judgment as 
  to Cowartâ€™s breach of contract and bad faith counterclaims.Â  Cowart appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Interpleader
Cowart argues the trial court 
  erred in granting interpleader to United of Omaha because United of Omaha was 
  not a neutral stakeholder.Â  We disagree.
In an appeal from a grant of 
  interpleader, this court examines whether the evidence before the trial court 
  was sufficient to support its grant of interpleader.Â  First Union Natâ€™l Bank 
  of South Carolina v. FCVS Communications, 321 S.C. 496, 499, 469 S.E.2d 
  613, 616 (Ct. App. 1997), revâ€™d in part, 328 S.C. 290, 494 S.E.2d 429 
  (1997) (dismissing as moot the writ of certiorari as to interpleader).Â  When 
  claims are such that a plaintiff is or may be exposed to double or multiple 
  liability, the claimaints may be joined as defendants and required to interplead.Â  
  Rule 22(a), SCRCP.Â  â€œâ€˜The historical and still the primary purpose of interpleader 
  is to enable a neutral stakeholder, usually an insurance company or a bank, 
  to shield itself from liability for paying over the stake to the wrong party.â€™â€Â  
  FCVS Communications, 321 S.C. at 499, 469 S.E.2d at 616 (quoting Indianapolis 
  Colts v. Mayor of Baltimore, 733 F.2d 484, 486 (7th Cir. 1984)).Â  Only the 
  potential for multiple claims is needed.Â  Id. at 499, 469 S.E.2d at 616.
In FCVS Communications, 
  First Union National Bank held the account for the partnership FCVS Communications.Â  
  When it became unclear who had the authority to transact business on the account, 
  the bank filed an interpleader action against the partnership and individual 
  partners in order to clarify the competing claims.Â  This court upheld the trial 
  courtâ€™s grant of interpleader in light of the conflicting claims to the funds.Â  
  FCVS Communications, 321 S.C. at 501, 469 S.E.2d at 617.Â  
Cowart argues that, unlike the 
  bank in FCVS Communications, United of Omaha is not a â€œneutral stakeholderâ€ 
  because it is trying to shield itself from liability due to its actions in changing 
  the beneficiary.Â  Thus, she argues, its actions do not fit within the purpose 
  of Rule 22, SCRCP. 
We find that United of Omaha, 
  like the bank in FCVS Communications, faced competing claims to the insurance 
  proceeds, thus exposing itself to double liability.Â  Here, both claims are arguably 
  valid. Â This alone justifies an action for interpleader.Â  Rule 22(a), SCRCP 
  (â€œPersons having claims against the plaintiff may be joined as defendants and 
  required to interplead when their claims are such that the plaintiff is or may 
  be exposed to double or multiple liability.â€).Â  Further, we conclude there is 
  no evidence that United of Omaha was not a â€œneutral stakeholder.â€Â  United of 
  Omaha sought to pay the proceeds due under the policy, despite Cowartâ€™s allegation 
  that United of Omaha inappropriately changed the beneficiary in this case.Â  
  Whether or not the beneficiary was appropriately changed has no effect on United 
  of Omahaâ€™s duty to pay; it merely affects to whom the proceeds are paid.Â  Thus, 
  United of Omaha was sufficiently neutral. 
To further support her argument, 
  Cowart cites to Citizens Bank of Forsyth v. Middlebrooks, 72 S.E.2d 298 
  (Ga. 1952), in which the Georgia Supreme Court denied an institutionâ€™s action 
  for interpleader.Â  The Middlebrooks court found that a stakeholder was 
  not entitled to interpleader because the stakeholder was in possession of all 
  the facts and there was no reasonably debatable question of law.Â  Id. 
  at 332.Â  This case is not helpful to Cowart, however, because here, the question 
  of the owner of the policy as well as the appropriate beneficiary is indeed 
  a question of law that is reasonably debatable.Â  Thus, even pursuant to Middlebrooks, 
  the grant of interpleader in the present case was appropriate.
Because the evidence presented 
  to the trial court was sufficient to demonstrate United of Omaha was exposed 
  to multiple liability consistent with Rule 22, SCRCP, and South Carolina case 
  law, we find no error in its decision to grant interpleader.
  II.              
Grant of Summary Judgment as to Cowartâ€™s Counterclaims 
   
Cowart argues the trial court 
  erred in granting summary judgment in favor of United of Omaha on her bad faith 
  and breach of contract claims because United of Omahaâ€™s motion was made under 
  Rules 12 and 22, SCRCP.Â  She argues the trial court was precluded from granting 
  a motion for summary judgment because she was never given notice.Â  We disagree.
In reviewing the grant of a 
  summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard that 
  governs the trial court under Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  Nexsen v. Haddock, 353 
  S.C. 74, 77, 576 S.E.2d 183, 185 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate 
  when no genuine issue of material fact exists and the moving party is entitled 
  to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Id.Â  In ruling on a motion for summary 
  judgment, the evidence and the inferences that can be drawn therefrom should 
  be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  George v. 
  Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  
If a court considers matters 
  outside the pleadings when deciding on a motion to dismiss, the motion will 
  be treated as one for summary judgment pursuant to Rule 56, SCRCP, provided 
  the parties are given the requisite notice and opportunity to present outside 
  materials pertinent to a Rule 56, SCRCP, motion.Â  Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP; Johnson 
  v. Dailey, 318 S.C. 318, 321, 457 S.E.2d 613, 615 (1995).Â  
In its December 16, 2002 reply 
  to Cowartâ€™s counterclaims, United of Omaha moved to dismiss the counterclaims 
  generally pursuant to Rules 12 and 22, SCRCP.Â  On the same date, United of Omaha 
  filed a motion to be relieved from liability and moved to have the bad faith 
  counterclaim dismissed pursuant to Rule 12, SCRCP.Â  Nearly a year later, in 
  November 2003, Cowart filed a separate motion for summary judgment as to her 
  counterclaims, she submitted an affidavit, and a hearing was held on all the 
  motions.Â  United of Omaha filed the November 11, 2003 affidavit of Tom Groves, 
  with supporting exhibits, prior to the hearing, and it was submitted to the 
  trial court without objection.Â  
Cowart claims that 
  she did not have the requisite notice that the trial court intended to transform 
  United of Omahaâ€™s motions to dismiss into motions for summary judgment until 
  she received the courtâ€™s order.Â  Although notice pursuant to Rule 56, SCRCP, 
  must be given when a trial court converts a motion to dismiss into one for summary 
  judgment, Cowart did not move before the trial court for reconsideration based 
  upon her lack of notice.Â  Because she did not complain about the conversion 
  and the lack of notice to the trial court, thus denying the court the opportunity 
  to rule upon the matter, her issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See 
  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 
  (2000) (holding that matters not raised to and ruled upon by the trial court 
  are not preserved for appellate review); In re Estate of Timmerman, 331 
  S.C. 455, 460, 502 S.E.2d 920, 922 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding that when a party 
  receives an order granting certain relief not previously contemplated or presented 
  to the trial court, the aggrieved party must move pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, 
  to alter or amend the judgment in order to preserve the issue for appellate 
  review).Â  Further, Cowart was not caught by surprise at the hearing because 
  she was able to present outside materials at the hearing in support of her own 
  motion for summary judgment.Â  
Because Cowart failed to complain 
  to the trial court that conversion was improper and she was nevertheless able 
  to present her own materials, this issue has no merit. 
  [3] 
CONCLUSION
The trial court did 
  not err in granting United of Omahaâ€™s motion for interpleader.Â  Cowartâ€™s issue 
  regarding the conversion of the motion to dismiss into one for summary judgment 
  is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Further, the denial of Cowartâ€™s motion 
  for summary judgment is not appealable.Â  Accordingly, the order of the trial 
  court is
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.Â  

 
   
    [2]  The policy itself refers to the application or endorsement for beneficiary 
    information. Â 

 
   
    [3]  Cowart also argues that the trial court erred in denying her motion 
    for summary judgment as to her contract counterclaim.Â  It is well-settled 
    that the denial of a motion for summary judgment is not appealable.Â  Olson 
    v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 354 S.C. 161, 168, 580 S.E.2d 440, 
    444 (2003).Â  Thus, we decline to address Cowartâ€™s argument on this issue.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD 
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Bobby Joe Reeves,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-099
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  10, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz III, of Columbia; 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Bobby Joe Reeves appeals his 
  conviction for first-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  He contends 
  the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to convict him of this 
  offense because the indictment did not identify the victim by name and did not 
  state the offense with sufficient certainty and particularity.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
In 1990, when the victim was eight months 
  old, her mother met Reeves through a mutual friend.Â  For financial reasons, 
  the victim and her mother moved in with Reeves.Â  During this time, the victim 
  became attached to Reeves and viewed him as a father figure.Â  Reeves moved out 
  of the home when the victim was five years old.Â  Despite the move, Reeves maintained 
  contact with the victim and her mother.Â  The victim had overnight visits with 
  Reeves almost every other weekend. 
In 1998, the victim and her mother moved 
  to Georgia.Â  Reeves continued to maintain a relationship with the victim 
  until July 4, 2000.Â  According to the victimâ€™s mother, the victim began to act 
  â€œunusualâ€ after the July 4th weekend.Â  Toward the latter part of July 2000, 
  Reeves contacted the victimâ€™s mother to schedule a visit with the victim.Â  When 
  the victim refused to go to Reevesâ€™ home, the victimâ€™s mother questioned her 
  about her decision.Â  The victim told her mother that Reeves had sexually abused 
  her on several occasions during her visits.
Immediately after this conversation, 
  the victimâ€™s mother contacted law enforcement in Augusta, Georgia.Â  On July 
  31, 2000, the case was referred to the Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  
  Ultimately, a Richland County grand jury indicted Reeves for one count of lewd 
  act upon a child and first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor.Â  
  A jury convicted Reeves of both charges and the trial judge imposed concurrent, 
  fifteen-year sentences.
DISCUSSION
For the first time on appeal, Reeves challenges his 
  conviction for first-degree CSC with a minor on the ground the indictment was 
  invalid. [2] Â  Specifically, he 
  contends the trial court was divested of subject matter jurisdiction to convict 
  him of this offense because the indictment did not identify the victim by name 
  and did not state the offense with sufficient certainty and particularity.Â  
  Based on these alleged deficiencies, Reeves characterizes the indictment as 
  â€œincomprehensible.â€Â  We disagree.
Issues relating to subject matter jurisdiction 
  may be raised at any time.Â  Browning v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 368, 465 
  S.E.2d 358, 359 (1995).Â  A circuit court has subject matter jurisdiction if:Â  
  (1) there has been an indictment that sufficiently states the offense; (2) there 
  has been a waiver of indictment; or (3) the charge is a lesser-included charge 
  of the crime charged in the indictment.Â  Id.; see Brown v. 
  State, 343 S.C. 342, 346, 540 S.E.2d 846, 849 (2001) (stating acts of a 
  court with respect to a matter to which it has no subject matter jurisdiction 
  are void).Â  
South Carolina appellate courts have held 
  the sufficiency of an indictment â€œmust be viewed with a practical eye; all the 
  surrounding circumstances must be weighed before an accurate determination of 
  whether a defendant was or was not prejudiced can be reached.â€ State v. Adams, 
  277 S.C. 115, 125, 283 S.E.2d 582, 588 (1981), overruled on other grounds 
  by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).
An indictment is sufficient if it contains the necessary 
  elements of the offense intended to be charged and sufficiently apprises the 
  defendant of what he must be prepared to meet.Â  Browning, 320 S.C. at 
  368, 465 S.E.2d at 359; State v. Gill, 355 S.C. 234, 238, 584 S.E.2d 
  432, 434 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied (Sept. 23, 2004).Â  â€œFurther, an 
  indictment is sufficient if the offense is stated with sufficient certainty 
  and particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and 
  the defendant to know what he is called upon to answer and whether he may plead 
  an acquittal or conviction thereon.â€ State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 628-29, 
  591 S.E.2d 600, 603 (2004).Â  â€œAn indictment phrased substantially in language 
  of a statute which creates and defines the offense is ordinarily sufficient.â€Â  
  Id. at 628, 591 S.E.2d at 603; see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-20 (2003) 
  (â€œEvery indictment shall be deemed and judged sufficient and good in law which, 
  in addition to allegations as to time and place, as required by law, charges 
  the crime substantially in the language of the common law or of the statute 
  prohibiting the crime or so plainly that the nature of the offense charged may 
  be easily understood and, if the offense be a statutory offense, that the offense 
  be alleged to be contrary to the statute in such case made and provided.â€).
In the instant case, the indictment for first-degree 
  CSC with a minor provided:

That Bobby Joe Reeves did in Richland County between June 
  30 and July 4, 2000, wilfully, unlawfully and feloniously commit a sexual battery 
  to wit:Â  sexual intercourse and/or fellatio and/or any intrusion, however slight, 
  of any part of a personâ€™s body or of any object into the genital and/or anal 
  opening of a personâ€™s body, except when such intrusion is accomplished for medically 
  recognized treatment or diagnostic purposes, who at the time was less than 11 
  years of age.Â  All in violation of SC Code of Laws Â§ 16-3-655.

â€œA person is guilty of criminal sexual 
  conduct in the first degree if the actor engages in sexual battery with the 
  victim who is less than eleven years of age.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655 (1) 
  (2003).Â  A â€˜[s]exual batteryâ€™ means sexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio, 
  anal intercourse, or any intrusion, however slight, of any part of a personâ€™s 
  body or of any object into the genital or anal openings of another personâ€™s 
  body, except when such intrusion is accomplished for medically recognized treatment 
  or diagnostic purposes.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-651(h) (2003). 
In terms of Reevesâ€™ complaint concerning 
  the Stateâ€™s failure to identify the victim by name, we find this omission did 
  not invalidate the indictment.Â  In several cases, this court and our supreme 
  court have found amendments that corrected the names of victims did not change 
  the nature of the charged offense, and, thus, did not deprive the circuit court 
  of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  See State v. Sweat, 221 S.C. 
  270, 273-74, 70 S.E.2d 234, 235-36 (1952) (holding nature of offense of larceny 
  was not changed when State amended indictment to change the name of the victim); 
  State v. Oâ€™Neal, 210 S.C. 305, 309, 42 S.E.2d 523, 524-25 (1947) (finding 
  amendment to indictment to correct name of defendant did not change the nature 
  of the offense charged); State v. McGill, 191 S.C. 1, 4-5, 3 S.E.2d 257, 
  258-59 (1939) (finding issues regarding the victimâ€™s name in an indictment do 
  not involve the circuit courtâ€™s jurisdiction); State v. Barnett, 358 
  S.C. 199, 201 n.1, 594 S.E.2d 534, 535 n.1 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding, in case 
  involving charge of grand larceny of a vehicle, amendment to name of owner of 
  the vehicle was not a jurisdictional flaw); State v. Johnson, 314 S.C. 
  161, 166, 442 S.E.2d 191, 194 (Ct. App. 1994) (holding amendment to substitute 
  the Corporation for the Foundation involved in charge of breach of trust with 
  fraudulent intent did not deprive the circuit court of subject matter jurisdiction 
  where â€œnature of the crime charged in the original indictments was not changed 
  by the substitution of the victim in the amended indictmentsâ€); cf. State 
  v. Bryson, 357 S.C. 106, 112, 591 S.E.2d 637, 640 (Ct. App. 2003) (concluding 
  amendment to replace name of one victim with another involved in charge of assaulting 
  an officer while resisting arrest divested the circuit court of subject matter 
  jurisdiction given the â€œamendment replaced the properly indicted count of assaulting 
  an officer while resisting arrest with a second unindicted count of the same 
  crimeâ€).
Although this case involved the omission 
  of the victimâ€™s name and not an amendment, we find the principles outlined in 
  the above-cited cases are applicable.Â  Moreover, we believe our supreme courtâ€™s 
  decision in Thompson v. State, 357 S.C. 192, 593 S.E.2d 139 (2004), is 
  dispositive of this issue.Â  In Thompson, the defendant pleaded guilty 
  to murder, armed robbery, and two counts of criminal conspiracy.Â  Several years 
  after the plea, Thompson petitioned our supreme court for a writ of certiorari 
  alleging for the first time that the trial court was without subject matter 
  jurisdiction because the indictments charging him with criminal conspiracy were 
  insufficient.Â  One of the grounds raised by Thompson was the fact that the indictments 
  did not identify the victim and the co-conspirator and did not specify facts 
  upon which the charges were based.Â  Our supreme court rejected this contention, 
  finding â€œthe alleged defects regarding the victimâ€™s name, the co-conspiratorâ€™s 
  identity, and the particular details of the conspiracy are defects that are 
  facially apparent and do not involve the elements of the offense.â€Â  Id. 
  at 196, 593 S.E.2d at 141.Â  
Applying Thompson to the instant 
  case, we hold the Stateâ€™s failure to identify the victim by name did not constitute 
  a jurisdictional defect. [3] Â  
  Given this holding, we find it was incumbent upon Reeves to raise this challenge 
  prior to trial.Â  
Furthermore, viewing the indictment â€œwith 
  a practical eye,â€ we hold it stated the offense of first-degree CSC with a minor 
  with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the trial court and Reeves 
  to know what crime was alleged.Â  Both the caption of the indictment and title 
  preceding the body of the indictment identified the charged offense as first-degree 
  criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  Additionally, the body of the indictment 
  identified the applicable statute, described the alleged sexual battery in terms 
  of the statute, and identified the age of the victim as less than eleven years 
  old.
In support of his 
  argument, Reeves directs our attention to this courtâ€™s decision in State 
  v. Ellison, 356 S.C. 33, 586 S.E.2d 596 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  We find, however, 
  that Ellison is distinguishable from the instant case.Â  In Ellison, 
  the defendant was indicted pursuant to an allegation that he sexually assaulted 
  a thirteen-year-old girl.Â  The caption of the indictment and the title preceding 
  the body of the indictment identified the offense as first-degree CSC with a 
  minor.Â  The body of the indictment stated the victim was thirteen years old 
  and the sexual battery was committed using aggravated force and aggravated coercion.Â  
  Id. at 35, 586 S.E.2d at 597.Â  At the beginning of the trial, the State 
  moved, without objection, to amend the indictment to charge the defendant with 
  first-degree CSC.Â  The trial court instructed the jury on the offense of first-degree 
  CSC and, on its own initiative, charged the jury on second-degree CSC with a 
  minor as a lesser-included offense.Â  Id. at 36, 586 S.E.2d at 597.Â  The 
  jury convicted the defendant of second-degree CSC with a minor.Â  
On appeal, this court vacated 
  the defendantâ€™s conviction, finding the trial court was without subject matter 
  jurisdiction to convict the defendant of this offense.Â  Specifically, the court 
  found:Â  1). second-degree CSC with a minor was not a lesser-included offense 
  of first-degree CSC; and 2). the original indictment did not sufficiently state 
  the offense for which the defendant was indicted.Â  Regarding the insufficiency 
  of the indictment language, we concluded:Â  1). the body of the indictment contained 
  allegations for second-degree CSC with a minor, first-degree CSC, and second-degree 
  CSC; and 2). the caption and title of the indictment alleged the crime of first-degree 
  CSC with a minor.Â  Id. at 38, 586 S.E.2d at 598.Â Â  Based on these discrepancies, 
  we held the indictment was unclear as to what judgment the court could pronounce 
  and sentence it could impose.Â  Id. at 38, 586 S.E.2d at 598. 
Unlike Ellison, the 
  indictment in the instant case clearly alleged in the caption, title, and body 
  that Reeves was being charged only with first-degree CSC with a minor.Â Â Â  
Finally, to the extent Reeves characterizes 
  the indictment as â€œincomprehensible,â€ we also find this argument to be without 
  merit.Â  Because the sexual battery described in the indictment merely tracked 
  the language of the definitional statute, Reeves contends he was not apprised 
  of what he was called upon to answer.Â  Initially, we note the fact that indictment 
  used the statutory language weighs in favor of finding the indictment sufficient 
  given it â€œcharges the crime substantially in the language . . . of the statute 
  prohibiting the crime.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-20 (2003).Â  Furthermore, the 
  victim alleged Reeves forced her to perform oral sex and digitally penetrated 
  her on one occasion.Â  Thus, the victimâ€™s allegations involved different types 
  of sexual battery that are encompassed in the language of the indictment.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the 
  circuit court had subject matter jurisdiction to convict Reeves of first-degree 
  CSC with a minor.Â  Accordingly, Reevesâ€™ convictions and sentences for first-degree 
  CSC with a minor and lewd act upon a minor are
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the 
    issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â  We note Reeves does not appeal his conviction and sentence for lewd 
    act upon a minor.Â  Because he received a concurrent, fifteen-year term of 
    imprisonment, we need not address his issue on appeal.Â  However, given this 
    issue involves questions of subject matter jurisdiction, we decline to apply 
    the â€œconcurrent sentence doctrine.â€Â  State v. Ervin, 333 S.C. 351, 
    359, 510 S.E.2d 220, 225 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  

 
   
    [3] Â Â  We would also point out that the victim was identified by name 
    in the indictment for lewd act upon a minor, the victim testified during an 
    in camera hearing prior to the trial, and the trial judge identified the victim 
    by name during jury selection.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
John E. Stone,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-100
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 10, 2005 


APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender 
  Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliot, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: John E. Stone appeals from his 
  conviction for kidnapping and first-degree criminal sexual conduct, arguing 
  the trial court erred in instructing the jury that the testimony of the victim 
  need not be corroborated.Â  Â Â Stoneâ€™s counsel attached to the brief a petition 
  to be relieved as counsel, stating that he had reviewed the record and concluded 
  this appeal lacks merit.Â  After a thorough review of the record and counselâ€™s 
  brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State 
  v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss [1]  Stoneâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s motion to 
  be relieved.
APPEAL DISMISSED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Rebecca J. Waters,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Sheldon K. Waters,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-102
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 10, 2005 


AFFIRMED in part, REVERSED in part, 
  and REMANDED


  
    
      
Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Catherine E. Fairey and O. Doyle Martin, both of Greenville 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this divorce case, Shelden 
  K. Waters (Husband) appeals from the family courtâ€™s order requiring him to pay 
  child support past his minor childâ€™s age of majority, imputing income to him 
  under the child support guidelines, equitably dividing marital debt, and awarding 
  attorneyâ€™s fees to Rebecca J. Waters (Wife).Â  We affirm in part and reverse 
  in part and remand.1Â  
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married for twenty-nine 
  years.Â  The couple lived in Michigan during the first part of their marriage.Â  
  Husband worked at the same job for eighteen years and was the primary wage earner.Â  
  Wife stayed home and cared for the coupleâ€™s four children.Â  Tragically, the 
  coupleâ€™s daughter, Olivia, died in the collapse of a stroller when she was five 
  years old.Â  A lawsuit followed with a judgment of $335,000.Â  The parties used 
  part of the money to set up a trust fund of $30,000 each for their remaining 
  three children of whom Adam was the youngest child with the provision the funds 
  would be available at age eighteen.Â  Following the accident, Husband was extremely 
  depressed.Â  Wife convinced Husband to move to South Carolina despite his reservations 
  about finding commensurate employment.Â  Husband had difficulty obtaining employment 
  at the same pay level he enjoyed in Michigan and although both parties had difficulty 
  dealing with the death of their daughter, Husband continued to support the family 
  after moving to South Carolina.Â  
Despite their attempt to â€œstart over,â€ 
  Husband and Wife continued to experience marital difficulties after moving.Â  
  The couple eventually separated and Wife filed for divorce on the ground of 
  physical cruelty and sought custody, child support, equitable apportionment 
  of the marital property, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Following the separation, Adam, 
  the partiesâ€™ only minor child, experienced significant problems.Â  Adam was arrested 
  several times, assaulted his mother, and was hospitalized following an overdose 
  of alcohol and medication.Â  At the time of the trial, Adam was seventeen years 
  old and not currently enrolled in high school.Â  Wife testified she â€œhopedâ€ Adam 
  would complete his education and she had â€œmade arrangementsâ€ for Adam to attend 
  adult education classes.Â  Wife asserted she would only consent to Adam remaining 
  in her home if he was in school and working.Â  
Notwithstanding Adamâ€™s behavioral difficulties, 
  Wife sought custody of him.Â  Additionally, she sought an increase of child support 
  and continuation of child support for one year after Adam reached majority to 
  allow him to complete his education.Â  At the time of the hearing, Wife was employed 
  as a bookkeeper and earned $43,548 annually.Â  Although Wife testified Husband 
  was a â€œvery hard workerâ€ and supported the family throughout the marriage, Husband 
  lost his job due to layoffs shortly before the final hearing.Â  Husband had earned 
  more than $42,000 per year and was actively seeking employment, but his only 
  income at the time of the hearing was unemployment compensation at the rate 
  of $1,204 per month.Â  Because Husband was not employed at his full earning potential, 
  Wife sought to impute income to Husband to increase his support obligation under 
  the child support guidelines.Â  
By order dated April 22, 2002, the family 
  court granted the parties a divorce based upon one yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  
  Although insufficient to support a finding of physical cruelty as the ground 
  for divorce, the family court also found there was a history of emotional, verbal 
  and physical abuse by Husband.Â  The family court found Husbandâ€™s underemployment 
  was voluntary and imputed income to him in the amount of $10.00 per hour.Â  Husband 
  was ordered to pay child support until Adam graduated from high school or reached 
  age nineteen.Â  The family court apportioned the marital estate equally between 
  the parties.Â  Although disputed by Husband, the family court found Wifeâ€™s credit 
  card debt was incurred for the benefit of both parties and their children.Â  
  Therefore, the marital estate included the credit card debt.Â  The family court 
  also ordered Husband to pay $10,000 of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Husband 
  appeals.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court has 
  the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence. Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 
  414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992). We are not, however, required to disregard the findings 
  of the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position 
  to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony. 
  Haselden v. Haselden, 347 S.C. 48, 58, 552 S.E.2d 329, 334 (Ct. 
  App. 2001); Wilson v. Walker, 340 S.C. 531, 537, 532 S.E.2d 19, 
  22 (Ct. App. 2000).

  LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Child Support
Husband argues the family court erred 
  by ordering him to pay child support past Adamâ€™s age of majority.Â  Specifically, 
  Husband asserts the evidence was insufficient to allow post-majority support 
  because Adam was not making any attempt to complete high school at the time 
  of the final hearing.Â  We agree.
The family court has authority: 

To make all orders for support run until further order of 
  the court, except that orders for child support run until the child is eighteen 
  years of age or until the child is married or becomes self‑supporting, 
  as determined by the court, whichever occurs first or to provide for child support 
  past the age of eighteen years if the child is in high school and is making 
  satisfactory progress toward completion of high school, not to exceed the nineteenth 
  birthday unless exceptional circumstances are found to exist or unless there 
  is a preexisting agreement or order to provide for child support past the age 
  of eighteen years; and in the discretion of the court, to provide for child 
  support past age eighteen where there are physical or mental disabilities of 
  the child or other exceptional circumstances that warrant the continuation of 
  child support beyond age eighteen for as long as the physical or mental disabilities 
  or exceptional circumstances continue. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(17) (Supp.2004).Â  In addition, child support awards 
  are addressed to the sound discretion of the family court and, absent an abuse 
  of discretion, will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Mitchell v. Mitchell, 
  283 S.C. 87, 92, 320 S.E.2d 706, 710 (1984). Abuse of discretion occurs when 
  the court is controlled by an error of law, or where the order, based upon findings 
  of fact, has no evidentiary support.Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 
  485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).
In the instant case, the family court ordered Husband to pay child 
  support for Adam â€œuntil he graduates from high school or reaches the age of 
  nineteen, whichever occurs first.â€Â  No evidence suggests Adam was â€œmaking satisfactory 
  progress toward completion of high schoolâ€ as required by section 20-7-420(17).Â  
  Adam spent little time in Wifeâ€™s home and Wifeâ€™s testimony was speculative at 
  best.Â  Wife offered no direct evidence Adam was attending high school; she only 
  expressed her â€œhopeâ€ Adam would complete high school and asserted she was â€œmaking 
  arrangementsâ€ for him to attend adult education.Â  In addition to revealing Adam 
  was not complying with the statuteâ€™s mandate, the record clearly reveals the 
  parties provided Adam with his own resources to help offset school expenses.Â  
  Upon reaching age eighteen, Adam would become entitled to the corpus of his 
  $30,000 trust fund.Â  Therefore, we find the family court erred in ordering Husband 
  to continue paying child support past Adamâ€™s age of majority.Â  
2.Â  Imputation of Income
Husband next argues the 
  family court erred in its calculation of child support under the South Carolina 
  child support guidelines.Â  Husband asserts the family court incorrectly imputed 
  $10 per hour to him without sufficient evidence Husbandâ€™s failure to reach his 
  full earning potential was voluntary.Â  We agree.
Under the child support 
  guidelines, income is defined as â€œactual gross income of the parent, if employed 
  to full capacity, or potential income if unemployed or underemployed.â€Â  27 S.C. 
  Code Ann. Regs. 114-4720(A) (Supp. 2004).Â  Regarding the imputation of income, 
  the guidelines provide:Â  

If the court finds that a parent is voluntarily unemployed 
  or underemployed, it should calculate child support based on a determination 
  of potential income which would otherwise ordinarily be available to the parent. 
  . . .
(b) In order to impute income to a parent who is unemployed 
  or underemployed, the court should determine the employment potential and probable 
  earnings level of the parent based on that parentâ€™s recent work history, occupational 
  qualifications, and prevailing job opportunities and earning levels in the community.

27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs 114-4720(A)(5) (Supp. 2004).Â  Additionally, 
  â€œ[w]hen the court orders a child support award that varies significantly from 
  the amount resulting from the application of the guidelines, the court shall 
  make specific, written findings of those facts upon which it bases its conclusion 
  supporting that award.â€Â  27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs 114-4710(A)(1) (Supp. 2004).Â  
  â€œThe failure to reach earning capacity by itself, does not automatically equate 
  to voluntary underemployment such that income must be imputed.â€Â  Kelley v. 
  Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 488-89, 477 S.E.2d 727, 731 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Instead, 
  when actual income versus earning capacity is at issue, the court should closely 
  examine the payorâ€™s good faith and reasonable explanation for the decreased 
  income.Â  Id. at 489, 477 S.E.2d at 731.Â  
Here, no evidence indicates Husbandâ€™s loss of his 
  prior job resulted from wrongdoing or was motivated by a desire to avoid his 
  support obligation.Â  Husband worked at the same job in Michigan for over eighteen 
  years and moved to South Carolina only at his Wifeâ€™s insistence.Â  Although Husband 
  had difficulty finding comparable employment in South Carolina, he was the primary 
  wage earner throughout the marriage.Â  Wife admitted Husband was a â€œvery hard 
  workerâ€ and always provided for the family.Â  Moreover, Husband did not voluntarily 
  leave his job but was dismissed due to company lay offs.Â  He was still receiving 
  unemployment benefits at the time of trial and was actively seeking employment.Â  
  Thus, the family court erred in its determination Husband was voluntarily underemployed.Â  
  Husband had a good faith and reasonable explanation for his underemployment; 
  therefore, the family court should not have imputed income to him and should 
  have based his child support obligation on his actual income. 
3.Â  Equitable Apportionment of Marital Debt
Husband next argues the family court erred in its 
  apportionment of Wifeâ€™s credit card debt.Â  We disagree.
â€œMarital propertyâ€ is defined as â€œall real and personal property 
  which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned 
  as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation . . . .â€ S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp.2004).Â  In making an equitable apportionment, the 
  family court should consider â€œ. . . any other existing debts incurred by the 
  parties or either of them during the course of the marriage[.]â€ S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 20-7-472(13) (Supp. 2004). â€œ[S]ection 20-7-472 creates a [rebuttable] presumption 
  that a debt either spouse incurred prior to marital litigation is a marital 
  debt and must be factored in the totality of equitable apportionment.â€Â  Hardy 
  v. Hardy, 311 S.C. 433, 436, 429 S.E.2d 811, 813 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
  â€œBecause Hardy establishes a presumption in favor of treating a debt 
  as marital when it is incurred prior to marital litigation, the party claiming 
  the debt is nonmarital bears the burden to overcome that presumption.â€Â  Wooten 
  v. Wooten, 358 S.C. 54, 60, 594 S.E.2d 854, 857 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
The family court effectuated a fifty-fifty division of the 
  marital estate and ordered Husband to pay $9,000 of credit card debt.Â  Although 
  Wife accrued the credit card debt prior to initiating the marital litigation, 
  Husband contends she ran up the debt in contemplation of divorce.Â  He argues 
  the debt should be treated like an asset secreted or disposed of in contemplation 
  of divorce and its value assessed against Wifeâ€™s share of the marital estate.Â  
  See Cooksey v. Cooksey, 280 S.C. 347, 352, 312 S.E.2d 581, 585 
  (Ct. App. 1984).Â  However, Husband offered no evidence to substantiate this 
  claim, and therefore, did not overcome the presumption the debt was incurred 
  for the benefit of the marriage.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the equitable 
  apportionment of the marital debt.Â  
4. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband argues the court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s 
  fees to Wife.Â  We agree and remand for adjustment of award after child support 
  changes.
One of the factors to be considered in awarding 
  reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and cost is the beneficial results obtained. Â Glasscock 
  v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  As we have 
  found in favor of the Husband on several of his issues, we remand the issue 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees to the family court for any adjustments it determines are 
  necessary in light of our opinion.
CONCLUSION
We find the family court erred in ordering Husband 
  to pay child support past Adamâ€™s age of majority because he was not making satisfactory 
  progress toward the completion of high school.Â  We affirm the equitable apportionment 
  of marital debt.Â  We reverse the imputation of income to the Husband and the 
  order for the Husband to pay child support past Adamâ€™s age of majority.Â  We 
  remand to the family court for the recalculation of child support.Â  In addition, 
  we remand the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees to the family court for redetermination.Â  
  Accordingly, the order of the family court is 
AFFIRMED in part, and REVERSED in part, and REMANDED.Â  

HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â  

 
  1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.
