THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Jadie C. Rayfield,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
LifeQuest,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-103
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 10, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Marvin Lee Robertson, Jr., of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant
Steven McKelvey and Thomas William McGee, III, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  Jadie C. Rayfield appeals 
  the circuit courtâ€™s order dismissing a rule to show cause, arguing the court 
  erred in finding no contempt of its order prohibiting the transfer of assets 
  by a judgment debtor in Rayfieldâ€™s personal injury action.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
Rayfield brought a personal injury action in 1998 
  in connection with injuries he sustained while using weightlifting equipment 
  at LifeQuest Fitness Center in Mount Pleasant.Â  In January 2000, he obtained 
  a $35,000 default judgment against â€œLIFEQUESTâ€ and subsequently filed an execution 
  against property that was executed nulla bona.Â  
This case involves multiple corporate entities 
  with similar names, a common registered agent for service of process, and some 
  common shareholders.Â  The first entity is Life Quest, Inc. (LQ1), which incorporated 
  in August 1991.Â  In January 1992, LQ1â€™s shareholders changed the companyâ€™s name 
  to LifeQuest of Mount Pleasant, Inc. (LQMP) and filed the change with the secretary 
  of stateâ€™s office in April 1992.Â  The second entity, LifeQuest, Inc. (LQ2), 
  incorporated in April 1992.Â  The third entity, LifeQuest of Charleston, Inc., 
  (LQC) incorporated later.Â  Wayne K. Caparas served as the registered agent for 
  each of these corporations. Steve DeGuzman and he owned LifeQuest shares.Â  
From 1992 to 1994, entities identified 
  as â€œLife Quest, Inc.â€ or â€œLifeQuest, Inc.â€ opened utility accounts with South 
  Carolina Electric and Gas, Inc. (SCE&G) for Mount Pleasant and Charleston 
  locations.Â  The entities made security deposits with SCE&G to open the accounts. 

In 1998, a foreclosure action against LQMP and 
  LQC resulted in the judicial sale of all of their assets.Â  SSN, Inc. purchased 
  LQMPâ€™s assets and SKS, Inc. purchased LQCâ€™s assets.Â  Timothy R. Sebold was SSNâ€™s 
  registered agent for service of process.Â  
In November 2002, following return of the nulla 
  bona execution, Rayfield obtained a circuit court order for supplemental 
  proceedings seeking to determine whether his judgment debtor, generally referred 
  to as â€œLifeQuest,â€ possessed any nonexempt property and assets that could be 
  used to satisfy his judgment.Â  Among other things, the order â€œenjoined the judgment 
  debtor â€¦ from making any transfer or other disposition of the property of the 
  judgment debtor, including â€¦ any funds due to the judgment debtor.â€Â  In February 
  2003, the court filed a second order for supplemental proceedings with a similar 
  prohibition on asset transfers after Rayfield discovered SCE&G held approximately 
  $19,375 of deposits in LifeQuestâ€™s name. 
Later in February 2003, Caparas and DeGuzman went to SCE&G 
  and requested that the LifeQuest accounts be closed and the deposits be refunded 
  to them.Â  SCE&G closed the accounts as requested.Â  However, pursuant to 
  company policy, SCE&G first applied the deposits against LifeQuestâ€™s unpaid 
  bill and current usage.Â  SCE&G did not terminate service because LifeQuest 
  continued to operate in the buildings.Â  Instead, it opened new accounts in SSNâ€™s 
  name and credited the remainder of the deposits to the new accounts.Â  
The court issued a rule to show cause in March 
  2003.Â  After a hearing, the court dismissed the rule to show cause, finding 
  SSN had bought all LifeQuest assets, including rights to the SCE&G deposits, 
  at the 1998 foreclosure sale.Â  Rayfieldâ€™s motion to reconsider was denied.Â  
  This appeal followed.
 STANDARD OF 
  REVIEW
This appeal comes to us in the posture of a dismissal 
  of a rule to show cause.Â  As such, we may reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision 
  regarding contempt only if it is without evidentiary support or is an abuse 
  of discretion.Â  Stone v. Reddix-Smalls, 295 S.C. 514, 516, 369 S.E.2d 
  840, 840 (1988).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs where the trial courtâ€™s ruling 
  is based on an error of law.Â  First Union Natâ€™l Bank v. First Citizens Bank 
  & Trust Co., 346 S.C. 462, 466, 551 S.E.2d 301, 303 (Ct. App. 2001).
DISCUSSION
Having carefully reviewed the 
  record, and based on our deferential standard of review, we find evidence to 
  support the findings of the trial court, even if were to consider the conflicting 
  evidence proferred by Rayfield.Â  Moreover, the confusion engendered by the various 
  corporate entities leads us to additionally conclude that, in any event, there 
  was no willful disobedience of a court order.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. 
  Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 417, 526 S.E.2d 716, 722 (2000) (stating 
  that the appellate court may affirm for any reason appearing in the record).
â€œIt is well settled that contempt 
  results from willful disobedience of a court order; and before a person may 
  be held in contempt, the record must be clear and specific as to acts or conduct 
  upon which the contempt is based.â€Â  Cheap-Oâ€™s Truck Stop, 350 S.C. 596, 
  607, 567 S.E.2d 596, 519 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œA willful act is defined as one 
  done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something 
  the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law 
  requires to be done; that is to say with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard 
  the law.â€Â  Id. at 607-08, 567 S.E.2d at 520.
 AFFIRMED. 
 HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  

   
     
      Charles W. King, Plaintiff,
      v.
      Island Club Apartments, a
      South Carolina Limited Partnership, and Finlay Properties, Inc., its
      general partner, Defendants,
      
      Island Club Apartments, a South Carolina Limited Partnership, and Finlay 
        Properties, Inc., its general partner, Third-Party Plaintiffs,
      v.
      Mark du Mas and The Paces Foundation, Inc., a Georgia Corporation, Third-Party 
        Defendants, Of Whom Island Club Apartments, a South Carolina Limited Partnership, 
        and Finlay Properties, its general partner, are,
    
     
      Appellants,
    
  
   
     
      And Mark du Mas and The Paces Foundation, Inc., a Georgia Corporation, 
        are,
    
     
      Respondents.
    
  

  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Thomas Kemmerlin, Special Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-107
Heard January 10, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  10, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stephen A. Husman and Vernon F. Dunbar, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Gregory F. Harley and Marvin H. Dukes, III, of Beaufort, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Island Club Apartments, a South 
  Carolina Limited Partnership, and Finlay Properties, Inc., its general partner 
  (collectively Island Club), filed a third-party complaint against Mark du Mas 
  and The Paces Foundation, Inc. (collectively du Mas), alleging du Mas: intentionally 
  interfered with the contractual relationship between Island Club and Charles 
  King, intentionally interfered with Island Clubâ€™s prospective relationships 
  regarding future development and construction contracts, and engaged in a civil 
  conspiracy to extort an ownership interest in Island Clubâ€™s project.Â  Island 
  Club appeals from the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of du 
  Mas on all claims.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
King and Island Club entered into a contract 
  on April 22, 1999, for Island Club to purchase a tract of land from King for 
  $450,000.00. Island Club planned to develop a low-income apartment complex on 
  the property utilizing state tax credit financing. In order to obtain the financing, 
  Island Club had to close on the project no later than November 15, 1999, which 
  was provided in the contract.Â  Additionally, the contract required Island Club 
  to immediately pay $2,500.00 and deposit $27,500.00 into escrow.Â  The balance 
  of the purchase price was to be paid at the closing.Â  
Following the execution of the contract, 
  Island Club had difficulty obtaining the required permits for the project.Â  
  The delay led Island Club to seek amendments to the purchase contract, which 
  would allow for the closing to occur without simultaneous payment of the remainder 
  of the purchase price.Â  King accepted changes to the original contract by letter.Â  
  Pursuant to these changes, King would receive a payment of $15,000 towards the 
  purchase price at the closing on November 12, 1999; Island Club would pay $1,500 
  to defray any fees incurred by King; and Island Club would provide a promissory 
  note for the remainder of the purchase price due, payable on February 15, 2000.Â  

According to Island Club, King agreed 
  to further changes to the contract during a telephone call on November 11, 1999.Â  
  The alleged oral agreement extended the date of the promissory note until April 
  30, 2000, applied the $15,000 payment to closing costs, and increased the purchase 
  price to $460,000.Â  
Although the letter changed the closing 
  date to November 12, 1999, the parties met on November 15, 1999 to close the 
  transaction. Prior to closing, King met with du Mas, seeking advice regarding 
  the transaction and its structure because du Mas was familiar with tax credit 
  financing. At the closing, du Mas asked questions on behalf of King regarding 
  the real estate deal and Island Clubâ€™s plans.Â  
Island Club presented closing documents 
  which reflected the alleged oral agreement rather than the written contract 
  or the modifications made in the letter.Â  King refused to proceed under the 
  terms of the oral contract and required the parties to close pursuant to the 
  original written contract, including the $450,000 payment. Subsequently, King 
  offered to sell the property if he received $100,000 at closing.Â  Island Club 
  presented testimony that du Mas offered to loan the money to Island Club in 
  exchange for an equity share of the project, though du Mas denied making such 
  an offer.Â  Â 
Regardless of what du Mas did or did not do, it 
  is undisputed that Island Club never tendered closing documents reflecting the 
  original contract or the terms of the written modification.Â  Additionally, Island 
  Club was not prepared to abide by the contract or the modification, which required 
  additional monies at the time of closing.Â  Because the parties could not agree 
  on the terms of the sale, the closing never took place.
King brought a declaratory judgment action 
  seeking a determination of the partiesâ€™ respective rights under the written 
  contracts.Â  Island Club filed counterclaims against King for breach of contract 
  and civil conspiracy, among other claims. [1] Â  Island Club also brought a third 
  party action against du Mas.Â  The third-party complaint alleged du Mas interfered 
  with the contractual relations between King and Island Club and prohibited the 
  closing from proceeding according to the oral agreement.Â  Additionally, the 
  complaint alleged du Mas interfered with the prospective relationships Island 
  Club would form and would benefit from in the development and construction of 
  the project.Â  Finally, the complaint asserted du Mas and King conspired to change 
  the terms of the contract to Island Clubâ€™s detriment and du Mas attempted to 
  extort an ownership interest in the project by changing the terms on the date 
  of the closing.Â  
The trial court granted du Masâ€™s motion 
  for summary judgment as to all claims in Island Clubâ€™s third-party complaint.Â  
  The court found Island Club presented no evidence that King breached any enforceable 
  contract or that du Mas induced any breach.Â  The court found du Mas did not 
  interfere with prospective relations between Island Club and Finlay because 
  Finlay is Island Clubâ€™s general manager and the two integrally related entities 
  would not cease doing business simply because this particular real estate closing 
  did not occur.Â  Additionally, the court found there was no evidence du Mas was 
  the reason the real estate closing was not consummated.Â  Finally, the court 
  found the evidence did not support the remaining substantive claim of a civil 
  conspiracy, and in addition, Island Club failed to plead special damages.Â Â Â  
  Â Â This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, 
  this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court:Â  summary 
  judgment is proper when â€œthere is no genuine issue as to any material fact and 
  the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; 
  Baughman v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-15, 410 S.E.2d 
  537, 545 (1991).Â  â€œOn appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate 
  court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and 
  from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non‑moving party below.â€Â  
  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Enforceable Contract
Island Club first asserts the trial court 
  erred in finding the oral modifications were not enforceable or that the closing 
  documents submitted were not sufficient evidence of the contract between King 
  and Island Club.Â  We disagree and find the trial court properly held the oral 
  modifications were unenforceable.Â  
The trial court properly relied upon the 
  Statute of Frauds in determining:Â  â€œUnder South Carolina law, a contract for 
  the sale of land must be in writing to be enforceable.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  Pursuant to Camp v. Springs Mortgage Corp., 310 S.C. 514, 
  517, 426 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1993), the claim may only be based on the existence 
  of a valid contract.Â  Island Clubâ€™s attorney admitted in his deposition that 
  none of the oral modifications were ever placed in writing. Â 
Island Club also seems to contend the 
  closing documents it provided for signature on November 15, 1999, are evidence 
  of the alleged modifications encompassed in their phone conversation. The documents 
  do not appear in the record on appeal, and therefore, they may not be considered 
  by this court.Â  See Rule 210, SCACR.Â  Furthermore, just as the oral modifications 
  themselves fail to satisfy the Statute of Frauds, so too would the closing documents 
  because there is no indication the documents were signed by King.Â  If King did 
  not sign them, he cannot be held to their contents under section 32-3-10.Â  Accordingly, 
  we must look solely to the written, original contract and the letter modifying 
  the terms of the original contract, which were both signed by King, to determine 
  whether there was any interference by du Mas.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Intentional Interference with Contractual Relations
Island Club next contends the trial court 
  erred in finding there was no evidence of interference by du Mas in enticing 
  King not to go forward with the real estate closing on November 15.Â  Additionally, 
  Island Club contends the court erred in finding du Mas was not a stranger to 
  the contract, but was instead a consultant or agent of King.Â  We disagree.
As found by the trial court:

Under South Carolina law, a plaintiff must establish the following 
  elements to prevail on a claim for intentional interference with contractual 
  relations: (1) the existence of a valid contract; (2) the wrongdoerâ€™s knowledge 
  thereof; (3) his intentional procurement of its breach; (4) the absence of justification; 
  and (5) resulting damages. Camp v. Springs Mortgage Corp., 310 S.C. 514, 
  517, 426 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1993).

The trial court found that du Mas was 
  entitled to summary judgment on the intentional interference with contractual 
  relations cause of action because, among other reasons, there was no evidence 
  that King breached an enforceable contract.Â  We agree.
As found above, the only enforceable contract 
  was the original written contract as modified by the letter signed by King on 
  November 1, 1999.Â  Accordingly, Island Club must show evidence that King breached 
  this contract to support its claim. 
Island Club never presented any evidence 
  of a breach of the written contract by King.Â  It is well-settled that â€œ[o]ne 
  who seeks to recover damages for breach of a contract, to which he was a party, 
  must show that the contract has been performed on his part, or at least that 
  he was, at the appropriate time, able, ready, and willing to perform it.â€Â  Swinton 
  Creek Nursery v. Edisto Farm Credit, ACA, 334 S.C. 469, 487, 514 S.E.2d 
  126, 135 (1999) (quoting Parks v. Lyons, 219 S.C. 40, 48, 64 S.E.2d 123, 
  126 (1951)).Â  Here, Island Club came to the closing prepared only to close in 
  accordance with the oral modifications to the agreement.Â  The promissory note 
  Island Club produced was due April 30th and not February 15th.Â  The HUD-1 statement 
  indicated the monies were in accordance with the oral modifications and not 
  the written agreements.Â  It was only after Island Club sought to close pursuant 
  to the oral modifications that King required the agreement to be completed pursuant 
  to the original contract, which called for a $450,000 cash payment at closing. 

Because Island Club provided no evidence 
  that it attempted to close in accordance with the written agreements, it cannot 
  now complain that King breached the contract.Â  See id.Â  Accordingly, 
  we find the trial court properly determined Island Club failed to present sufficient 
  evidence of a genuine issue of material fact regarding whether King breached 
  the written contracts and du Mas intentionally interfered with the contract. 
  [2] 
III.Â Â Â  Intentional Interference with Prospective Relations
Island Club contends the trial court erred 
  in granting du Mas summary judgment on its claim of intentional interference 
  with the prospective contract between Island Club and Finlay.Â  We disagree and 
  find the trial court properly granted summary judgment to du Mas.

The tort of intentional interference with prospective 
  contractual relations was first recognized in the case of Crandall Corp. 
  v. Navistar [Intern.] Transp. Corp., 302 S.C. 265, 395 S.E.2d 179 (1990).Â  
  The elements of the cause of action are (1) the intentional interference with 
  the plaintiff's potential contractual relations, (2) for an improper purpose 
  or by improper methods, (3) causing injury to the plaintiff.

Â Love v. Gamble, 316 S.C. 203, 214, 448 S.E.2d 876, 882 (Ct. App. 1994).
The Love case also explains what is required to show improper 
  methods necessary to support such a claim.Â  

Methods of interference considered improper are those means 
  that are illegal or independently tortious, such as violations of statutes, 
  regulations, or recognized common-law rules.Â  Improper methods may include violence, 
  threats or intimidation, bribery, unfounded litigation, fraud, misrepresentation 
  or deceit, defamation, duress, undue influence, misuse of inside or confidential 
  information, or breach of a fiduciary relationship.Â  
Methods also may be improper because they violate an established 
  standard of a trade or profession, or involve unethical conduct.Â  Sharp dealing, 
  overreaching, or unfair competition may also constitute improper methods.Â  

Id., at 215, 448 S.E.2d at 882-83 (quoting Duggin 
  v. Adams, 360 S.E.2d 832, 836-37 (1987) (citations omitted)).
The trial court specifically found du Mas could 
  not possibly interfere with the relations between Finlay and Island Club because 
  they were essentially the same entity â€“ Finlay was Island Clubâ€™s general partner.Â  
  The court also concluded there was no evidence of wrongdoing on the part of 
  du Mas. We agree there was no evidence of wrongdoing.Â  In the deposition testimony 
  of representatives of Island Club, no representative could point to any specific 
  method used or anything said by du Mas which caused King to back out of the 
  sale of land, which is the basis for the prospective relationship between Finlay 
  and Island Club.Â  The only contention raised was the offer by du Mas to loan 
  $100,000 in exchange for an equity interest.Â  However, the parties admitted 
  it occurred after Island Club sought to close pursuant to the oral modifications 
  and King demanded a cash payment in order to close on November 15. 
Additionally, it was admitted by attorneys representing Island 
  Club and Finlay that they did not recall anything du Mas said at the closing 
  that was not true or was a misrepresentation.Â  Accordingly, the trial court 
  properly concluded there was no genuine issue of material fact as to whether 
  du Mas intentionally interfered with the prospective relations between Island 
  Club and Finlay.
IV.Â Â Â  Civil Conspiracy
Island Clubâ€™s final claim is that the 
  trial court erred in finding there was no evidence of a civil conspiracy between 
  King and du Mas.Â  We disagree.
The trial court found:

[I]n order for a claim for conspiracy to go forward, the plaintiff 
  must plead and prove special damages, not simply reallege conduct and damages 
  arising from other torts.Â  See Vaught v. Waites, 300 S.C. 201, 
  208, 387 S.E.2d 91, 95 (S.C. Ct. App. 1989).Â  In this case, Third Party Plaintiffs 
  have done neither. The facts and damages asserted appear to be identical to 
  the facts and damages alleged in support of their other contract and claims. 


Island Club does not appeal this finding 
  in its brief.Â  Accordingly, Island Club is bound by this unappealed ruling.Â Â  
  See Charleston County Sch. Dist. v. South Carolina State Dairy Commâ€™n, 
  274 S.C. 250, 252, 262 S.E.2d 901, 902 (1980) (a party who does not appeal from 
  an adverse decision is bound by the decision); Dwyer v. Tom Jenkins Realty, 
  Inc., 289 S.C. 118, 120, 344 S.E.2d 886, 888 (Ct. App. 1986) (unchallenged 
  alternative findings can support a judgment).Â  Additionally, there is ample 
  evidence to support the finding of the trial court because the complaint merely 
  realleges the same damages, which were caused by the claims of interference 
  with contractual and prospective relations.Â  Â Thus, we affirm the trial 
  courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of du Mas on this issue.
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court properly granted 
  summary judgment to du Mas on Island Clubâ€™s claim that he intentionally interfered 
  with the contract between King and Island Club because Island Club failed to 
  provide evidence of a breach of an enforceable contract between the parties.Â  
  We also conclude the court properly found Island Club failed to provide evidence 
  to support its claim that du Mas intentionally interfered with the prospective 
  relationship between Island Club and Finlay.Â  Finally, we find the trial court 
  properly granted summary judgment to du Mas on Island Clubâ€™s claim that he entered 
  a civil conspiracy with King to injure Island Club. 
  [3] Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  These claims are not the subject of this appeal.Â  The sole claims 
    on appeal arise from Island Clubâ€™s third-party complaint against du Mas.

 
   
    [2]  Because we find that no breach of contract occurred, we need not 
    address Island Clubâ€™s argument that the trial court erred in finding du Mas 
    was a stranger to the contract.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing 
    of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (explaining 
    that the appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition 
    of prior issues is dispositive).Â  

 
   
    [3]  Because we find the trial court properly granted summary judgment 
    to du Mas on all claims raised by Island Club, we need not address the issue 
    regarding the limitation of damages to $50,000.Â  See Futch, 
    335 S.C. at 613, 518 S.E.2d at 598 (explaining that the appellate court need 
    not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issues is dispositive).Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.Â  
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Brenda Tart Dudley,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-110
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  11, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Louis S. Moore, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Brenda Tart Dudley was convicted 
  of shoplifting and sentenced to ten years imprisonment, suspended upon the service 
  of four years and five years probation.Â  She argues on appeal that the trial 
  judge erred in:Â  (1) repeatedly interrupting counsel during the trial, expressing 
  bias, and thereby denying her a fair trial; and (2) giving her a sentence disproportionate 
  to the offense.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
On August 7, 2001, Ronald Lyles, owner 
  of an Ace Hardware store, observed Dudley and a male removing the plastic packaging 
  from expensive pliers and placing the pliers in the maleâ€™s clothing.Â  The pliers 
  had been removed from their display several aisles over.Â  Dudley and the male 
  separated and left the store.Â  Lyles chased the male in the parking lot until 
  he disappeared down an alley.Â  Lylesâ€™ brother questioned Dudley until police 
  arrived.Â  Dudley denied taking anything from the store.Â  Dudley gave police 
  the name of a man she was with, but the man was never taken into custody.Â  The 
  pliers were never recovered.Â  Dudley was charged with shoplifting.Â  
After electing to proceed in a bench trial, 
  Dudley was convicted.Â  She appeals.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Questioning by the Court
Dudley argues she was denied her right 
  to a fair trial because the trial judge interrupted counsel to ask questions 
  of the witnesses and the judge expressed a bias with regard to shoplifting charges.Â  
  We disagree.
Prior to the bench trial, the trial judge 
  expounded on the problem of shoplifting in society.Â  The judge informed Dudley 
  that if she was convicted, he would put her in jail.Â  Throughout the trial, 
  the judge would interrupt counsel for both Dudley and the State to question 
  witnesses, including Dudley.Â  The judge denied Dudleyâ€™s motion for a directed 
  verdict, stating that there was no question that Dudley knew the male suspect, 
  that she was a confederate of the male suspect, and, citing the store-ownerâ€™s 
  testimony, that she knew what he was placing in his clothing.Â  However, the 
  judge went on to address the requirements for granting a motion for directed 
  verdict and to state that he had not yet weighed the facts and would not determine 
  the matter until he had heard the entire case.Â  
Although Dudley argues the trial judge was biased 
  against those charged with shoplifting and that the judge indicated by his questions 
  that he had deliberated her guilt prior to the close of the case, this issue 
  is not properly before this court.Â  Dudley did not object to the judgeâ€™s pre-trial 
  statements, to his interruptions, or to his comments during the directed verdict 
  motion.Â  She never complained to the trial judge that his actions were denying 
  her of a fair trial, she failed to raise the issue of bias before the judge, 
  and she failed to request that the judge recuse himself.Â  Accordingly, she failed 
  to preserve her complaint for appellate review.Â  State v. Hicks, 330 
  S.C. 207, 216, 499 S.E.2d 209, 214 (1998) (holding that issues not raised to 
  and ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review); Bryan 
  v. Bryan, 296 S.C. 305, 311, 372 S.E.2d 116, 120 (Ct. App. 1988) (holding 
  that where a party failed to raise the issue of bias and failed to request recusal, 
  the issue of judicial bias was waived on appeal).Â  As Dudley never complained 
  about judge bias below, she cannot argue that issue on appeal.Â  
II. Disproportionate Sentence
Dudley argues her sentence was out of proportion 
  with the severity of the crime, and thus her punishment was cruel and unusual.Â  
  We disagree.
Prior to trial, the judge informed Dudley that 
  â€œif youâ€™re convicted, Iâ€™m gone [sic] put you in jail.Â  I want you to know that 
  ahead of time.Â  If you convicted [sic] and I find you guilty, Iâ€™m gone [sic] 
  put you in jail because you have used the system and you lost.â€Â  The trial judge 
  also warned Dudley that he had previously given a man convicted of shoplifting 
  a ten-year sentence. [2] Â  After finding Dudley guilty of the crime, the trial judge 
  considered her sentence.Â  Noting her long criminal history [3]  and after hearing from two of 
  her children, the trial judge asked Dudley to acknowledge her involvement in 
  the crime and he would consider that a mitigating circumstance in sentencing.Â  
  When she again denied involvement, the judge gave her the weekend to consider 
  the matter further.Â  When the matter was reconvened, Dudley apologized to the 
  judge, but she stated she was not â€œdenying or acknowledgingâ€ her involvement 
  in the crime.Â  The trial judge sentenced her to ten years, suspended upon the 
  service of four years and five years probation.Â  
We note that this issue is not properly before 
  us.Â  Dudley did not object to the sentence or complain to the judge that the 
  sentence was disproportionate to the severity of the crime.Â  Accordingly, this 
  issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Hicks, 330 S.C. at 216, 
  499 S.E.2d at 214; State v. Shumate, 276 S.C. 46, 47, 275 S.E.2d 288, 
  288 (1981) (holding that a failure to object to a sentence at the time of sentencing 
  precludes appellate review of the matter).Â  
In any event, a trial judge has broad discretion 
  in giving sentences within the statutory limits.Â  Brooks v. State, 325 
  S.C. 269, 271-72, 481 S.E.2d 712, 713 (1997).Â  â€œA sentence is not excessive 
  if it is within statutory limitations and there are no facts supporting an allegation 
  of prejudice against a defendant.â€Â  Id. at 272, 481 S.E.2d at 713.Â  Dudley 
  was convicted of her third shoplifting offense.Â  The sentence for a third offense 
  shoplifting conviction is up to ten years imprisonment.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-110 
  (2003) (defining shoplifting as a misdemeanor or felony, depending on the value 
  of the property taken); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-57 (2003) (â€œA person convicted 
  of an offense for which the term of imprisonment is contingent upon the value 
  of the property involved must, upon conviction for a third or subsequent offense, 
  be punished as prescribed for a Class E felony.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-20 
  (A)(5) (2003) (noting the punishment for a Class E felony is not to exceed ten 
  years).Â  Thus, the sentence was clearly within the statutory mandates.Â Â  
â€œThe cruel and unusual punishment clause 
  requires the duration of a sentence not be grossly out of proportion with the 
  severity of the crime.â€Â  State v. Jones, 344 S.C. 48, 56, 543 S.E.2d 
  541, 545 (2001).Â  Three factors are considered in determining proportionality:Â  
  â€œ(1) the gravity of the offense compared to the harshness of the penalty; (2) 
  sentences imposed on other criminals in the same jurisdiction; and (3) sentences 
  for the same crime in other jurisdictions.â€Â  Id.Â  
Dudley points to two cases from this jurisdiction 
  to support her argument that her sentence was disproportionate.Â  In State 
  v. Timmons, 349 S.C. 389, 563 S.E.2d 657 (2002), the defendant was sentenced 
  to eight years for his fifteenth shoplifting conviction and to two years for 
  possession of cocaine.Â  The court affirmed the convictions and sentences, deciding 
  only the issue of whether the trial court had subject matter jurisdiction to 
  entertain the defendantâ€™s plea to possession of cocaine.Â  Timmons, 349 
  S.C. at 394, 563 S.E.2d at 660.Â  Dudley also points to State v. Lewis, 
  325 S.C. 324, 478 S.E.2d 696 (Ct. App. 1996), in which a defendant with nearly 
  twenty prior convictions, including four prior shoplifting convictions, was 
  sentenced to three years for shoplifting.Â  This court affirmed his sentence, 
  finding it was within the statutory maximum.Â  Lewis, 325 S.C. at 327, 
  478 S.E.2d at 698.Â  
We find Dudleyâ€™s sentence did not violate the cruel and usual punishment 
  clause.Â  Her suspended sentence was within the statutory maximum.Â  Her sentence 
  is not grossly disproportionate to the crime of third offense shoplifting.Â  
  Finally, her sentence was not grossly disproportionate to the sentences given 
  to others convicted of shoplifting, as seen in Timmons and Lewis.Â Â  

CONCLUSION
 Based on the foregoing, Dudleyâ€™s conviction 
  and sentence are
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR. 

 
   
    [2] Â  Although Dudley does not complain about this specific incident, 
    we note that the trial judge seemed to indicate he would punish Dudley for 
    exercising her right to a trial.Â  After informing Dudley of her right to a 
    trial, the trial judge later said that if Dudley were convicted: â€œ. . . Iâ€™m 
    gone [sic] send you to jail for a lot longer time than I would if you were 
    entering a plea because youâ€™ve taken the time from the court when in your 
    heart-of-hearts you know whether or not youâ€™ve got a good defense or not.â€Â  
    Dudley never objected to this statement at trial, and she does not complain 
    about this issue now.Â  Although it is impermissible for a trial judge to consider 
    the exercise of a constitutional right to a trial in sentencing, this issue 
    is not preserved for our review.Â  Davis v. State, 336 S.C. 329, 333, 
    520 S.E.2d 801, 803 (1999) (holding it was impermissible for a sentencing 
    court to consider the exercise of the right to trial in pronouncing sentence); 
    State v. Hazel, 317 S.C. 368, 370, 453 S.E.2d 879, 880 (1995) (same).Â  
  

 
   
    [3]  Dudley had a prior criminal record that included two prior shoplifting 
    convictions, involuntary manslaughter, food stamp fraud, simple possession 
    of marijuana, receiving stolen goods, grand larceny, and giving a false statement 
    upon attempting to purchase a weapon.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Kimberly Patterson,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Yancey Patterson,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
Georgia V. Anderson, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-112
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William G. Rhoden, of Gaffney, for Appellant.
Yancey Patterson, pro se, of Blacksburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal of the family 
  courtâ€™s decision in favor of Yancey Patterson (Father) on Kimberly Pattersonâ€™s 
  (Mother) motion for reduction in child support.Â  We affirm.1
FACTS
Yancey Patterson, Father, and Kimberly Patterson, 
  Mother, were formerly married.Â  In 2002, Father received custody of the coupleâ€™s 
  three children.Â  Mother received standard visitation rights â€œcontingent upon 
  [Mother] providing [Father] with monthly verification that she has seen and 
  met with her mental health doctor and/or counselor.â€Â  The family court gave 
  Father the right to suspend visitation if Mother did not comply with this order.Â  

Shortly thereafter, Mother was admitted to inpatient 
  treatment at Charter Hospital for alcohol abuse.Â  Upon leaving Charter, Mother 
  was arrested for her third driving while intoxicated (DUI) offense, though she 
  was only convicted of a DUI 2nd.Â  She then admitted herself into Patrick B. 
  Harris Hospital.Â  Following her inpatient treatment, Father suspended Motherâ€™s 
  visitation with the children.Â  Mother also successfully completed an outpatient 
  treatment program at Cherokee County Alcohol Commission.Â  
In August 2003, Mother made a motion for reduction 
  of child support and a contempt motion against Father for not allowing her to 
  see the children.Â  Husband answered and counterclaimed for child support arrearages 
  and to terminate or restrict Motherâ€™s visitation rights.Â  At a temporary hearing, 
  the trial court found Mother had significant alcohol abuse problems.Â  However, 
  it also recognized that â€œit appears these problems have subsided and she is 
  continuing counseling.â€Â  
At the final hearing, following Motherâ€™s presentation 
  of her case, the family court found in favor of the Father without the Father 
  presenting any evidence.Â  The trial court determined that Mother â€œis capable 
  of obtaining employment and is not entitled to a reduction or termination of 
  her child support.â€Â  However, while the original support rate of $127.15 per 
  week was to continue to accrue, Mother only had to pay $50 per week until the 
  final disposition of her social security disability claim.Â  This appeal followed.Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has 
  authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 
  154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to 
  disregard the findings of the trial court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 
  276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the trial 
  court, which saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate 
  their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers 
  v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS


I. Involuntary Dismissal
Mother claims the trial court 
  erred in granting a directed verdict2 
  sua sponte for Father at the conclusion of her case.Â  We disagree.
Mother never objected to the family 
  courtâ€™s action on the record filed with this court.Â  â€œIt is axiomatic that an 
  issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised 
  to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  
  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).Â  
  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved for our review.
II. Child Support
Mother claims the trial court erred in not reducing 
  her child support obligation even though she was no longer employed.Â  We disagree.Â  

The trial court can modify prospective child support 
  awards as circumstances warrant, but usually only upon a showing of changed 
  circumstances, including the ability of a supporting parent to pay.Â  Calvert 
  v. Calvert, 287 S.C. 130, 137, 336 S.E.2d 884, 888 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  Furthermore, 
  â€œto warrant a modification in . . . child support, the change of circumstances 
  must be either substantial or material.â€Â  Id. at 138, 336 S.E.2d at 888.Â  
  The amount of child support awarded is within the sound discretion of the trial 
  court whose decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  
  Millis v. Millis, 282 S.C. 610, 613, 320 S.E.2d 66, 67 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  

Mother testified that a doctor from Charter told her 
  she could not work, though she provided no affidavit to that effect.Â  Susan 
  Lineberger, Motherâ€™s counselor, also testified that Motherâ€™s â€œpsychiatric limitations 
  would make it almost impossible for anything except a sheltered workshop setting, 
  you know, where they just work for an hour or two a day.â€Â  However, Lineberger 
  made a contrary statement to the unemployment office.Â  Mother discounted her 
  own witnessâ€™s contrary statement to the unemployment office that Mother was 
  â€œokay to return to work on 3-11-2003â€ by arguing that â€œLineberger is not a doctor.Â  
  Sheâ€™s a counselor.â€Â  Mother also admitted to signing numerous documents at the 
  unemployment office stating that she was able to work.Â  
Although Mother had no income sources other than her 
  family, they contributed significant amounts towards her child support payments 
  and housing expenses.Â  The trial court determined that they could continue to 
  do so.Â  At the time of trial, Mother was also pursuing a social security disability 
  claim, which the trial court recognized had already been denied twice.Â  
Based on this evidence, the trial court was â€œnot 
  satisfied [Mother was] disabled and [could not] work.â€Â  The trial court was 
  in a better position to evaluate the partiesâ€™ credibility and assign comparative 
  weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 
  610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Therefore, we find the trial court acted within its 
  discretion in deciding to retain the current child support obligation.Â  The 
  order of the trial court contemplated Motherâ€™s situation and provided a reasonable 
  procedure to review and evaluate any changed circumstances in the processing 
  of her disability claim.Â  In its order the court set up a review every ninety 
  days of the status of Motherâ€™s social security claim.Â  We will not disturb this 
  decision.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s 
  decision is hereby 
 Affirmed.  
 GOOLSBY, HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

 
  1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
  2 For a bench trial it would have been an involuntary 
    nonsuit rather than a directed verdict.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Elaine W. McCallum,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Beaufort County School District, Self-Insured Employer, through the South 
        Carolina Boards Insurance Trust,        
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-113
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
J. Olin McDougall, II, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
Kirsten Leslie Barr, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Elaine W. McCallum appeals 
  the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Commissionâ€™s (the Commission) decision denying her workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  
  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
McCallum sought benefits for injuries 
  she sustained in an accident that allegedly occurred during the course and scope 
  of her employment as a gifted and talented teacher at St. Helena Elementary 
  School on August 23, 2000.Â Â Â  
McCallum testified on her own behalf before 
  the Single Commissioner.Â  According to her testimony, on the day of the accident 
  McCallum was calculating student grade point averages, which required her to 
  review student files located in the schoolâ€™s main office.Â  The files were stored 
  in eleven by fourteen inch boxes.Â  McCallum alleged she was lifting a box of 
  files when she turned and her right knee â€œpopped out.â€Â  She remained at work 
  for part of the day, but eventually signed a â€œblank leave sheet,â€ a form an 
  employee would sign to indicate absence, and went home.Â  McCallum did not fill 
  out a workersâ€™ compensation incident report or report her injury to a supervisor 
  that day.Â  She testified that Joyce Chisolm, the school nurse, heard her cry 
  out, â€œI think Iâ€™ve killed myself, Iâ€™ve hurt my knee.â€Â  However, at the hearing, 
  Chisolm testified that although her office was next to the student files, she 
  never heard McCallum cry out in pain and knew nothing of an injury.Â Â Â Â Â  
Following the alleged accident, McCallum continued 
  working.Â  McCallum testified that she made an appointment with Dr. Rodin, an 
  orthopedist, for September 1, 2000.Â  Prior to her September 1 appointment with 
  Dr. Rodin, McCallum sought treatment for a cough from Dr. Jenkins, an associate 
  doctor within the same practice.Â  According to Dr. Jenkinsâ€™s record dated August 
  31, 2000, McCallum did not complain of any problem with her knee. 
McCallum then saw Dr. Rodin, but failed to check 
  the box directly above her signature on the patient registration form to indicate 
  her injury was work related.Â  Language located directly above McCallumâ€™s signature 
  on the patient registration form stated that written workersâ€™ compensation verification 
  was needed before she could be seen if her problems were work related.Â  The 
  second page of the registration form contained a space for McCallum to list 
  â€œall injuriesâ€ she could recall with appropriate dates; however, she listed 
  no injuries and Dr. Rodin filled the space with a â€œÃ˜â€ symbol showing no injuries.Â  
  On the final page of the registration form, McCallum signed a statement acknowledging 
  her responsibility for the payment of treatment costs. Â 
On September 8, 2000, McCallum sustained another 
  injury while shopping.Â  McCallum was leaving a store and leaning on a shopping 
  cart when a store employee jerked the cart away causing her hip to â€œpopâ€ and 
  a pain to shoot down past her right knee.Â  
McCallum submitted Dr. Rodinâ€™s records in support 
  of her workerâ€™s compensation claim.Â  Dr. Rodinâ€™s record dated November 2, 2000, 
  reveals that McCallum was unsure of the date of her injury.Â  Dr. Rodinâ€™s report 
  dated September 1, 2000, suggests McCallum twisted her knee carrying boxes of 
  student files on August 23, 2000.Â  A notation at the bottom of the page shows 
  the note was not dictated until April 24, 2001, because, according to Rodin, 
  â€œthe original dictation couldnâ€™t be found.â€Â  Dr. Rodin testified, via deposition, 
  that he relied on his recollections, handwritten notes, and McCallumâ€™s registration 
  form in dictating the note.Â  McCallum, however, did not mention any history 
  of an accident on her registration form, and Dr. Rodinâ€™s handwritten notes indicate 
  McCallum had no history of an accident. Â Â Moreover, on March 21, 2001, 
  Dr. Rodin dictated an operative note reporting McCallum injured her knee as 
  the result of a fall.Â  The Commission affirmed the Single Commissionerâ€™s finding 
  that Dr. Rodinâ€™s dictation was neither reliable nor credible and his opinions 
  should be accorded little weight.Â Â  
Dr. Laverne Davis, principal of St. Helena Elementary 
  School, testified on behalf of Beaufort County School District at the hearing.Â  
  Dr. Davis testified she first learned of McCallumâ€™s injury in November 2000.Â  
  Prior to that time, Dr. Davis thought McCallum was out of work due to the injuries 
  she sustained while shopping.Â  Although McCallum informed Davis she needed to 
  attend physical therapy sessions, McCallum did not tell Davis she was injured 
  at work during the months of August, September, or October.Â  
After she learned of McCallumâ€™s allegations, Dr. 
  Davis investigated by speaking to everyone who worked in the school office and 
  witnesses listed on the incident report McCallum filled out in November 2000, 
  including Terry Miller.Â  Dr. Davis testified that no one, including Miller, 
  had any knowledge of McCallum injuring her right knee at work.Â  The Single Commissioner 
  admitted the deposition testimony of Miller into evidence at the hearing.Â  In 
  her deposition, Miller testified that she first learned McCallum was injured 
  when she called and reported her shopping injury.Â  According to Miller, it was 
  not until much later that she learned McCallum alleged she was injured at work.Â Â Â Â  

Following the hearing, the Single Commissioner 
  issued an order finding McCallum was not entitled to workersâ€™ compensation benefits 
  because she was not injured within the course and scope of her employment.Â  
  McCallum appealed to the Commission, arguing the Single Commissioner erred in:Â  
  1). finding McCallum was not injured in the course and scope of her employment; 
  2). admitting the deposition testimony of Miller; 3). admitting the hearsay 
  testimony of Dr. Davis; 4). according little weight to Dr. Rodinâ€™s testimony 
  and records; and 5). finding McCallum lacked credibility and was too highly 
  educated to misunderstand the patient registration forms.Â  The Commission unanimously 
  affirmed the order of the Single Commissioner in its entirety.Â  
McCallum appealed to the circuit court.Â  The circuit 
  court affirmed the decision of the Commission and denied McCallumâ€™s motion for 
  reconsideration.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the 
  standard of review for decisions by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission. Lark 
  v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 132, 276 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1981).Â  â€œThe 
  appellate courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the commissionâ€™s decision 
  is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.â€ 
  Hendricks v. Pickens County, 335 S.C. 405, 411, 517 S.E.2d 698, 
  701 (Ct. App. 1999); see Roper Hosp. v. Clemons, 
  326 S.C. 534, 536, 484 S.E.2d 598, 599 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œOn appeal from the 
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, this court may reverse where the decision 
  is affected by an error of law.â€).Â  â€œIt is not within our province to reverse 
  findings of the Commission which are supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Broughton 
  v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 496, 520 S.E.2d 634, 637 (Ct. 
  App. 1999).Â  
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Scope of Employment
McCallum argues the Commission erred in finding that she 
  did not prove she sustained an injury in the course and scope of her employment 
  on August 23, 2000.Â  We disagree.
In order to receive workersâ€™ compensation benefits, 
  McCallum must prove that she sustained an â€œinjury by accident arising out of 
  and in the course of the employment.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2004).Â  
  The Commission found McCallum was not entitled to benefits and affirmed the 
  Single Commissionerâ€™s ruling that McCallum did not sustain an injury by accident 
  arising out of her employment on August 23, 2000.Â  We must affirm the Commissionâ€™s 
  ruling unless it is clearly erroneous in view of the substantial evidence on 
  the whole record.Â  Nettles v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. #7, 341 S.C. 
  580, 586, 535 S.E.2d 146, 149 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is â€˜not 
  a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of 
  the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow 
  reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached 
  or must have reached in order to justify its action.â€™â€Â  Miller by Miller 
  v. State Roofing Co., 312 S.C. 452, 454, 441 S.E.2d 323, 324-25 
  (1994) (quoting Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 
  304, 306 (1981)).Â  â€œThe substantial evidence rule does not allow judicial fact-finding, 
  or the substitution of judicial judgment for agency judgment.Â  A judgment upon 
  which reasonable men might differ will not be set aside.â€Â  Toddâ€™s Ice Cream, 
  Inc. v. South Carolina Employment Sec. Commâ€™n, 281 S.C. 254, 258, 315 S.E.2d 
  373, 375 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  However, â€œ[w]here there is a conflict in the evidence, 
  either of different witnesses or of the same witnesses, the findings of fact 
  of the Commission as triers of the fact are conclusive.â€Â  Holcombe v. Dan 
  River Mills/Woodside Div., 286 S.C. 223, 225, 333 S.E.2d 338, 340 (Ct. App. 
  1985).
Our review of the record indicates there was substantial 
  evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s finding McCallum was not injured in the 
  course of her employment.Â  The Commission noted that McCallumâ€™s claim for benefits 
  relied largely on her own testimony and that the Single Commissioner properly 
  discounted her testimony because it lacked credibility.Â  The testimony of school 
  employees Dr. Davis, Chisolm, and Miller contradicted McCallumâ€™s testimony.Â  
  Specifically, Chisolm testified she did not witness McCallum injure herself, 
  and Davis testified McCallum did not report the alleged injury until November 
  2000.
Additionally, although McCallum relied on medical 
  records to support her claim, the Commission found some of Dr. Rodinâ€™s medical 
  records contradicted McCallumâ€™s testimony.Â  Dr. Rodinâ€™s record dated September 
  1, 2000, supported McCallumâ€™s account of the injury, but Dr. Rodin did not dictate 
  the note until the following April.Â  Dr. Rodin stated he relied on his recollections, 
  handwritten notes, and McCallumâ€™s registration form in dictating the note.Â  
  McCallum, however, did not mention any history of accident on her registration 
  form, and Dr. Rodinâ€™s handwritten notes indicate McCallum had no history of 
  accident. Â Moreover, on March 21, 2001, Dr. Rodin dictated an operative 
  note reporting McCallum injured her knee as the result of a fall.Â  Therefore, 
  we find substantial evidence existed to support the Commissionâ€™s decision to 
  deny benefits to McCallum.
II.Â  Deposition testimony
McCallum argues the Commission 
  erred in admitting the deposition testimony of Miller into evidence.Â  We disagree.
As discussed above, McCallum 
  testified that she requested an incident report from school office manager, 
  Miller.Â  In response, the School District moved to have Millerâ€™s deposition 
  admitted to show Miller testified McCallum did not ask for an incident form.Â  
  The Single Commissioner admitted the deposition over McCallumâ€™s attorneyâ€™s objection 
  that he had no notice the testimony would be admitted by the School District.Â  
  McCallum also argues admission of the deposition violated Rule 32, SCRCP, which 
  governs the use of depositions in court proceedings.Â Â Â  
We find neither of McCallumâ€™s 
  arguments convincing.Â  Great liberality is exercised in permitting the introduction 
  of evidence in proceedings under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Hamilton 
  v. Bob Bennett Ford, 339 S.C. 68, 70, 528 S.E.2d 667, 668 (2000).Â  Furthermore, 
  the record reveals that McCallumâ€™s attorney noticed the deposition and conducted 
  all of the questioning.Â  Although McCallumâ€™s attorney did not submit the deposition 
  as an exhibit, he was aware of the substance of the testimony.Â  Additionally, 
  in its notice of witnesses and medical reports submitted to McCallumâ€™s attorney, 
  the attorney for the school district indicated that Miller was a potential witness.Â  
  Moreover, even if admitting the testimony was error, it was harmless because 
  the deposition was cumulative to other evidence in the record.Â  Specifically, 
  Dr. Davis testified that at no point in August, September, or October 2000 did 
  McCallum inform her of an injury to her right knee.Â  Dr. Davis also stated that 
  his investigation into McCallumâ€™s claim revealed that no one at the school had 
  any knowledge of the alleged injury.Â  Chisolm, the school nurse, also testified 
  that she was not aware of McCallumâ€™s injury until November despite being in 
  close proximity to the file room where the alleged injury occurred.Â  See 
  Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 299, 519 S.E.2d 583, 600 (Ct. 
  App. 1999) (finding admission of improper evidence is harmless where it is merely 
  cumulative to other evidence); see also Eadie v. H.A. Sack Co., 
  322 S.C. 164, 172, 470 S.E.2d 397, 401 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding an error not 
  shown to be prejudicial does not constitute grounds for reversal).Â Â  
III.Â  Testimony
McCallum argues the Commission erred in allowing 
  Dr. Davis to testify regarding the hearsay comments of Miller in contravention 
  of Rule 802 of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence.Â  Rule 802, SCRE (â€œHearsay 
  is not admissible except as provided by these rules or by other rules prescribed 
  by the Supreme Court of this State or by statute.â€).Â  We disagree. 
Dr. Davis testified that, 
  in her capacity as principal, she undertook to investigate McCallumâ€™s claim 
  after learning of the allegation.Â  In the course of her investigation, Davis 
  spoke to Miller, the schoolâ€™s office manager.Â  At the hearing, Davis related 
  that Miller said she had no knowledge of McCallumâ€™s alleged work-related injury.Â  
  The Single Commissioner admitted the testimony over counselâ€™s hearsay objection.
â€œ[T]he South Carolina Rules of Evidence do not 
  apply in proceedings before the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.â€Â  Hamilton, 
  339 S.C. at 70, 528 S.E.2d at 668; see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-330(1) (2005) 
  (providing that except in proceedings before the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, 
  rules of evidence apply in contested matters before an agency).Â  Therefore, 
  great liberality is exercised in permitting the introduction of evidence in 
  proceedings under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, and even hearsay evidence may 
  be admissible, provided it is corroborated by facts, circumstances or other 
  evidence.Â  Hamilton, 339 S.C. at 70, 528 S.E.2d at 668.Â  We find the 
  Commission committed no error in admitting Davisâ€™s hearsay comments into evidence 
  because it was corroborated by other evidence and circumstances.Â  Dr. Otis Smith, 
  the executive director of human resources for the school district, testified 
  that prior to his receipt of McCallumâ€™s family leave request form, the district 
  office had no knowledge of McCallumâ€™s injury.Â  He further testified he assumed 
  there was no injury because no one that he spoke with had any knowledge of an 
  accident form being filed.Â  Moreover, as previously noted, neither Davis nor 
  Chisolm were aware of McCallumâ€™s claim until November 2000.Â Â  
IV.Â  Medical Testimony
McCallum argues the Commission erred in finding 
  the records and reports of Dr. Rodin should be accorded little weight because 
  there was not substantial evidence in the record to support that determination.Â  
  We disagree.
â€œThe final determination of witness credibility 
  and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Full Commission.â€Â  
  Ross v. American Red Cross, 298 S.C. 490, 492, 381 S.E.2d 728, 730 (1989).Â  
  The reviewing court may not â€œsubstitute its judgment for that of the [Commission] 
  as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) 
  (2005).Â  
The Commission properly found Dr. Rodinâ€™s testimony 
  should be accorded little weight.Â  McCallum contends the Commission improperly 
  substituted its opinion for that of her expert, Dr. Rodin.Â  However, the Commission 
  only discounted Dr. Rodinâ€™s testimony regarding the date, time and place of 
  McCallumâ€™s injury and questioned the credibility of the medical records he maintained.Â  
  As discussed above, internal inconsistencies existed between Dr. Rodinâ€™s records 
  and recollections.Â  Other witnessesâ€™ testimony, found credible by the Commission, 
  contradicted McCallum and Rodinâ€™s account of the injury.Â  Therefore, the Commission 
  committed no error in finding Dr. Rodinâ€™s medical records were of questionable 
  veracity and were outweighed by more credible evidence.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
V.Â  Credibility of Witness
McCallum argues the Commission erred in finding 
  she lacked credibility and was too highly educated to misunderstand a patient 
  registration form.Â  We disagree.
Prior to her first visit with Dr. Rodin, McCallum 
  completed a patient registration form.Â  On the form, she failed to indicate 
  her accident was work related and listed no injuries.Â  The registration form 
  also informed McCallum workersâ€™ compensation verification was needed before 
  she could be seen if her problems were work related.Â  The Single Commissioner 
  found:

The Claimant has a Masters (plus) in education.Â  I often find 
  the injured workers unable to articulate their problems, which can lead to confusion.Â  
  Here, I find that the Claimant is highly educated and I do not find it believable 
  that she signed certain documents, including insurance forms signed at Lowcountry 
  Medical Group, without understanding them. Â Â Â Â  

McCallum argued the finding was 
  erroneous before the Commission because the Single Commissioner could not make 
  a finding regarding McCallumâ€™s education level and credibility without expert 
  testimony.Â  The Commission found the argument without merit, and we agree.Â  
  The Commission is accorded the final determination in all matters regarding 
  witness credibility.Â  Ross, 298 S.C. at 492, 381 S.E.2d at 730.Â  We will 
  not substitute our judgment for that of the Commission concerning the weight 
  of evidence on questions of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  
  Because it is the province of the Commission to evaluate witness credibility 
  in choosing to believe or disbelieve testimony, we find no error.Â  
CONCLUSION
The record reveals substantial evidence 
  existed to support the Commissionâ€™s finding McCallum was not injured in the 
  course and scope of her employment.Â  We find no error in the Commissionâ€™s decision 
  to admit the deposition testimony of Miller into evidence and to allow Davis 
  to testify regarding Millerâ€™s statements.Â  Likewise, substantial evidence supports 
  the Commissionâ€™s finding that Dr. Rodinâ€™s reports and testimony were not credible 
  and should be accorded little weight.Â  Finally, we find no error in the Commissionâ€™s 
  determination McCallumâ€™s testimony was not credible.Â  Therefore, the order of 
  the circuit court affirming the Commission is
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  

   
     
      The International Order of Foresters, Plaintiffs,
      v.
      Louise Johnson, Carrie B. Johnson, and Cecil Yonce, Jr., Defendants,Of 
        whom Carrie B. Johnson is,
    
     
      Appellant,
    
  

  

and

  

   
     
      Cecil Yonce, Jr., is,
    
     
      Respondent.
    
  

  


Appeal From Edgefield County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-114
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Theo W. Mitchell, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Christian G. Spradley, of Saluda, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant Carrie Johnson argues 
  that the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to respondent because 
  she never received notice of the hearing on the motion for summary judgment.Â  
  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
The International Order of Foresters filed 
  an interpleader action against Louise Johnson, Appellant, and Respondent Cecil 
  Yonce, Jr., to determine who should be awarded the proceeds of the life insurance 
  policy of decedent Silvester Johnson, Appellantâ€™s estranged spouse.Â  Appellant 
  was not named as a beneficiary to the policy, and the decedent executed an assignment 
  of the proceeds to Yonce.Â  Appellant alleged that Yonce committed fraud and 
  used undue influence over the decedent.Â  In discovery, Appellant refused to 
  admit that her husband signed the application for life insurance until she had 
  consulted a handwriting expert.Â  She alleged in her answer to the request to 
  admit that Yonce may have taken out policies of life insurance on other illiterate 
  workers.Â  
Yonce filed a motion for summary judgment, and 
  a hearing was scheduled for April 19, 2004.Â  Neither Appellant nor her attorney 
  appeared at the hearing, but the circuit court made the specific finding that 
  all the parties were properly served with notice according to the clerkâ€™s office. 
  [2] Â  Yonce presented the affidavit of the insurance agent to the effect 
  that there was no undue influence and the decedent understood what he was signing.Â  
  The circuit court found Appellant had no interest in the matter because she 
  was not named a beneficiary and because the decedent took the life insurance 
  policy out on himself and then executed an assignment of the policy to Yonce.Â  
  The circuit court granted Yonceâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â Â  Nothing in 
  the record indicates that Appellant filed a motion for reconsideration or a 
  motion for relief from judgment.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellant argues summary judgment was 
  improper because neither she nor her attorney were ever given notice of the 
  hearing as required by Rule 6(d), SCRCP. 
  [3] Â  We disagree.
Summary judgment is appropriate where 
  there is no genuine issue of material fact and it is clear the moving party 
  is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  If further 
  inquiry into the facts is necessary to clarify application of the law, summary 
  judgment is not appropriate.Â  Tupper v. Dorchester Co., 326 S.C. 318, 
  325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).Â  â€œSummary judgment should not be granted even 
  when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts if there is dispute as to the 
  conclusion to be drawn from those facts.â€Â  Id.Â  The evidence and the 
  inferences therefrom must be viewed in a light most favorable to the non-moving 
  party.Â  Id.
As Appellant correctly points out, notice 
  of a hearing should be sent to all parties no later than ten days before the 
  hearing.Â  Rule 6(d), SCRCP.Â  Yonce alleges in his brief that Appellant was served 
  notice of the hearing on March 9, 2004, for the April 19, 2004, hearing.Â  There 
  is no evidence in the record regarding when Appellant was served.Â  The circuit 
  court, however, specifically found that notice of the hearing was properly given.Â  
  Despite the circuit courtâ€™s ruling on the notice issue, Appellant failed to 
  complain before the circuit court in a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion that she was 
  not served notice of the hearing.Â  Because she failed to raise this argument 
  before the circuit court, it is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Mize 
  v. Blue Ridge Ry. Co., 219 S.C. 119, 129-30, 64 S.E.2d 253, 258 (1951) (holding 
  that an issue not specifically raised by the appellant before the trial court 
  was not preserved for appellate review, regardless of the fact that the trial 
  judge addressed it).Â  
Further, even on the merits, we find the 
  grant of summary judgment was proper.Â  Viewing the evidence in the light most 
  favorable to Appellant, the life insurance policy on the decedent was executed 
  by the decedent to insure his own life, decedent executed a valid assignment 
  of the insurance proceeds to Yonce, and decedent never named Appellant a beneficiary 
  of the policy.Â  There is no evidence in the record of any fraud on Yonceâ€™s part, 
  nor is there evidence that the decendentâ€™s handwriting was forged on the life 
  insurance policy or the assignment.Â  Accordingly, there is no evidence which 
  supports Appellantâ€™s claim to the proceeds.Â  Based on this evidence, we find 
  the circuit court correctly granted summary judgment in favor of Yonce.Â  
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary 
  judgment is
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.Â  

 
   
    [2]  At the time of the summary judgment hearing, the Independent Order 
    of Foresters had deposited the proceeds of the life insurance policy with 
    the clerk of court and was no longer a party.Â  Also, Louise Johnson had failed 
    to answer the complaint and was in default.Â  The only remaining parties to 
    the action were Yonce and Appellant.Â Â  

 
   
    [3] Â  Appellant raises two issues on appeal, both of which deal with whether 
    it was appropriate for the circuit court to grant summary judgment where there 
    was no notice given.Â  Accordingly, we treat the issues as one.Â
