THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED 
  ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Michael Toner,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Employment Security Commission,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-115
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 15, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Everett Hope Garner, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Harold W. Funderburk, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Michael Toner appeals the decision 
  of the circuit court, affirming the Employment Security Commissionâ€™s finding 
  that workersâ€™ compensation benefits are excluded from the definition of wages 
  for purposes of calculating unemployment benefits.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
As a result of an onâ€“the-job injury, Michael 
  Toner received temporary total workersâ€™ compensation payments from November 
  9, 2000 to May 15, 2002.Â  During this same time period, Toner was laid-off from 
  work because of a lack of work. He sought unemployment benefits for the period 
  in question.Â Â  To determine the amount of his unemployment benefits, the South 
  Carolina Employment Security Commission considered the holidays and vacation 
  days for which Toner was paid and which the employer reported to the Commission 
  as wages. However, the Commission determined the workersâ€™ compensation payments 
  should not be included in determining the amount of Tonerâ€™s unemployment benefits, 
  because they are not included in the definition of wages.Â  Section 41-27-380 
  of the South Carolina Code (1986) defines wages for tax and benefit computations 
  under the South Carolina Employment Security Law as follows:

(1) â€œWagesâ€ means all remuneration 
  paid for personal services, including commissions and bonuses, any sums paid 
  to an employee by an employer . . ..â€Wagesâ€ does not include:
(a) The amount of any payment with respect to services 
  performed in behalf of an individual in its employ under a plan or system established 
  by an employing unit which makes provision for individuals in its employ generally 
  or for a class or classes of individuals (including any amount paid by an employing 
  unit for insurance or annuities or into a fund to provide for any such payment), 
  on account of (i) retirement, (ii) sickness or accident disability, (iii) medical 
  and hospitalization expenses in connection with sickness or accident disability, 
  or (iv) death . . . .

Toner appealed to the circuit court, which agreed with 
  the Commission, finding workersâ€™ compensation payments are not wages for purposes 
  of calculating Tonerâ€™s unemployment benefits.Â  Toner now appeals the circuit 
  courtâ€™s order.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an action at law, tried without a jury, 
  our standard of review extends only to the correction of errors of law.Â  Okatie 
  River, L.L.C. v. Southeastern Site Prep, L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 334, 577 
  S.E.2d 468, 472 (Ct. App. 2003) (citations omitted).Â  The circuit courtâ€™s findings 
  will not be disturbed on appeal unless they are wholly unsupported by the evidence 
  or controlled by an erroneous conception of the application of the law.Â  Gordon 
  v. Colonial Ins. Co. of California, 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 
  (Ct. App. 2000) (citation omitted).
Likewise, when reviewing the decision 
  of an administrative agency, our scope of review is limited, and we will neither 
  overturn the agencyâ€™s findings of fact if they are supported by substantial 
  evidence, nor will we disturb the agencyâ€™s rulings on questions of law if they 
  are sound as a matter of law.Â  Alton Newton Evangelistic Assâ€™n, Inc. v. South 
  Carolina Employment Sec. Commâ€™n, 284 S.C. 302, 304, 326 S.E.2d 165, 166 
  (Ct. App. 1985) (citations omitted).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Toner argues that because workerâ€™s compensation 
  is not specifically excluded from the definition of wages and because the Employment 
  Security Law is â€œremedial social legislation,â€ workerâ€™s compensation should 
  be included when calculating unemployment benefits.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction 
  is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€Â  Charleston 
  County Sch. Dist. v. State Budget and Control Bd., 313 S.C. 1, 5, 437 S.E.2d 
  6, 8 (1993) (citing Bankers Trust of South Carolina v. Bruce, 275 S.C. 
  35, 37, 267 S.E.2d 424, 425 (1980)).Â  The best evidence of the legislative intent 
  is in the text of the statute.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 
  S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000) (citation omitted).Â  We cannot construe a statue without 
  regard to its plain and ordinary meaning, and we cannot â€œresort to subtle or 
  forced construction in an attempt to limit or expand a statuteâ€™s scope.â€Â  Pascal 
  v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 437, 454 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1995) 
  (citation omitted).Â  Further, if statutes deal with the same subject matter, 
  we must reconcile them, â€œif possible, so as to render both operative.â€Â  Hodges, 
  341 S.C. at 88, 533 S.E.2d at 583 (citing Butler v. Unisun Ins., 323 
  S.C. 402, 408, 475 S.E.2d 758, 761 (1996)).
Section 41-27-380 of the South Carolina 
  Code (1986) provides the definition of wages for computing benefits under our 
  South Carolina Employment Security Law.Â  Workersâ€™ compensation is neither expressly 
  included in nor expressly excluded from the definition of wages.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Â§ 41-27-380 (1986).
However, we are convinced that workersâ€™ 
  compensation benefits are payments to employees under employersâ€™ plans for a 
  class of individuals because of sickness or accident disability or expenses 
  in connection therewith and are implicitly excluded from the statuteâ€™s definition 
  of wages.Â  Tonerâ€™s argument that workersâ€™ compensation is not excluded from 
  the definition of wages turns on the notion that the workersâ€™ compensation system 
  is a creature of statuteâ€”not one of an employing unit.Â  Under the laws governing 
  workersâ€™ compensation, employers may opt out of the program if they prove they 
  have the ability to pay similar benefits or show they are self-insured.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-5-10 (1976); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-5-20 (Supp. 2004).Â  In 
  other words, employers may participate in the workersâ€™ compensation plan or 
  provide some other means of covering workers.Â  Such a system of payments is 
  the very type intended to be excluded by the Legislature from the calculation 
  of unemployment benefits. This holding is consistent with the way other courts 
  have decided this issue. See Molnar v. Admâ€™r, Unemployment Comp. Act 
  Â 685 A.2d 1157, 1162 (Conn. Super. Ct. 1995), affâ€™d, 685 A.2d 1107 
  (Conn. 1996) (finding reasonable the board of reviewâ€™s decision that workerâ€™s 
  compensation payments did not constitute qualifying â€œwagesâ€ for purposes of 
  calculating unemployment compensation benefits under Connecticut law); Lavin 
  v. Alton Box Bd. Co., 431 So.2d 202, 203 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1983) (noting 
  that temporary total disability benefits are not wages to be used in computing 
  workerâ€™s average weekly wage); Swackhammer v. Unemployment Comp. Bd. of Review, 
  484 A.2d 851, 853 (Pa. Commw. Ct. 1984) (finding that wages as used in Pennsylvania 
  unemployment compensation law did not include workerâ€™s compensation benefits 
  since they are awarded on account of job related disabilities and not in consideration 
  of personal services).
Toner also argues that inasmuch as vacation 
  and holiday pay were included in his wages and reported by the employer to the 
  commission, the definition of wages should be expanded in this case to include 
  workerâ€™s compensationÂ  payments. We disagree. Vacation and holiday pay were 
  part of his compensation set by the terms of Tonerâ€™s hiring agreement and are 
  necessarily included in the wages on which the employer is taxed for Employment 
  Security purposes. See State by Bassett v. Hatcher, 131 S.E.2d 
  172, 175 (W. Va. 1963); accord Carter v. Bd. of Review Under Oklahoma 
  Employment Sec. Act, 323 P.2d 362 (Okla. 1958). 
Finally, Toner argues that because our 
  Employment Security Law is remedial social legislation, it should be liberally 
  construed to include workerâ€™s compensation as wages. In Alton Newton, 
  we held â€œ[a]s social legislation, the Employment Security Law should be construed 
  to provide protection to as many employees as possible.â€Â  284 S.C. at 305, 326 
  S.E.2d at 167 (citations omitted). Nevertheless, Toner has the burden to show 
  he meets the eligibility requirements of the statute. Hyman v. South Carolina 
  Employment Sec. Commâ€™n, 234 S.C. 369, 373, 108 S.E.2d 554, 556 (1959).Â Â  
  Considering our scope of review, the purpose of the Employment Security Law, 
  and the language of the statute, we conclude the circuit court was correct in 
  holding workersâ€™ compensation benefits are excluded from the definition of wages.
CONCLUSION
Because we conclude workersâ€™ compensation benefits 
  are not wages for the purpose of calculating unemployment benefits, we are constrained 
  to affirm the order of the circuit court. If there is an element of unfairness 
  in this decision, any remediation of such a result rests in the hands of the 
  Legislature.
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, J., SHORT, J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Arnold Hawkins, Freedonia Hawkins and Lakeya Hawkins,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-116
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  16, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
George J. Kefalos, of Charleston, for Appellants.
Robert J. Thomas and William E. Hopkins, Jr., both of Columbia, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  In this insurance coverage 
  dispute, Appellants (the Hawkinses) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s denial of their 
  motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV) or alternatively for 
  a new trial.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Respondent South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance 
  Company (Farm Bureau) issued a homeownerâ€™s insurance policy concerning property 
  located at 3826 Highway 17A North, Jamestown, South Carolina.Â  The policy was 
  issued based on the application signed by Arnold Hawkins.Â  In the application, 
  Arnold Hawkins represented he owned the property to be covered by the policy.
In January 2000, the property sustained substantial 
  fire damage.Â  After investigation by both the South Carolina Law Enforcement 
  Division and Farm Bureau, it was determined the fire was intentionally set.Â  
  The investigation also revealed Arnold Hawkins did not own the property when 
  he signed the insurance application.Â  At the time Arnold Hawkins made the representation 
  of ownership on the application, title to the property was in the name of Arnoldâ€™s 
  daughter, Lakeya Hawkins.
Farm Bureau initiated a declaratory judgment action 
  seeking a judgment that coverage was not available because the fire was intentionally 
  set by, or at the direction of, Arnold Hawkins or, alternatively, Farm Bureau 
  was relieved of its obligations under the policy due to the material misrepresentations 
  of Arnold Hawkins as to the ownership of the property.Â  Pursuant to special 
  interrogatories, the jury found for Farm Bureau only on the material misrepresentation 
  claim.Â  The Hawkinses filed a motion for JNOV or a new trial pursuant to Rule 
  50, SCRCP.Â  The circuit court denied the motion, and this appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Hawkinses allege the circuit court erred in denying 
  the motion for JNOV or, in the alternative, a new trial.Â  We disagree.
At the close of the evidence, the Hawkinses moved 
  for a directed verdict on one ground as to the misrepresentation claim. [1] Â  The sole argument was based on the failure 
  of Farm Bureau prior to trial to tender the premiums to the named insured, Arnold 
  Hawkins.Â  We initially observe that this defenseâ€”failure to tender premiumsâ€”constitutes 
  an affirmative defense or matter of â€œavoidanceâ€ under Rule 8(c), SCRCP.Â  See 
  Oyler v. Oyler, 293 S.C. 4, 7, 358 S.E.2d 170, 172 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œ[A]n 
  avoidance is a defense which goes beyond the basic elements of the opposing 
  partyâ€™s cause and depends upon additional facts to defeat the claimâ€); see 
  generally Floyd v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. Co., 285 S.C. 
  148, 150, 328 S.E.2d 132, 132 (Ct. App. 1985); Brown v. Dr. Michael D. HoffmanÂ  
  & Assoc., 111 S.W.3d 826, 827 (Texas 2003); McCord v. Horace Mann 
  Ins. Co., 390 F.3d 138, 141 (Mass. 2004) (referring to failure of condition 
  precedent as an affirmative defense).
The Hawkinses pled no such defense, and the general 
  rule precludes consideration of claims or defenses not presented in the pleadings.Â  
  See Fraternal Order of Police v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 
  352 S.C. 420, 435, 574 S.E.2d 717, 725 (2002) (â€œGenerally, claims or defenses 
  not presented in the pleadings will not be considered on appealâ€); Howard 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways, 343 S.C. 149, 155, 538 S.E.2d 291, 
  294 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œAffirmative defenses are waived if not pledâ€); Oyler 
  v. Oyler, 293 S.C. at 6, 358 S.E.2d at 171-72 (stating that under Rule 8(c), 
  SCRCP, a party must set forth in its pleadings any matter â€œconstituting an avoidance 
  or affirmative defenseâ€); R. Brown & Sons, Inc. v. Credit Alliance Corp., 
  473 A.2d 1168, 1170 (Vt. 1984) (â€œ[A] matter raised constituting an avoidance 
  is an affirmative defense and must be affirmatively pledâ€). While a matter not 
  included in the pleadings may be tried by the express or implied consent of 
  the parties under Rule 15(b), SCRCP, the scant record before us does not allow 
  us to affirmatively find such consent.Â  The burden is on the appellant to present 
  a sufficient record for review.Â  State v. Mitchell, 330 S.C. 189, 194, 
  498 S.E.2d 642, 645 (1998); State v. Smith, 359 S.C. 481, 490, 597 S.E.2d 
  888, 893 (Ct. App. 2004). [2] Â  

We do not believe the Hawkinsesâ€™ argument would 
  prevail in any vent.Â  We begin this analysis with the acknowledgement that generally 
  â€œan insurance company suing to cancel a policy for fraud[] must restore or tender 
  the premiums received as a condition of relief.â€Â  Arnold v. Life Ins. Co. 
  of Georgia, 226 S.C. 60, 73, 83 S.E.2d 553, 559 (1954).Â Â  The supreme court 
  revisited this issue in the case of McElmurray v. American Fidelity Fire 
  Insur. Co., 236 S.C. 195, 113 S.E.2d 528 (1960).Â  InÂ  McElmurray, 
  the court focused on the policy language and determined that â€œ[t]he policy contract 
  expressly negates necessity for return to the insured of the unearned premium 
  in order to effect cancellation of the policy by the insurer.â€Â  Id. at 
  205, 113 S.E.2d at 533.Â Â  We are persuaded the policy language here compels 
  the same conclusion.Â  Under the terms of the policy, the parties agreed that 
  â€œ[i]f the premium is not refunded with the cancellation or when the policy is 
  returned to us, we will refund it within a reasonable time after the 
  date cancellation takes effect.â€Â  (emphasis in original)Â  Farm Bureau, therefore, 
  was not required to refund the premiums to Arnold Hawkins as a condition precedent 
  to maintaining the underlying declaratory judgment action.Â  Moreover, Farm Bureauâ€™s 
  efforts to cancel the policy did not â€œtake effectâ€ until it prevailed on its 
  misrepresentation claim.Â  In this regard, during the hearing on post-trial motions, 
  Farm Bureau advised that â€œa check [will be] available for the Hawkinsâ€™ [sic] 
  as soon as the judgment is entered.â€Â  The Hawkinses, through counsel, promptly 
  refused the tender.Â  And finally, it is beyond dispute that an earlier tender 
  of the premiums to Arnold Hawkins would have likewise been a futile act, and 
  any contention to the contrary finds no traction in the abbreviated record before 
  us. 
Having addressed the sole ground asserted by the 
  Hawkinses in their directed verdict motion, we decline to addressâ€”as unpreservedâ€”the 
  remaining issues argued in their brief.Â  A directed verdict motion stating the 
  specific grounds is a prerequisite for a subsequent motion for judgment notwithstanding 
  the verdict.Â  See In re McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 93, 551 S.E.2d 
  235, 238 (2001) (stating only grounds raised in directed verdict motion may 
  properly be reasserted in JNOV motion).Â  
CONCLUSION
For these reasons, we find that the trial court 
  acted within its discretion in denying the motion for a new trial and properly 
  denied the JNOV motion. 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  It does appear the Hawkinses may have made an initial motion 
    for a directed verdict at the close of Farm Bureauâ€™s case in chief, but that 
    portion of the trial transcript was not included in the record on appeal.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Farm Bureau advanced this argument in its final brief.Â  The 
    Hawkinses submitted a final reply brief, but chose not to respond to their 
    failure to include this defense in their Answer and Counterclaim.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
General Heating and Air Conditioning Co. of Greenville, Inc.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
SMD Construction, LLC, and Robert L.
Scroggs, Jr.,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-117
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  16, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William S. Brown, Peter G. Siachos, both of Greenville, for 
  Appellants.
David Weldon Gantt, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from 
  a breach of contract action in which the circuit court, sitting nonjury, awarded 
  damages and entered judgment in favor of General Heating and Air Conditioning 
  Co. of Greenville, Inc.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
General and SMD Construction entered a contract 
  for work to be performed at a manufacturing facility in Georgia.Â  The first 
  contract was signed on February 22, 2000 and completed in May 2000.Â  General 
  was paid the full amount on this contract.Â  The parties entered a second contract 
  in June 2000.Â  The contract price was $227,541.Â  When General completed the 
  work in November 2000, it was due $49,028 under the contract.Â  
General brought suit against SMD and Robert L. 
  Scroggs, Jr., president of SMD, alleging SMD owed $49,028 on the contract, and 
  Scroggs personally guaranteed payment of the amount owed.Â  SMD filed a counterclaim 
  alleging breach of contract by General and denying Scroggs made a personal guaranty.Â  

John Algary, Vice President of General, testified 
  as to the amount owed by SMD for the work completed.Â  He also stated he met 
  with Scroggs regarding the amount owed, and Scroggs agreed to personally guarantee 
  the payment in exchange for Generalâ€™s forbearance of filing a mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  
  Algary further testified that SMD never lodged a complaint in connection with 
  the work performed by General under the second contract.Â  
Mark Clark, Generalâ€™s treasurer, testified 
  he met with Scroggs regarding the outstanding payment.Â  Scroggs agreed to personally 
  guarantee the payment owed General in exchange for General not filing a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien. According to Clark, Scroggs claimed that the filing of the lien would 
  prevent SMD from arranging funding for the money then due General under the 
  contract.
Robert Scroggs, President of SMD, testified there 
  were some problems with the work completed by General, but he was unsure of 
  the time frame, and he did not contact General regarding the problems.Â  He admitted 
  he never wrote General regarding the problem, and the problems were not mentioned 
  in any of the documents generated during the relevant time period.Â  Scroggs 
  acknowledged the weak financial situation of SMD and the need for additional 
  funding.Â  Scroggs denied that he personally guaranteed the payment of the remaining 
  balance due General, asserting instead that he was merely guaranteeing that 
  SMD would pay what was owed.Â  
Michael Bird, also with SMD, testified that he 
  was not satisfied with some of Generalâ€™s work, although he acknowledged the 
  absence of correspondence to confirm his trial testimony.Â  
The trial court found General had established its 
  claims against SMD for breach of the underlying contract and Scroggs for his 
  personal guaranty for the amount owed.Â  The court found in favor of General 
  on SMDâ€™s counterclaims.Â  The court entered judgment in favor of General in the 
  amount of $49,028 plus interest.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action for breach of contract seeking money damages 
  is an action at law.â€Â  R & G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. 
  Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 430, 540 S.E.2d 113, 117 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œIn an action 
  at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the 
  judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence 
  which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes Assocs. v. City 
  of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976). â€œThe judgeâ€™s 
  findings are equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in a law action.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS



 
 SMD contends that General failed to meet a condition 
  precedent in the contract, specifically the provision concerning Generalâ€™s duty 
  of â€œsatisfactory performance.â€Â  Scroggs maintains the court erred in finding 
  he personally guaranteed any amount owed by SMD.Â  We disagree, finding ample 
  evidence in the record to support the judgment of the able trial judge.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Condition Precedent
The contract provided:Â  â€œThe Contractor 
  [SMD] agrees to pay the Subcontractor [General] for satisfactory performance 
  of the Contractorâ€™s Work . . . .â€Â  A condition precedent entails something that 
  is essential to a right of action.Â  Worley v. Yarborough Ford, Inc., 
  317 S.C. 206, 210, 452 S.E.2d 622, 624 (Ct. App. 1994).Â Â  â€œIn contract law, 
  the term connotes any fact other than the lapse of time, which, unless excused, 
  must exist or occur before a duty of immediate performance arises.â€Â  Id.Â  
  We agree the satisfaction of SMD was a condition precedent to the payment of 
  the contract price, as such finding is not challenged on appeal and it represents 
  the law of this case.Â  Indeed, Algary, Generalâ€™s vice president, admitted the 
  work had to meet SMDâ€™s satisfaction.
The fundamental fallacy in SMDâ€™s position is its 
  apparent contention that its trial testimonyâ€”that it was not satisfied with 
  Generalâ€™s workâ€”is dispositive.Â  Our standard of review requires us to affirm 
  unless there is no evidence to support the trial judgeâ€™s findings. The court 
  found Generalâ€™s work was satisfactorily completed, and the record supports such 
  finding.Â  For example, the testimony of Algary and Clark, deemed credible by 
  the fact finder, supports this finding.Â  The trial judge assigned weight to 
  the absence of credible evidence of SMDâ€™s purported dissatisfaction with Generalâ€™s 
  work during the relevant time period prior to litigation, and we find no error 
  in this regard.Â  It was well within the province of the trial judge to view 
  the testimony offered by SMD as self-serving, especially in light of the complete 
  absence of documentation to support its position.Â  As there was evidence to 
  support the trial judgeâ€™s determination of SMDâ€™s satisfaction with the work 
  of General, and the corresponding finding that SMD owed the balance of the contract 
  price to General, we affirm the judgment for General on its breach of contract 
  claim against SMD.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Personal Guaranty

A.Â Â Â Â Â  Intent of Letters

Scroggs contends the letters he signed 
  were not evidence of a personal guaranty, but instead indicated his willingness 
  to assure payment by SMD.Â  We disagree and find evidence to support the trial 
  judgeâ€™s finding that Scroggs was personally liable to General for the remainder 
  of the contract price.
â€œA guaranty of payment is an absolute 
  or unconditional promise to pay a particular debt if it is not paid by the debtor 
  at maturity.â€Â  Citizens & S. Nat. Bank of South Carolina v. Lanford, 
  313 S.C. 540, 543, 443 S.E.2d 549, 550 (1994).Â  Additionally, â€œa contract signed 
  by an individual as an officer has been held to be the contract of the officer 
  where the contract contains a provision with respect to individual liability 
  of the signing officer.â€Â  Klutts Resort Realty, Inc. v. Downâ€™Round Dev. Corp., 
  268 S.C. 80, 87, 232 S.E.2d 20, 24 (1977) (citing 19 Am. Jur. 2d, Corporations 
  Â§ 1343 (1965)).Â  A director, officer, or other agent, signing a promise or guaranty 
  in the proper form for an individual, is not relieved from personal liability 
  by the addition to his name of terms such as director, president or other designation.Â  
  Id. at 88, 232 S.E.2d at 24.Â  â€œThese terms are regarded merely as [d]escriptio 
  personae, that is, a term descriptive of the person rather than the relationship 
  in which he signs the agreement.â€Â  Id.  
General provided evidence of conversations with 
  Scroggs in December 2000 and January 2001 in which Scroggs offered his â€œpersonal 
  guaranteeâ€ of payment provided General forgo its right to file a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien.Â  General accepted Scroggsâ€™ offer.Â  These assurances by Scroggs were followed 
  by letters.Â  The March 2, 2001, letter sent by Scroggs included the following 
  language:Â  â€œI would like to offer you my personal guarantee via this letter 
  for the money due.â€Â  It is signed by â€œRobert L. Scroggs, Jr./President.â€ Also, 
  the letter dated April 18, 2001, includes the following:Â  â€œPlease accept this 
  check and letter as my personal guarantee that all funds will be satisfied with 
  interest.â€Â  Again it is signed as â€œRobert L. Scroggs, Jr./President.â€ [1]   
We find, based on the evidence, including the language 
  used in the letters, the record supports the finding that Scroggs intended to 
  personally guarantee the debt of SMD to General.Â  While he signed the letters 
  as â€œPresident,â€ Scroggs explicitly stated it was a â€œpersonal guaranteeâ€ for 
  the debt.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the trial judgeâ€™s determination 
  that Scroggs intended to personally guarantee the debt of SMD to General.

B. Â Â Â Â  Consideration

Scroggs also maintains the personal guaranty 
  was invalid because there was no consideration. We disagree.
â€œA guaranty must be supported by sufficient legal 
  consideration, either a benefit to the principal obligor or guarantor on the 
  one hand, or some detriment to the obligee on the other.â€Â  Hope Petty Motors 
  of Columbia, Inc. v. Hyatt, 310 S.C. 171, 178, 425 S.E.2d 786, 791 (Ct. 
  App. 1992).Â  â€œA mere promise to pay the debt of another without any consideration 
  for such promise is void.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œValuable consideration may consist 
  of some right, interest, profit or benefit accruing to one party or some forbearance, 
  detriment, loss or responsibility given, suffered or undertaken by the other.â€ 
  McPeters v. Yeargin Constr. Co., 290 S.C. 327, 331, 350 S.E.2d 208, 211 
  (Ct. App. 1986).Â  
In the instant case, Clark testified General agreed 
  to forego the filing of a mechanicâ€™s lien in exchange for the personal guarantee 
  by Scroggs.Â  Clark testified the conversation occurred in January 2001.Â  Additionally, 
  Algary testified conversations regarding payment began as early as December 
  2000.Â  The forbearance from filing the mechanicâ€™s lien by General was sufficient 
  consideration to support the personal guaranty from Scroggs.
There also exists some dispute as to whether the 
  timing of the alleged conversations and the written personal guaranty support 
  a finding that the forbearance from filing the mechanicâ€™s lien was sufficient 
  consideration.Â  The case was tried on the premise that the mechanicâ€™s lien was 
  required to be filedâ€”pursuant to South Carolina lawâ€”within ninety days of the 
  completion of the project.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-90 (Supp. 2004). [2] Â Â  The work on the project was completed in 
  late November 2000 according to all involved.Â  Therefore, the mechanicâ€™s lien 
  would need to have been filed no later than the latter part of February 2001 
  or the beginning of March.Â  The first letter is dated March 2, 2001.Â  The subsequent 
  letter is clearly beyond the time for filing a mechanicâ€™s lien as it is dated 
  April 18, 2001.
However, the testimony by Clark and Algary indicated 
  the agreement to provide the guaranty in exchange for forgoing their right to 
  file a mechanicâ€™s lien occurred in December 2000 or January 2001.Â  The acknowledgment 
  and ratification of the agreement occurred in the letters, which may be after 
  the filing date, but the actual agreement occurred within the time for filing 
  the lien.Â  Thus, there is some evidence to support the trial judgeâ€™s conclusion 
  that the agreement not to file a mechanicâ€™s lien was sufficient and valuable 
  consideration to support the personal guaranty from Scroggs.
CONCLUSION
The judgment of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  There is some discussion in the briefs regarding whether the 
    letters met the Statute of Frauds.Â  However, this issue was never raised to 
    the trial court and never ruled upon by the court.Â  Accordingly, it is not 
    preserved for our review on appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 
    330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue 
    cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to 
    and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate reviewâ€).

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We accept as the law of this case the applicability of the 
    South Carolina mechanicâ€™s lien statute, section 29-5-90, in terms of computing 
    the time period for the filing of a lien.

PER CURIAM:Â  Darnell Alston (Appellant) 
  pled guilty to (1) first-degree burglary, (2) armed robbery, (3) two counts 
  of kidnapping, and (4) first-degree criminal sexual conduct.Â  Appellant was 
  sentenced to fifty years in prison for first-degree burglary, and thirty years

On appeal, counsel for Appellant has filed a final 
  brief along with a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Appellant has filed

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Esau Davis,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-119
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  16, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender 
  Robert M. Dudek, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Deputy Director for Legal Services Teresa A. Knox,.Legal Counsel Tommy Evans, Jr. 
  and Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, S.C. Dept. of Probation, all of Columbia, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this appeal, Esau Davis 
  argues the circuit court lacked jurisdiction to accept a guilty plea and revoke 
  his probation.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In August 2002, a Dorchester County grand 
  jury indicted Davis for throwing bodily fluids on a correctional facility employee.Â  
  On November 19, 2002, Davis pled guilty to the charge and received a sentence 
  of three years suspended to three years probation.Â  Davisâ€™s probation was subject 
  to a number of conditions including that Davis would not change residences without 
  the consent of his agent, would pay a supervision fee, and that he would follow 
  the advice and/or instructions of his agent.Â  
Davis was subsequently charged with violating 
  several conditions of his probation, including those outlined above. Â On February 
  24, 2003, Davis appeared at an administrative hearing to discuss the alleged 
  violations.Â  At the conclusion of the hearing, an administrative hearing officer 
  completed a report which found that Davis committed several violations of his 
  probation.Â  In the report, the hearing officer recommended a partial revocation 
  of Davisâ€™s probation for one year and screening for shock incarceration.Â  The 
  report also noted â€œFor Information Purposes Only: The Subject Has A Pending 
  Charge For Shoplifting 3rd.â€ Â 
On April 24, 2003, Davis appeared for 
  a guilty plea/probation revocation hearing.Â  As the administrative hearing report 
  noted, Davis faced one count of shoplifting, his third offense.Â  While questioning 
  Davis during the plea proceeding, the court inquired as to whether he was aware 
  that a conviction on the shoplifting charge would violate his probation and 
  expose him to three years in prison.Â  Davis responded in the affirmative.Â  Ultimately, 
  the court accepted his guilty plea and imposed a sentence of thirty days with 
  credit for time served.Â  The court also revoked Davisâ€™s probation in accordance 
  with the administrative hearing officerâ€™s recommendation.Â  The shoplifting charge 
  was not a factor in the revocation of Davisâ€™s probation.
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Davis argues his guilty 
  plea and probation revocation should be vacated because he â€œdid not waive grand 
  jury presentment in writing, and his probation was simultaneously revoked with 
  his guilty plea.â€Â  We disagree.
 In a criminal case, the circuit court has subject 
  matter jurisdiction to convict a defendant only if: â€œ(1) there has been an indictment 
  which sufficiently states the offense; (2) there has been a waiver of the indictment; 
  or (3) the charge is a lesser-included charge of the crime charged in the indictment.â€Â  
  Cutner v. State, 354 S.C. 151, 155, 580 S.E.2d 120, 122 (2003).Â  Furthermore, 
  â€œ[t]he lack of subject matter jurisdiction can be raised at any time, can be 
  raised for the first time on appeal, and can be raised sua sponte 
  by the court.â€Â  State v. Guthrie, 352 S.C. 103, 107, 572 S.E.2d 309, 
  311 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing State v. Brown, 351 S.C. 522, 570 S.E.2d 
  559 (2002)).
In order for a defendant to waive presentment 
  of an indictment, such waiver must be in writing.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-23-130 
  & 140 (2003); State v. McNeil, 314 S.C. 473, 475, 445 S.E.2d 461, 
  462 (Ct. App. 1994); see also Summerall v. State, 278 S.C. 
  255, 294 S.E.2d 344 (1982) (holding failure to execute written waivers of presentment 
  rendered guilty pleas invalid).
In the present case, it could not be clearer 
  that Davis did execute a written waiver of presentment.Â  At the beginning of 
  the plea proceeding, the court inquired as to whether Davis was informed of 
  his right to have the matter submitted to a grand jury.Â  Davisâ€™s counsel answered 
  that he was so informed.Â  To further ensure Davis knew of his right to grand 
  jury presentment, the trial court provided Davis and defense counsel time to 
  discuss the issue.Â  After a brief recess, defense counsel explained, â€œIâ€™ve explained 
  to him his rights as to the grand jury; and he wishes to waive that right.â€Â  
  The court went on to explain, in detail, the consequences of waiving presentment, 
  and Davis responded that he wished to â€œwaive the presentment and proceed here 
  today.â€Â  At this point, the following colloquy took place:

 The Court:Â  All right, Sir.Â  And [your intention 
  to waive presentment has] been indicated on the plea sheet where you have signed; 
  is that right?  [1] 
 [Davis]:Â  Yes, Maâ€™am.
 The Court:Â  Very well.Â  So youâ€™ve indicated 
  both orally and in writing that intention; is that right?
 [Davis]:Â  Yes, Maâ€™am.

Because it is clear from the record 
  that Davis did properly waive presentment in writing, we find his argument to 
  be without merit.Â  We also note that the shoplifting charge was not a factor 
  the trial court used to revoke Davisâ€™s probation; thus, to the extent Davis 
  argues his probation revocation is invalid because of the alleged errors with 
  the shoplifting charge, we find this argument to be meritless as well.
AFFIRMED.  
  [2] 
 HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  The â€œplea sheetâ€ is in the record, and Davisâ€™s signature is located 
    just below a box that is checked and reads â€œDefendant Waives Presentment to 
    Grand Jury.â€Â  

 
   [2]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD 
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State,       
        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Gustavo Alvarado,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-120
Heard January 11, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  16, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes and Richard Harold Warder, both of 
  Greenville, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliot, 
  Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Gustavo Alvarado appeals his 
  conviction for trafficking in marijuana.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
 On December 13, 2001, Chris Hines, a deputy with 
  the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Department, was patrolling Interstate 85 looking 
  for instances of aggressive driving, such as following too closely, improper 
  lane changes, and various trucking violations.Â  During the early evening hours, 
  Hines noticed a 1997 dark maroon Honda Accord tailgating and drifting onto the 
  lane divider. This observation prompted Hines to follow the car, turn on his 
  in-car video camera, and call out a traffic stop with his dispatch. 
Hines then stopped the car; however, because of 
  the heavy traffic on the highway, he went to the passenger side of the car and 
  requested the occupant in the front passenger seat to open the window.Â  When 
  the passenger opened the window about four or five inches, Hines immediately 
  detected an overwhelming odor of air freshener as well as a faint odor of raw 
  marijuana from inside the vehicle.
Alvarado, who was driving the car, produced a driverâ€™s license.Â  
  Following standard procedure, Hines further requested the vehicle registration 
  and insurance information.Â  After Alvarado produced these documents, Hines noticed 
  the proof of insurance had expired and instructed Alvarado to step to the rear 
  of the car.Â  
Hines then requested the passenger to look in 
  the glove box to locate current registration and insurance information on the 
  car.Â  Hines also asked the passenger his name and relationship to the driver.Â  
  The passenger produced identification from a company in Delaware that gave only 
  his name.Â  He also stated he was â€œjust a friendâ€ and his date of birth was October 
  10, 1977. 
After calling dispatch to check for warrants on 
  both Alvarado and his passenger, Hines learned that Spartanburg County had an 
  active warrant for someone with the same name as the passenger but a date of 
  birth of September 15, 1981.Â  In addition, the passenger appeared to Hines to 
  be in his late teens.Â  Hines attempted to verify the passengerâ€™s age with Alvarado, 
  and based on what Alvarado told him, determined that the passenger may in fact 
  be the subject of the warrant.Â  Because of Hinesâ€™ concerns about the smells 
  emanating from the car and conflicting information from Alvarado about the passenger, 
  he kept Alvarado and the passenger separated and called for a backup as well 
  as a narcotics K-9 officer.Â  
Hines testified he gave Alvarado warning tickets 
  for following too closely and the lane change violation.Â  He further testified 
  that he asked Alvarado if there was marijuana in the car and Alvarado hung his 
  head and answered there was not.Â  In contrast, when Hines inquired about cocaine 
  in the car, Alvarado raised his head and denied it.Â  When Hines asked a second 
  time about marijuana, Alvarado denied it, but again hung his head and avoided 
  eye contact.Â  In addition, Alvarado refused to allow a search of the car, even 
  after Hines explained to him that as the driver, he had authority to consent.Â  

When the backup officers arrived, the 
  passenger finally gave a correct date of birth matching what was on the warrant.Â  
  In addition, Deputy Teddy Hampton with the K-9 unit testified that contrary 
  to the usual practice, his K-9 dog abruptly pulled him to the rear of the vehicle 
  and scratched the bumper to indicate it had found something. 
  [1] Â  
Upon opening the trunk, Hines found 
  a U-Haul box.Â  When he pulled back one part of the lid of the box, he discovered 
  marijuana wrapped in brown packing tape.Â  Officers then placed Alvarado under 
  arrest.Â  
In addition to the U-haul box, officers 
  recovered a large garbage-style black plastic bag also contained marijuana.Â  
  Inside this bag was a white trash bag with marijuana and several other smaller 
  bags or bundles of marijuana.Â  During a search of the interior compartments 
  of the car, officers found a set of scales used to weigh small items and a green 
  pipe with a drawing of a skull on it.Â  In addition, Hampton, who searched Alvarado 
  incident to his arrest, found a wad of cash on Alvaradoâ€™s person, which, Alvarado 
  said, was around $700 but actually turned out to be more than that amount.
The Greenville County grand jury indicted 
  Alvarado for the offense of trafficking in marijuana.Â  Following a jury trial 
  in November 2002, Alvarado was found guilty as charged and sentenced to serve 
  eighteen years and fined $15,000.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
1.Â  Alvarado argues the 
  trial court should have suppressed the drugs because the traffic stop was pretextual 
  and the stop and resulting search were therefore unlawful.Â  We disagree.
â€œIn an appeal from a motion 
  to suppress evidence based on Fourth Amendment grounds, an appellate court may 
  conduct its own review of the record to determine whether the evidence supports 
  the circuit courtâ€™s decision.â€ [2] Â  Nevertheless, in reviewing such 
  a motion on appeal, â€œthis court is bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual 
  findings if any evidence supports the findings.â€ [3] Â  
Regarding Alvaradoâ€™s contention 
  that the stop was pretextual, the trial court found that the stop was reasonable 
  and supported by probable cause and that Hinesâ€™ conduct was entirely appropriate 
  under the facts presented in this case.Â  We agree with the State that there 
  is evidence in the record to support these findings. 
  [4] Â  Hines testified he observed the Honda Accord only about one car length 
  behind the vehicle in front of it while traveling at about sixty miles per hour.Â  
  He further stated that such a following distance was grossly inadequate under 
  the standards of the National Traffic Safety Administration. 
  [5] Â  
We also find no merit to 
  Alvaradoâ€™s argument that the marijuana should have been suppressed because Hines 
  did not have a reasonable suspicion to further detain him after giving him traffic 
  violation warnings.Â  
In support of 
  his argument that he was unlawfully detained, Alvarado cites State v. Williams 
  [6]  for the proposition that after the stop has been completed, further 
  detention is improper.Â  In our view, although Williams limits what a 
  police officer can do after a routine traffic stop, the case expressly allows 
  further detention for questioning after the stop is completed if â€œthe officer 
  has a reasonable suspicion of a serious crime.â€ 
  [7] 
In this case, Hines stated 
  he smelled the air freshener and the marijuana before he issued the traffic 
  warning to Alvarado.Â  He further testified he became concerned that Alvaradoâ€™s 
  passenger might have been the subject of an outstanding warrant.Â  In addition, 
  as noted by the trial court, the conflicting stories that Alvarado and his passenger 
  gave to Hines constituted an additional factor that when considered with the 
  other suspicious circumstances, would lead to an articulable suspicion of criminal 
  activity.
2.Â  We disagree with Alvaradoâ€™s contention that 
  the chain of custody for the marijuana found in the car was not sufficiently 
  established to admit the drugs into evidence. [8] Â  
â€œThe admission of evidence is discretionary with 
  the trial judge.â€ [9] Â  â€œProof of chain of custody need 
  not negate all possibility of tampering but must establish a complete chain 
  of evidence as far as practicable.â€ [10] Â  â€œ[I]f the identity of each person in the 
  chain handling the evidence is established, and the manner of handling is reasonably 
  demonstrated, no abuse of discretion is shown in the admission, absent proof 
  of tampering, bad faith, or ill-motive.â€ 
  [11] Â  Furthermore, â€œwhere there is a weak link in the chain of custody, 
  as opposed to a missing link, the question is only one of credibility and not 
  admissibility.â€ [12] 
In the present case, Hines testified that after 
  he seized the bags of marijuana, he listed them on the property report and secured 
  them with evidence tape.Â  Tony Vinskus, the supervisor over the property and 
  evidence section, testified that narcotics must be submitted to his division 
  in tamper-proof, sealed packaging.Â  Vinskus also testified that when contraband 
  is received, trained personnel witness the drop being made and the evidence 
  remains in a locked dropbox until it is processed into evidence storage.Â  As 
  to the one individual who handled the evidence before it was analyzed but was 
  not called as a witness at trial, Vinskus testified about that employeeâ€™s responsibilities 
  and the procedures she followed in carrying out her duties.Â  We have found no 
  evidence suggesting this individual did not follow established protocol, and 
  Alvarado does not direct our attention to anything in the record showing her 
  work on the case deviated from standard procedure. [13] 
3.Â  Finally, we reject Alvaradoâ€™s argument that he 
  should have received a directed verdict because the evidence was insufficient 
  to support a finding that he had dominion and control over the marijuana.
Any person â€œwho is knowingly in actual 
  or constructive possessionâ€ of ten pounds or more of marijuana is guilty of 
  trafficking in marijuana. [14] Â  
  â€œTo prove constructive possession, the State must show a defendant had dominion 
  and control,â€ over the contraband. 
  [15] Â  â€œConstructive possession can be established by circumstantial as 
  well as direct evidence, and possession may be shared.â€ 
  [16] Â  â€œThe knowledge element may be proved circumstantially by evidence 
  of acts, declarations, or conduct of the accused from which an inference may 
  be drawn that the accused knew of the existence of the prohibited substance.â€ [17] Â  â€œBecause actual knowledge of the presence 
  of the drug is strong evidence of intent to control its disposition or use, 
  knowledge may be equated with or substituted for the intent element.â€ 
  [18] 
In support of his argument, Alvarado emphasizes 
  that the vehicle that he was driving belonged to his brother and he had merely 
  borrowed it to give his cousin, Ricardo Gallegos, a ride.Â  He also notes that 
  Gallegos testified at trial that Alvarado was unaware of and had nothing to 
  do with the marijuana seized in the present case, which was found in a closed 
  container in the trunk of the car.Â  
We, however, hold the record has sufficient 
  evidence that would support a finding by the jury that Alvarado had at least 
  the right to exercise dominion and control over the drugs.Â  It is undisputed 
  that Alvarado was driving the car when it was stopped; therefore, it is reasonable 
  to infer that he had dominion and control over â€œpremises upon which the drugs 
  were found.â€ [19] Â  And this is not the only evidence that supports 
  Alvaradoâ€™s conviction.Â  Alvaradoâ€™s behavior during the traffic stop, including 
  his refusal to make eye contact when asked if he had marijuana and the vague 
  answers he gave to questions regarding the circumstances of his journey, could 
  be considered indicative of his participation in criminal activity and of his 
  awareness that he had been caught with contraband.Â  He also had over $700 in 
  cash on his person when he was arrested.Â  Moreover, during the trial, Gallegos 
  admitted to owning only the pipe that was seized from the car, which could support 
  an inference that the scales belonged to Alvarado.Â  In addition, the excessive 
  amount of air freshener in the car was susceptible of the inference that the 
  occupants were attempting to mask the pungent smell of the marijuana, which, 
  despite this effort, was of such a quantity that it emanated an odor that was 
  detected almost immediately by both the arresting officer and the K-9 dog.
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Hampton stated that he usually started the dog from the front of 
    the car and worked backwards.

 
   
    [2] Â  State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C. 344, 349-50, 592 S.E.2d 344, 
    347 (Ct. App.), cert. denied (Nov. 19, 2004).

 
   
    [3] Â  Id. at 349, 592 S.E.2d at 344 (emphasis added).

 
   
    [4] Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-1930 (1991) (prohibiting driving 
    more closely than is reasonable); id. Â§ 56-5-1900 (stating rules for 
    driving on roadways laned for traffic); State v. Butler, 343 S.C. 198, 
    201, 539 S.E.2d 414, 416 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œ[T]he decision to stop an 
    automobile is reasonable where the police have probable cause to believe that 
    a traffic violation has occurred.â€).

 
   
    [5] Â  Hines also explained the in-car video that he took did not show 
    any traffic violations because he turned the tape on only after he saw the 
    initial violations.Â  

 
   
    [6] Â  351 S.C. 591, 571 S.E.2d 703 (Ct. App. 2002).

 
   
    [7] Â  Id. at 598, 571 S.E.2d at 707.

 
   
    [8] Â  We further agree with the State that any error in the admission 
    of this evidence was later cured by statements elicited by Alvarado in his 
    case-in-chief from Ricardo Gallegos, the passenger in the car, that Gallegos 
    bought a hundred pounds of marijuana and put it in the trunk of the car.

 
   
    [9] Â  State v. Williams, 297 S.C. 290, 293, 376 S.E.2d 773, 774 
    (1989).

 
   [10]  Id.

 
   
    [11]  State v. Taylor, 360 S.C. 18, 25, 598 S.E.2d 735, 738 (Ct. 
    App. 2004).

 
   
    [12]  State v. Carter, 344 S.C. 419, 424, 544 S.E.2d 835, 837 (2001).Â  
  

 
   
    [13]  We further agree with the State that there is no merit to Alvaradoâ€™s 
    contention that testimony from four additional individuals whose names appeared 
    on the property report was necessary.Â  According to Vinskus, these individuals 
    were involved in handling the evidence only after it had been analyzed.Â  See 
    State v. Singleton, 319 S.C. 312, 317, 460 S.E.2d 573, 576 (1995) (noting 
    that when offering fungible evidence, the State â€œmust trace possession of 
    the substance and what was done with it from the time it was taken until the 
    final analysisâ€).

 
   
    [14]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(e)(1) (2002 & Supp. 2004).

 
   
    [15]  State v. Hudson, 277 S.C. 200, 202, 284 S.E.2d 773, 774-75 
    (1981). 

 
   
    [16]  Id. at 202, 284 S.E.2d at 775.

 
   
    [17]  State v. Mollison, 319 S.C. 41, 45, 459 S.E.2d 88, 91 (Ct. 
    App. 1995).

 
   
    [18]  State v. Kimbrell, 294 S.C. 51, 54, 362 S.E.2d 630, 631 (1987).

 
   
    [19]  State v. Lane, 271 S.C. 68, 73, 245 S.E.2d 114, 117 (1978) 
    (quoting State v. Ellis, 263 S.C. 12, 23, 207 S.E.2d 408, 413 (1974)); 
    see also State v. Potts, 464 P.2d 742, 745 (Wash. Ct. App. 1969) 
    (rejecting the defendantâ€™s argument that the failure of the prosecution to 
    prove he was the owner of the car in which marijuana was found was fatal to 
    the claim that he had constructive possession of the drugs and noting that 
    the defendant, as the driver and sole occupant of the car, â€œhad dominion and 
    control over the â€˜premisesâ€™â€), cited in State v. Wise, 272 S.C. 
    384, 387, 252 S.E.2d 294, 295 (1979).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Derrin Delesline,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Daniel  F.Â  Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-121
Heard February 8, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  16, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and 
  Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Derrin Delesline appeals his 
  convictions for distribution of crack cocaine and distribution of crack cocaine 
  in proximity of a school.Â  He argues the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction 
  because the indictments did not allege the requisite mental state of knowledge.Â  
  He also argues the court erred in admitting a tape recording made from a wire 
  worn by a confidential informant and in failing to strike testimony regarding 
  other drug transactions.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the 
  following authorities:
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The indictments alleged the elements necessary 
  to convey subject matter jurisdiction: State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 
  576, 579, 564 S.E.2d 103, 105 (2002) (A court acquires subject matter jurisdiction 
  over a defendant where â€œthere is an indictment which sufficiently states the 
  offense, the defendant waives presentment, or the offense is a lesser included 
  offense of the crime charged in the indictment.â€); Browning v. State, 320 
  S.C. 366, 368, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1995) (â€œThe true test of the sufficiency 
  of an indictment is not whether it could be made more definite and certain, 
  but whether it contains the necessary elements of the offense intended to be 
  charged and sufficiently apprises the defendant of what he must be prepared 
  to meet.â€); State v. Gill, 355 S.C. 234, 584 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (holding the element of knowledge is not required in an indictment for the crime 
  of distribution of crack cocaine).
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The issue of whether the trial 
  court erred in admitting the tape recording is not preserved for review: State 
  v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 482 S.E.2d 760 (1997) (holding a general objection 
  that fails to specify the particular ground on which the objection is based 
  is insufficient to preserve a question for review); York v. Conway Ford, 
  Inc., 325 S.C. 170, 480 S.E.2d 726 (1997) (stating an objection made in 
  an off-the-record conference not later placed on the record does not preserve 
  the issue for review). 
3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The issue of whether the trial 
  court erred in failing to strike testimony concerning other drug transactions 
  is not preserved for review: State v. McFadden, 318 S.C. 404, 410, 458 
  S.E.2d 61, 65 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding issues concerning objectionable testimony 
  are not preserved for appellate purposes when an objection is sustained if the 
  objecting party does not move to strike the offending testimony).Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING 
  EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Kenneth E. Sowell,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-122
Heard November 10, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  17, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kenneth E. Sowell, of Greenville, pro se, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John M. McIntosh, Chief, State Grand Jury, Sherri A. Lydon, and Assistant 
  Attorney General Jennifer D. Evans, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Kenneth Sowell appeals the 
  circuit courtâ€™s order finding him in criminal contempt for disclosing grand 
  jury information subject to a protective order.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The State Grand Jury conducted an investigation 
  into a methamphetamine ring in Greenville, Greenwood, and Laurens counties.Â  
  As a result of this investigation, the grand jury â€œtrue-billedâ€ an indictment 
  against Bobby Joe Lewis for trafficking and conspiracy to traffic methamphetamine.Â  
  After being charged, Lewis hired Sowell to represent him on the charges.Â  Sowell 
  came into contact with Lewis through Kenneth Curtis, who was also a target of 
  the investigation and previously a client of Sowell.Â  According to Curtis, 
  he paid Sowell to represent Lewis with the understanding that if Lewis intended 
  to â€œflip,â€ Sowell would let him know. 
In the course of his representation of Lewis, Sowell 
  requested that the Attorney Generalâ€™s office provide him with information that 
  was part of the grand jury investigation.Â  Because the Legislature has 
  deemed this information to be secret, its dissemination is governed by the provisions 
  of section 14-7-1720 of the South Carolina Code of Laws.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-7-1720(A) 
  (Supp. 2004) (â€œState grand jury proceedings are secret, and a state grand juror 
  shall not disclose the nature or substance of the deliberations or vote of the 
  state grand jury.â€); see Anderson v. State, 338 S.C. 629, 632, 
  527 S.E.2d 398, 399 (Ct. App. 2000) (recognizing this stateâ€™s long-held policy 
  regarding the secrecy surrounding grand jury proceedings).Â  
Pursuant to this statute, the Attorney General 
  â€œmay not disclose the testimony of a witness examined before a state grand jury 
  or other evidence received by it except when directed by a court for the purpose 
  of . . . providing the defendant the materials to which he is entitled pursuant 
  to Section 14-7-1700.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-7-1720(A)(4)(Supp. 2004); see 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-7-1700 (Supp. 2004) (â€œSubject to the limitations of Section 
  14-7-1720(A) and (D) and Rule 5, South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure, 
  a defendant has the right to review and to reproduce the stenographically or 
  electronically recorded materials.â€).Â  â€œIf the court orders disclosure of matters 
  occurring before a state grand jury, the disclosure must be made in that manner, 
  at that time, and under those conditions as the court directs.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 14-7-1720(A) (Supp. 2004).
In this case, the judge issued a protective order 
  that permitted the dissemination of the grand jury information to Sowell, but 
  imposed certain conditions on the disclosure.Â  The order provides in relevant 
  part:

IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that the Attorney General is protected 
  if he chooses to disclose to the attorneys for the defendants in the above-captioned 
  cases testimony taken in the State Grand Jury and interviews of witnesses and 
  other documents which must subsequently be disclosed under normal circumstances 
  at trial.Â  It is understood that the State Grand Jury material is being provided 
  only for purposes of the trial of the above-captioned cases.Â  The attorney for 
  the defendants and the defendants are bound by the secrecy provisions of Â§ 14-7-1720.
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 
  14-7-1700 and â€“1720(A) (Law. Co-op. 1976), the defendants and their attorneys 
  are prohibited from photocopying any State Grand Jury testimony, interviews 
  of witnesses and any other documents that may be disclosed to the defendants 
  and their attorneys in reference to the above-captioned case.Â  All such materials 
  shall be completely destroyed at the conclusion of the case.Â  
Nothing in this Order prohibits the defendants or their attorneys 
  from using Brady material for purposes of preparing for trial.

The relevant materials were made available to Sowell 
  after the protective order was signed.Â  Sowell admits the information was shared 
  with Gene Gore, a private investigator Sowell had employed numerous times.Â  
  Sowell testified he informed Gore that the information he was sharing with him 
  could not be given to anyone and the documents must be kept â€œunder lock and 
  key at all times.â€
Significantly, Gore also sold used cars, and Kenneth 
  Curtis had previously purchased five or six cars from him.Â  It was ultimately 
  revealed that Curtis paid Gore for his investigative services.Â  A portion of 
  the evidence subject to the court order led to another member, Floyd Ballew, 
  of the methamphetamine ring who implicated Curtis.Â  Gore found Ballew and had 
  him sign an affidavit to this affect.Â  Gore then used this affidavit to confront 
  Curtis in an attempt to acquire information.Â  
This disclosure of information by Gore to Curtis 
  was revealed when Curtis was caught on a confidential informantâ€™s tape stating 
  he was aware he was the subject of the State Grand Jury investigation.Â  Based 
  on this information, the State filed a motion for Sowell to show cause why he 
  was not guilty of criminal contempt. 
After a hearing, the trial judge found Sowell guilty 
  of criminal contempt of court for willfully disclosing information subject to 
  a protective order.Â  Specifically, the judge held the State â€œclearly established 
  that [Sowell] was not directed by the Court to release this information to Gore 
  nor did he explain the secrecy requirement of the Protective Order.â€Â  The 
  judge sentenced Sowell to ninety days imprisonment suspended upon the payment 
  of a $5,000 fine within ninety days.Â  Subsequently, Sowell filed a motion for 
  reconsideration.Â  The judge denied this motion, but reduced the amount 
  of the fine to $2,500. Â 
Sowell appeals his conviction of criminal contempt 
  of court.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A determination of contempt ordinarily resides 
  in the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Whetstone v. Whetstone, 
  309 S.C. 227, 233, 420 S.E.2d 877, 880-81 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œThis court will 
  reverse a trial courtâ€™s decision regarding contempt only if it is without evidentiary 
  support or is an abuse of discretion.Â Â  An abuse of discretion can occur where 
  the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.â€Â  First Union Natâ€™l 
  Bank v. First Citizens Bank & Trust Co. of South Carolina, 346 S.C. 
  462, 466, 551 S.E.2d 301, 303 (Ct. App. 2001) (citations omitted).
DISCUSSION
Sowell argues the circuit court judge erred in 
  finding him in criminal contempt. 
  [1] Â  He contends he was permitted to reveal grand jury information to his 
  investigator and, thus, there was no evidence to support the judgeâ€™s decision.Â  
  We disagree. 
â€œThe power to punish for contempt is inherent in 
  all courts and is essential to the preservation of order in judicial proceedings.â€Â  
  In re Diggs, 344 S.C. 434, 434, 544 S.E.2d 632, 632 (2001).Â  A courtâ€™s 
  contempt power arises when an individual willfully disobeys an order of the 
  court.Â  Id.Â  â€œA willful act is defined as one â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally 
  with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific 
  intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say, 
  with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™â€Â  Spartanburg County 
  Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 
  (1988) (quoting Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1434 (5th ed. 1979)).Â  â€œIntent 
  for purposes of criminal contempt is subjective, not objective, and must necessarily 
  be ascertained from all of the acts, words and circumstances surrounding the 
  occurrence.â€ State v. Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. 122, 129, 447 S.E.2d 213, 
  217 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  
However, â€œ[o]ne may not be convicted of contempt 
  for violating a court order which fails to tell him in definite terms what he 
  must do.â€Â  Welchel v. Boyter, 260 S.C. 418, 421, 196 S.E.2d 496, 498 
  (1973).Â  In a criminal contempt proceeding, the State has the burden of proving 
  the guilt of the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  State v. Bowers, 
  270 S.C. 124, 131, 241 S.E.2d 409, 412 (1978).Â  â€œ[B]efore a person may be held 
  in contempt, the record must be clear and specific as to acts or conduct upon 
  which such finding is based.â€Â  State v. Harper, 297 S.C. 257, 258, 376 
  S.E.2d 272, 274 (1989).Â Â  
As a threshold matter, we note that Sowell neither 
  challenges the validity of the order nor the application of section 14-7-1720 
  to him. [2] Â  Therefore, we do not analyze this issue.Â  
  Instead, he admits disclosure of the material to his investigator, but claims 
  this disclosure did not violate the protective order. 
Section 14-7-1700 grants a defendant the right 
  to review and reproduce grand jury material.Â  This right is limited by the strictures 
  of sections 14-7-1720(A) and (D), as well as Rule 5 of the South Carolina Rules 
  of Criminal Procedure.Â  Section 14-7-1720(A) requires that the disclosure to 
  the defendant â€œmust be made in that manner, at that time, and under those conditions 
  as the court directs.â€Â  By the terms of the order, the judge imposed on Sowell 
  the same secrecy provisions that are applicable to the Attorney General under 
  section 14-7-1720(B). [3] Â  Therefore, if Sowell intended 
  to disclose this information to Gore in order to prepare an adequate defense 
  for Lewis, he was bound by the mandatory language of section 14-7-1720(B)(2), 
  which provides in pertinent part:

The Attorney General or his designee promptly shall provide 
  the presiding judge before whom was impaneled the state grand jury whose material 
  has been disclosed, the names of the persons to whom the disclosure has been 
  made, and shall certify that he has advised these persons of their obligation 
  of secrecy under this section.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§14-7-1720 (B)(2) (Supp. 2004). [4] Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Applying these provisions to the instant case, 
  we hold the judgeâ€™s decision was not based on an error of law given he relied 
  on the appropriate legal standards for a finding of contempt.Â  In determining 
  Sowell willfully violated the protective order, the judge found the State presented 
  clear and specific evidence of Sowellâ€™s conduct and that Sowell was guilty beyond 
  a reasonable doubt.
Furthermore, the trial judge sat as the trier of 
  facts.Â  Thus, based on our limited standard of review, we will not disturb his 
  findings unless they are without evidentiary support.Â  We find there is evidence 
  to support the judgeâ€™s ruling.Â  First, there is no dispute that Sowell failed 
  to inform the court that he disclosed the grand jury material to Gore until 
  prompted by the Stateâ€™s motion for a rule to show cause.Â  In terms of the second 
  requirement under section 14-7-1720(B)(2), the judge concluded Sowell failed 
  to explain to Gore the obligation of secrecy.Â  In support of this ruling, the 
  judge implicitly rejected the testimony of Sowell and, instead, found Gore and 
  Curtis to be credible witnesses.Â  We give due deference to the trial judgeâ€™s 
  consideration of credibility matters.Â  See Cherry v. Thomasson, 
  276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981) (On appeal, this court is not 
  required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, 
  was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative 
  weight to their testimony.).Â  
In his findings of fact, the judge stated Gore 
  testified, â€œhe was not given any instruction regarding the release of this information 
  to any other individuals from the Defendant.â€Â  Additionally, â€œGore admits that 
  the information contained in this material was related to Mr. Kenny Curtis.â€Â  
  As to Curtis, the judge found that â€œCurtis testified that he was kept apprized 
  throughout this investigation of the material that pertained to him and paid 
  Gore five thousand dollars ($5,000) to act as a private investigator for the 
  Defendant.â€Â  These findings are supported by the testimony of Gore and 
  Curtis.Â  Based on the specific facts of this case and our limited standard of 
  review, we hold the judge did not abuse his discretion in finding Sowell in 
  criminal contempt of the protective order.Â  
 This decision should not be interpreted 
  to mean that a defense attorney is precluded from disclosing state grand jury 
  material to his or her staff or investigator.Â  This position, which the State 
  appeared to advocate at oral argument, would put defense counsel at a disadvantage 
  in that it would severely limit counselâ€™s ability to prepare an adequate defense.Â  
  However, if disclosure is permitted then defense counsel must abide by the conditions 
  imposed by a court pursuant to section 14-7-1720(A).Â  By requiring defense counsel 
  to proceed through the proper channels, similar to the State, the court will 
  be able to preserve the sanctity of grand jury material.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the circuit court judgeâ€™s 
  finding of criminal contempt is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â Â  
  

 
   
    [1] Â  We note Sowell raises five separate issues in his brief.Â  Because 
    all of the issues challenge the finding of contempt, we have consolidated 
    them in the interest of clarity.

 
   
    [2] Â Â  The plain language of section 14-7-1720 applies only to jurors, 
    individuals involved in the state grand jury process, and law enforcement 
    personnel who are entitled to the information under subsection (B) based on 
    their assistance to the Attorney General.Â  Therefore, the secrecy provisions 
    of section 14-7-1720 would not apply to Sowell unless the judge, as in this 
    case, limited the use of the information pursuant to the courtâ€™s power to 
    condition the disclosure of information.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-7-1720 (A) (Supp. 
    2004).

 
   
    [3] Â Â  In the protective order, the judge only generally referenced the 
    secrecy provisions of section 14-7-1720.Â  However, in the contempt 
    order, the judge specifically relied on subsection A when he concluded that 
    Sowell failed to obtain prior approval of the court before disclosing the 
    information.Â  The judge also implicitly relied on subsection B in finding 
    that Sowell failed to explain to Gore the secrecy requirement of the protective 
    order.Â  The judgeâ€™s reliance on subsection A would appear to be inapplicable 
    to Sowell given that subsection controls the initial disclosure to the Attorney 
    General and forms the basis for the protective order.Â  Based on our review 
    of section 14-7-1720, we believe the procedure governing Sowellâ€™s disclosure 
    of the grand jury information was controlled by section 14-7-1720(B)(2), which 
    does not require prior approval of the court.Â Â  This error, as will be discussed, 
    does not affect our ultimate decision.

 
   
    [4] Â Â  We note that the language of our state statute is similar to that 
    of Rule 6(e)(3) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure.Â  See State 
    v. Follin, 352 S.C. 235, 246, 573 S.E.2d 812, 817 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œFederal 
    Rule of Criminal Procedure 6(e) is very similar to our statute regarding disclosure 
    of secret information to subsequent grand juries.â€).Â Â Â  Despite the fact that 
    our statute tracks the language of the federal rule, our research has not 
    revealed any federal case law that provides definitive guidance on the issue 
    presented in this appeal.Â  See Sara Sun Beale, et al., Grand 
    Jury Law and Practice Â§5:7 (2d ed. 2003), available in Westlaw, 
    GRJURLAW (â€œIn particular, it is not clear whether [Rule 6(e)(3)(A)(i)] permits 
    the attorney to make further disclosures of the grand jury materials to others.â€); 
    Id. (â€œ[T]he courts are not likely to accept any argument that disclosures 
    to private investigators assisting the prosecutors with a criminal case would 
    be permitted under the â€˜performance of dutiesâ€™ clause since the same disclosure 
    would be barred by the more specific subsection of the Rule that governs disclosures 
    to agents assisting the government in the criminal case.Â  By contrast, a prosecutorâ€™s 
    disclosure of grand jury materials to his secretary, paralegal, or law clerk 
    would be regarded as routine disclosure closely tied to the prosecutorâ€™s role 
    in conducting the grand jury proceeding and any subsequent criminal action.â€); 
    1 Charles Alan Wright, Federal Practice and Procedure Â§ 107, at 398-400Â  
    (3d ed. 1999) (â€œ[M]achinery has now been provided by which federal prosecutors 
    can utilize, without a court order, other government personnel.Â  The government 
    personnel to whom grand-jury material is disclosed under this provision cannot 
    use the material in a manner that would not be permissible for the government 
    attorney himself.â€).Â  Given the divergent views analyzing this issue and the 
    fact that Sowell does not challenge the validity of the protective order, 
    we have chosen not to establish a bright line rule for a defense attorneyâ€™s 
    disclosure of grand jury information.Â  Instead, we limit our review of this 
    issue by applying the facts of the instant case to our state statutory language 
    within the context of our limited standard of review.
