THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Wells Fargo Bank Minnesota, National Association,
FKA, Norwest Bank Minnesota, 
        National Association, as Trustee, for the registered Holders of Option 
        One Mortgage Loan Trust 1999-C, Asset-Backed Certificate, Series 1999-C, 
        without recourse,        Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Peggy M. Luther and the South Carolina Department of Public Safety, and 
        all unknown persons with any right, title or interest in the mobileÂ Â  
        manufactured home described herein being a class designated as John Doe 
        now known to be Denise Gardner,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
Jeffrey M. Tzerman, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-123
Heard January 11, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  17, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
 Robert J. Thomas, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Rolland E. Greenburg, III and William L. Todd, both of Columbia, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  This appeal 
  arises from an order allowing foreclosure on a piece of real property but not 
  on a mobile home located on that property.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In 1996, Denise Gardner acquired sole 
  ownership of a mobile home that she placed on a piece of vacant real estate 
  in Lugoff.Â  Both Denise and her mother, Peggy Luther, had an ownership interest 
  in the real estate. [1] Â  Peggy moved into the mobile 
  home with Denise after Denise was involved in an automobile accident.Â  
While Peggy was living with Denise, an 
  agent of Approved Federal Savings Bank (â€œBankâ€) contacted Peggy offering to 
  consolidate her various debts by refinancing her real property.Â  Peggy agreed 
  and understood the consolidation transaction was going to be a refinance on 
  her property.Â  Pursuant to section 37-10-102(a) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 
  2003), the Bank provided Peggy with a notice that explained she could choose 
  her own closing attorney and insurance agent.Â  Because Peggy indicated she had 
  no preference in legal counsel, Brett F. Kline was chosen by the Bank and served 
  as Peggyâ€™s counsel.Â  Kline met with Peggy twice in her home during this transaction.Â  

In order to effectuate the refinancing, 
  Denise signed a limited warranty deed on September 3, 1999, conveying her interest 
  in the real estate to Peggy, such that Peggy would become the sole owner of 
  the real estate.Â Â  While the face of the deed did not purport to transfer the 
  mobile home, the legal description of the deeded property which was contained 
  on a separate paper and attached to the deed, included a statement that the 
  transfer included all improvements on the real estate and â€œthat it is the borrowerâ€™s 
  intent that the mobile home loses its nature as personalty and becomes realty.â€Â  

Peggy also executed a promissory 
  note in favor of the Bank [2]  
  for $65,500 on that same day.Â  The promissory note was secured by a mortgage 
  on the real estate.Â Â  The legal description of the mortgaged property also stated 
  that the transfer included all improvements and â€œthat it is the borrowerâ€™s intent 
  that the mobile home loses its nature as personalty and becomes realty.â€Â  Peggy 
  also executed an â€œAffixation Affidavit Regarding Manufactured Home,â€ and a manufactured 
  housing rider to the mortgage, in which Peggy attested to the permanent affixation 
  of the mobile home to the real estate.Â  
Peggy testified that she was seventy 
  years old, did not necessarily understand what she was signing, did not finish 
  the ninth grade, and was in poor health.Â  Peggy also testified that at the time 
  she signed these papers, she believed that the land and the mobile home belonged 
  to her daughter, Denise.Â  During Peggyâ€™s deposition, Peggy represented that 
  she knew she was signing the papers in order to have the â€œtrailer refinanced,â€ 
  but that she did not and never had owned the mobile home.Â  Peggyâ€™s deposition 
  testimony also revealed that she acknowledged signing the papers, but no one 
  was there to witness her signature.Â  Peggy testified that her attorney, Kline, 
  told her â€œnot to worry about it, that he was going to take it back to the office, 
  and get somebody to witness it there.â€Â  The documents revealed Robert V. Harrelson 
  to be the subscribing witness.Â  
Denise testified that it was never her 
  intent to transfer the mobile home to her mother, and that she told Kline that 
  she would not sign anything that could ever cause her to lose her mobile home.Â  
  Denise also testified that she thought her mother was borrowing money on the 
  land and not the mobile home.Â  The loan proceeds were used to pay off Peggyâ€™s 
  medical bills and to pay off money Denise owed on the mobile home.Â  
On December 1, 2000, Peggy defaulted 
  on the promissory note and mortgage.Â  The Bank brought a declaratory judgment 
  action seeking a determination that the mobile home was subject to the mortgage 
  and an action for foreclosure of the mortgage.Â  The case was transferred to 
  the master-in-equity.Â  
The master issued an order on February 
  11, 2004, finding that each page of the mortgage was initialed by Peggy except 
  the legal description, â€œwhich was prepared and attached to the document after 
  the execution of the Mortgage and was never presented to or reviewed by Peggy.â€Â Â  
  The master also found, in relevant part, that (1) the deed and mortgage were 
  not properly witnessed, (2) the mortgage was invalid as a legal mortgage, (3) 
  the deed failed to transfer title to the mobile home to Peggy, (4) the Bank 
  failed to perfect a lien on the mobile home, (5) the failure to perfect was 
  fatal to the Bankâ€™s claim that it was entitled to foreclose on the mobile home 
  as an improvement located on the real property, and (6) the Bank was entitled 
  to foreclose pursuant to an equitable mortgage against the real estate only.Â  
  The Bank appeals the masterâ€™s failure to include the mobile home in the equitable 
  mortgage. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œActions for foreclosure or the cancellation 
  of instruments are actions in equity.â€Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 324 S.C. 
  570, 576-77, 479 S.E.2d 510, 513 (1996).Â  Since the master-in-equity heard 
  this equitable action without appeal to the circuit court, the appellate court 
  may find the facts on appeal in accordance with its own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Id.Â  However, the appellate court should not disregard 
  the findings of the master who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better 
  position to judge their credibility.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Bankâ€™s sole argument on appeal 
  is that the master erred in concluding that the mobile home was not a fixture 
  and not subject to the equitable mortgage.Â  We disagree.Â  
The Bank argues that it was the intent 
  of the parties to subject the mobile home to the equitable mortgage and permanently 
  affix the mobile home to the real estate.Â  In making this argument, the Bank 
  asserts the master erred in making certain findings of fact.Â  First, the Bank 
  alleges the master erred in omitting from the order the fact that the legal 
  description of the deeded property included the mobile home.Â  Second, the Bank 
  alleges that the master erred in finding the legal description, which included 
  the mobile home, was prepared and attached to the mortgage and deed after 
  Peggy signed the papers.Â  Third, the Bank argues the master erred in finding 
  that Denise testified â€œthe mobile home at no time was to be transferred or included 
  in the contemplated loan.â€Â  We disagree and find that the facts, in accordance 
  with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence, support the order of 
  the master-in-equity.
Initially, we find the Bankâ€™s equitable 
  mortgage did not extend to the mobile home.Â  For an equitable lien to arise, 
  there must be a debt owing from one person to another; specific property to 
  which the debt attaches; and an intent, expressed or implied, that the property 
  will serve as security for the payment of the debt.Â  First Federal Sav. and 
  Loan Assâ€™n of Charleston v. Bailey,  316 S.C. 350, 356, 450 S.E.2d 
  77, 80-81 (Ct. App. 1994). If a mortgage is actually signed by the mortgagor 
  and intended to secure the debt, it can be treated as an equitable mortgage. 
  See Stelts v. Martin, 90 S.C. 14, 16-17, 72 S.E.2d 550, 551 (1911);Â  
  Bryce v. Massey, 35 S.C. 127, 142, 14 S.E. 768, 774 (1892).
In this case, there is no doubt that Peggy 
  owes a debt to the Bank.Â  Moreover, it is uncontested that Peggy sought to secure 
  the debt with her real estate.Â  However, we do not find that Denise or Peggy 
  intended for the mobile home to serve as security.Â  The Bank does not appeal 
  from the masterâ€™s finding that the deed purporting to transfer the mobile home 
  from Denise to Peggy was invalid.Â  This unappealed ruling becomes the law of 
  the case and precludes consideration of the validity of the deed on appeal.Â  
  See ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche,  
  327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 S.E.2d 470, 472 (1997).Â  As a result, Peggy never 
  had an ownership interest in the mobile home to subject to a mortgage.Â  Cf. 
  McDavid v. McDavid, 187 S.C. 127, 139, 197 S.E. 204, 209 (1938) 
  (â€œIf one has a legal right to sell land, he would likewise have the right to 
  mortgage it.â€).Â  
Therefore, we must look to the intent of 
  Denise, as sole and exclusive owner of the mobile home, to see if she entered 
  into any transaction that would subject her mobile home to the Bankâ€™s equitable 
  mortgage.Â  Denise, however, owes no debt to the Bank.Â  The debt owed to the 
  Bank is owed solely by Peggy.Â  While Denise signed a deed that purported to 
  transfer her interest in the mobile home to her mother, this deed was found 
  to be invalid.Â  See ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, L.P.,  327 S.C. 
  at 241, 489 S.E.2d at 472.Â  Moreover, the legal description of the deeded property 
  included improvements and a statement â€œthat it is the borrowerâ€™s intent that 
  the mobile home loses its nature as personalty and becomes realty.â€Â  This legal 
  description was never signed or initialed by Denise, nor does it evince Deniseâ€™s 
  intent; rather, it merely expresses Peggyâ€™s intent as â€œborrower.â€Â Â  
Although the Bank asserts that the parties 
  were represented by attorney Kline, implying that Denise knew the legal description 
  on the deed included the mobile home and reflected her intent to transfer interest 
  in the mobile home, the record does not reflect that attorney Kline represented 
  Deniseâ€™s interests.Â Â Â  Rather, the record demonstrates that Kline was hired 
  to represent Peggyâ€™s interests and served as Peggyâ€™s legal counsel.Â  
Denise expressed her intent to remain the 
  owner of the mobile home to Kline and testified that she thought her mother 
  was borrowing money on the land.Â  Thus, we find Denise did not intend to secure 
  Peggyâ€™s debt with her mobile home and as a result, the equitable mortgage was 
  properly limited to the real estate.Â  
Additionally, we find the mobile home 
  was not a fixture to the real estate and thus not subject to the equitable mortgage.Â  
  A mobile home is generally classified as personal property, such that a security 
  interest may be perfected by listing the interest on the certificate of title.Â  
  Brockbank v. Best Capital Corp., 341 S.C. 372, 379, 534 S.E.2d 688, 692 (2000).Â  
  However, a mobile home may cease being personal property by annexation to real 
  estate and may be sold with the real estate.Â  Id.Â Â  In such a case, the 
  mobile home is considered a fixture and may be subject to any mortgage on the 
  real estate.Â Â  See In re Rebel Mfg. And Mktg. Corp., 54 B.R. 674 
  (Bankr. D.S.C. 1985); Gilbert v. Easterling, 217 S.C. 267, Â­Â­275, 60 
  S.E.2d 595, 597 (1950).Â  
 A mobile home does not become a fixture 
  by mere affixation to realty.Â  City of North Charleston v. Claxton, 315 
  S.C. 56, 62-63, 431 S.E.2d 610, 614 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  â€œCriteria for determining 
  whether personalty becomes a fixture when affixed to realty includes: (1) the 
  mode of attachment; (2) the character of the structure of the article; (3) the 
  intent of parties making the annexation; and (4) the relationship of the parties.â€Â  
  Id.Â  
In this case, the relationship of the 
  parties is clear: Peggy and Denise are mother and daughter and the Bank is the 
  lender.Â  With respect to the mode of attachment and the character of the structure, 
  Denise testified that the mobile home is a rectangular doublewide, set up in 
  two sections and fastened together.Â  She stated:Â  â€œThe tires donâ€™t come with 
  it, but itâ€™s all set up where they just put the tires back under it.Â  I mean, 
  itâ€™s movable.â€ Denise further explained:Â  â€œThe tongue is laying right up under 
  it.Â  All it takes is bolts to put it up.â€Â  
At issue is the intent of the parties 
  making the annexation.Â  There is evidence that Peggy and the Bank intended the 
  mobile home to be a fixture.Â  Peggy signed a deed and mortgage containing a 
  legal description stating that it was the borrowerâ€™s intent to treat the mobile 
  home as a fixture and part of the real estate.Â  In addition, Peggy signed an 
  affidavit stating that the mobile home was permanently affixed to the real estate 
  and a rider in which she promised that the mobile home would be permanently 
  affixed.Â  Furthermore, she purported to grant the Bank a security interest in 
  the mobile home.Â  
At most, these documents evidence 
  Peggyâ€™s and the Bankâ€™s intention to treat the mobile home as a fixture but do 
  not suggest Denise, as rightful owner of the mobile home, had a similar intent.Â  
  Although Denise signed the deed, she did not initial the legal description, 
  which stated that the transfer included all improvements and that the borrower 
  intended to treat the mobile home as a fixture.Â  Nothing in the legal description 
  suggests Denise intended to treat the mobile home as a fixture.Â Â  
Moreover, we decline to give substantial 
  weight to the documents considering the circumstances under which they were 
  signed. [3] Â  Peggy explained that the Bank 
  contacted her and offered her a loan.Â  She stated that she was seventy years 
  old, did not necessarily understand what she was signing, did not finish the 
  ninth grade, and was in poor health.Â  Peggyâ€™s attorney was chosen by the lender, 
  did not leave copies of the documents with Peggy, failed to have the documents 
  properly witnessed, and was hired to represent the interests of Peggy and not 
  Denise.Â  Neither Peggy nor Denise signed or initialed the legal description, 
  which purported to include the mobile home in the deed and mortgage and purported 
  to state Peggyâ€™s intent to treat the mobile home as a fixture.
Peggy testified that she believed that 
  the land and the mobile home belonged to her daughter, Denise, but represented 
  that she knew she was signing the papers in order to have the â€œtrailer refinanced.â€Â  
  Denise, on the other hand, never intended to for her mother to secure the loan 
  with the mobile home or forfeit ownership of the home.Â  
Based on these facts, we find 
  the mobile home did not become a fixture by its mere annexation to the real 
  estate subject to the equitable mortgage.Â  Rather, the evidence suggests that 
  the mobile home was readily movable and the parties did not intend to permanently 
  annex the home to the real estate.Â  As a result, the master did not err in concluding 
  that the mobile home was not a fixture and not subject to the equitable mortgage.
Finally, the Bank argues the master erred 
  in finding it was estopped from including the mobile home in the mortgage because 
  the deed failed to transfer title to the mobile home to Peggy.Â Â  The Bank asserts 
  that the statutes setting forth the procedure for transferring a mobile home 
  in addition to real estate were not in effect at the time the deed was executed 
  and therefore not applicable to the transaction.Â  This argument was never raised 
  to or ruled upon by the master-in-equity, and is not preserved for our review.Â  
  See Holy Loch Distrib., Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 24, 531 
  S.E.2d 282, 284 (2000).Â  Furthermore, the masterâ€™s order did not find that the 
  Bank was estopped from including the mobile home in the mortgage.Â  Rather, the 
  order determined that the mobile home was not permanently affixed to the property, 
  was not contemplated in the loan, was not transferred by deed to Peggy, and 
  was not subject to the lien because the Bank failed to perfect by listing the 
  interest on the certificate of title.Â  Therefore, we decline to address this 
  issue on appeal. 
CONCLUSION
Because we find the master correctly 
  concluded that the mobile home was not a fixture and not subject to the equitable 
  mortgage, the order of the master-in-equity is hereby 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.       

 
   
    [1]  The partiesâ€™ briefs clarify that Denise and Peggy owned the real 
    estate as tenants in common.Â  The description of the real estate attached 
    to the mortgage and deed explains that it was conveyed to Peggy and Denise 
    by deed in November of 1998.Â  Peggy testified that the property was her daughterâ€™s 
    property, but â€œ[i]t ended up in my name somehow.â€Â  The final order describes 
    Deniseâ€™s interest as an â€œundivided one-half (1/2) interest.â€Â  

 
   [2]  Approved Federal Savings Bank subsequently assigned 
    the note and mortgage to Appellant, Wells Fargo Bank Minnesota.Â  

 
   
    [3]  The Bank seems to argue, pursuant to the parol evidence rule, that 
    we are bound to consider only the documents as evidence of the partiesâ€™ intent.Â  
    However, the parol evidence rule only applies to the construction of written 
    agreements.Â  See Redwend Ltd. Partnership v. Edwards,  
    354 S.C. 459, 471, 581 S.E.2d 496, 502 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œThe parol evidence 
    rule prevents the introduction of extrinsic evidence of agreements or understandings 
    contemporaneous with or prior to execution of a written instrument when the 
    extrinsic evidence is to be used to contradict, vary, or explain the written 
    instrument.â€).Â  In this case, we are not construing a written agreement, but 
    determining the extent of an equitable mortgage and fashioning a remedy in 
    equity.Â  Thus, we are not bound by the parole evidence rule.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Keisha Norris,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Allstate Insurance Company,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-124
Heard January 12, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  17, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Andrew N. Poliakoff, of Spartanburg, and M. Celia Robinson, 
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
W. Francis Marion, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.: Â Keisha Norris, sister 
  of the deceased, Tony Woodward, appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment 
  to Allstate Insurance Company from an action for declaratory judgment as to 
  whether Allstate provided insurance coverage for a shooting incident resulting 
  in Tony Woodwardâ€™s death.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In June 1999, Ricky Hull, a passenger 
  in an automobile operated by Roshaun Hall, shot and killed Tony Woodward, a 
  pedestrian walking down a street in Spartanburg County.Â  The vehicle driven 
  by Roshaun Hall was insured by Allstate Insurance Company.Â  Ricky Hull subsequently 
  pled guilty to murder, while Hall pled guilty to assault with intent to kill.Â  

Norris, Woodwardâ€™s sister, brought this 
  declaratory judgment action to determine whether the Allstate policy on Hallâ€™s 
  vehicle covered the incident.Â  Both parties filed motions for summary judgment.Â  
  The trial court, relying on State Farm Mut. Auto Ins. Co. v. Bookert, 
  337 S.C. 291, 523 S.E.2d 181 (1999), granted Allstateâ€™s motion for summary judgment 
  finding the incident was not â€œforeseeably identifiable with the normal use of 
  an automobile.â€Â  The court further found the insuring language in the policy 
  that included â€œloading or unloadingâ€ of the insured vehicle did not apply to 
  provide coverage as there was no evidence an accident occurred when the vehicle 
  was being loaded or unloaded.Â  The trial court subsequently denied Norrisâ€™ motion 
  for reconsideration.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS


 Norris argues Woodwardâ€™s 
  injuries were sustained while the insured vehicle was being put to the normal 
  and foreseeable use of transportation, and the vehicle was an active accessory 
  to the injuries such that coverage from the policy applies under South Carolina 
  law.Â  We disagree.
This case is controlled 
  by our Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Bookert, 
  337 S.C. 291, 523 S.E.2d 181 (1999).Â  In reversing this courtâ€™s decision finding 
  coverage, the Supreme Court in Bookert determined injuries to Bookertâ€™s 
  son were not â€œforeseeably identifiable with the normal use of an automobileâ€ 
  where the assailant shot Bookertâ€™s son from an automobile as her son was about 
  to enter a restaurant.Â  The Supreme Court noted the following stipulated facts 
  in Bookert:

Maryâ€™s son, respondent Michael 
  Bookert, is an insured under Maryâ€™s policy.Â  Michael and some friends stopped 
  at a Hardeeâ€™s, where two soldiers and about fifteen other young men became involved 
  in an altercation.Â  Michael and his friends left and went to a McDonaldâ€™s, as 
  did some of the fifteen men from Hardeeâ€™s.Â  The two soldiers, who were armed, 
  picked up a third soldier and drove to the McDonaldâ€™s where they circled the 
  parking lot, looking for the Hardeeâ€™s men.Â  As Michael was about to go in the 
  restaurant, he heard the soldiers yelling, and turned in their direction.Â  The 
  soldiersâ€™ vehicle was stopped in the traffic lane with its motor running, one 
  soldier in the back holding a shotgun while the front passenger brandished a 
  handgun.Â  The vehicle jerked forward, the soldier wielding the shotgun fell, 
  and fired his gun.Â  Michael was not hit by the shotgun pellets, but while the 
  vehicle was still moving forward, the passenger fired the handgun striking Michael 
  with a bullet in each leg.

Id. at 292-93, 523 S.E.2d 
  at 181-82.Â  
Norris attempts to distinguish 
  Bookert from the facts of this case asserting that in Bookert, 
  the car was stopped with its engine running and the only movement of the vehicle 
  came when the car â€œjerkedâ€ at which point shots were fired.Â  Thus, Norris contends 
  the transportation requirement was not met in Bookert, accounting for 
  the courtâ€™s determination that there was no coverage.Â  We first note that the 
  Supreme Court did not rely on the transportation requirement in Bookert, 
  but instead relied on the foreseeability factor in denying coverage.Â  At any 
  rate, the stipulated facts in Bookert do not indicate the vehicle was 
  stopped when Bookertâ€™s son was shot.Â  To the contrary, the court clearly stated 
  Bookertâ€™s son was shot â€œwhile the vehicle was still moving forward.â€Â  Because 
  we can discern no material distinction from the facts at hand and the facts 
  in the Bookert case, we find no error in the trial judgeâ€™s determination 
  there was no coverage because the incident was not â€œforeseeably identifiable 
  with the normal use of an automobile.â€
Norris also claims that the trial court erred in 
  granting summary judgment because the policy in question covered â€œloading and 
  unloadingâ€ of a vehicle, thereby expanding the coverage to include the negligent 
  loading of dangerous passengers.Â  We disagree.
The Allstate policy provides coverage for â€œclaims 
  for accidents arising out of the ownership, maintenance or use, loading or unloading 
  of an insured auto.â€Â  Norris argues that Hall was negligent or reckless in â€œloadingâ€ 
  Hull as a passenger when he had knowledge that Hull had dangerous propensities 
  and the trial court therefore erred in granting summary judgment to Allstate.Â  
  We refuse to accept this illogical construction.Â  Woodward was not injured by 
  any activity that occurred during the actual loading or unloading of Hull, nor 
  was he injured as a result of any activity necessary or integral to the loading 
  or unloading of Hull.Â  See Home Indem. Co. v. Harleysville Mut. Ins. 
  Co., 252 S.C. 452, 457, 166 S.E.2d 819, 822 (1969) (where a policy includes 
  a loading and unloading provision, the â€œcomplete operationâ€ doctrine provides 
  the test to determine whether unloading has commenced is whether the acts in 
  progress at the time of the accident were necessary and integral to the movement 
  of goods from the vehicle, whether they would have occurred but for the need 
  to move the goods, and whether they were closely related in time and space to 
  the actual movement of goods from the vehicle).Â  Further, even though the â€œloading 
  and unloadingâ€ provision is an expansion of coverage, coverage is still only 
  expanded to â€œclaims for accidents arising out of . . . loading or unloading 
  of an insured auto.â€Â  Such a negligent loading theory as advocated by Norris 
  â€œgloss[es] over the critical causal relation test.â€Â  Nationwide Mut. Ins. 
  Co. v. Brown, 779 F.2d 984, 988 (4th Cir. 1985).Â  The accident 
  upon which insurance coverage is claimed must bear a causal relation or connection 
  with the loading or unloading of the insured automobile.Â  Here, there simply 
  is no such connection.
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the trial 
  court granting summary judgment to Allstate is 
AFFIRMED.
CURETON, AJ., concurs.
BEATTY, J.:Â  Although I agree with the majorityâ€™s 
  finding that we are bound by the holding in State Farm Mutual Auto Insurance 
  v. Bookert, 337 S.C. 291, 523 S.E.2d 181 (1999), I write separately to express 
  some concerns regarding the similarities in this case to valid prior caselaw.
In Wausau Underwriters Insurance Company 
  v. Howser, 309 S.C. 269, 422 S.E.2d 106 (1992), the victimâ€™s car was bumped 
  and she was eventually shot by an unknown driver of another car.Â  In answering 
  a question certified from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth 
  Circuit, our state supreme court found a causal connection, holding the victimâ€™s 
  injuries arose out of the use of the assailantâ€™s vehicle:Â  â€œOnly through use 
  of his vehicle was the assailant able to closely pursue Howser, thereby enabling 
  him to carry out the pistol assault.Â  The gunshot was the culmination of an 
  ongoing assault, in which the vehicle played an essential and integral part.â€Â  
  Howser, 309 S.C. at 273, 422 S.E.2d at 108.
Our state supreme court similarly found 
  a causal connection in Home Insurance Company v. Towe, 314 S.C. 105, 
  441 S.C.2d 825 (1994).Â  In that case, the passenger in Toweâ€™s moving car threw 
  a bottle at a road sign and inadvertently struck the victim on his tractor.Â  
  Our state supreme court determined there was a causal connection between the 
  use of Toweâ€™s automobile and the victimâ€™s injuries:Â  â€œThe use of the automobile 
  placed Alexander in the position to throw the bottle at the sign and the vehicleâ€™s 
  speed contributed to the velocity of the bottle increasing the seriousness of 
  McCaskeyâ€™s injuries.â€Â  Towe, 314 S.C. at 107, 441 S.E.2d at 827.
I am unable to distinguish the facts of 
  the present case from Howser and Towe.Â  The victim in the present 
  case was pursued and shot by assailants in a moving vehicle.Â  The vehicle played 
  an â€œessential and integral partâ€ of the assault, allowing the assailants to 
  closely pursue the victim.Â  I find Bookert to be in conflict with Howser 
  and Towe.Â  Absent Bookert, I would be inclined to find there was 
  a â€œcausal connectionâ€ between the use of the vehicle and the shooting of the 
  victim because the use of the vehicle played such an integral role in this case.Â  
  The Bookert court found that the gun shot injuries were not foreseeably 
  identifiable with the normal use of the vehicle.Â  Bookert, 337 S.C. at 
  293, 523 S.E.2d at 182.Â  Since the decision in Bookert (1999), it is 
  arguable that drive-by shootings are foreseeably identifiable with the normal 
  use of a vehicle. [1] Â  The use 
  of a motor vehicle is a necessary part of a drive-by shooting.
Until our Supreme Court overrules Howser, 
  we must assume that the fact that an assailant fired a gun from an automobile 
  does not automatically defeat coverage by the automobileâ€™s insurer.Â  Although 
  it is certainly arguable that today, drive-by shootings are foreseeably identifiable 
  with the normal use of an automobile, I nevertheless believe this court is bound 
  by the finding in Bookert of no causal connection.Â  Accordingly, I concur.

 
   
    [1]  According to unofficial data from SLED, drive by shootings in South 
    Carolina have increased from 2 in 1999 to 41 in 2003 (the latest figures available).

THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY 
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
John May,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Nancy Hopson,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Terry A. Finger, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-125
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  17, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James D. Donohoe, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.Â  
No appearance by or for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  John May appeals the order 
  of the special referee, arguing he erred in dismissing Mayâ€™s breach of contract 
  action and his quantum meruit and negligence claims.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
May, an interior decorator, 
  and Nancy Hopson entered into a series of three separate oral agreements in 
  connection with the decoration of Hopsonâ€™s new house.Â  Under the terms of their 
  first agreement, Hopson agreed to pay May $75 per hour plus a 15% commission 
  on the purchase price of furniture and art he selected.Â  Hopson paid the only 
  two invoices May submitted, which totaled $3200.Â  
The parties then entered 
  into a second oral agreement whereby May continued decorating Hopsonâ€™s house 
  at no charge and, in turn, Hopson agreed to allow May to utilize her house as 
  a showcase for his prospective clients.Â  Pursuant to their agreement, Hopson 
  also provided May with office space and administrative support for his decorating 
  business, at no charge.Â  This second agreement did not include a fee arrangement, 
  and May made no demands for payment for his continued services as Hopsonâ€™s personal 
  decorator.Â  
Finally, the parties entered 
  into a third oral agreement to jointly provide decoration and design services 
  for a model home built by a third party.Â  Under the terms of this agreement, 
  May and Hopson would share equally in both the cost of purchasing furniture 
  and accessories, and in any profits realized upon a sale.Â  When the furniture 
  and accessories failed to sell, disputes arose between the parties concerning 
  who was responsible financially.Â  Eventually, Hopson removed furniture and accessories 
  from the model house.Â  May demanded Hopson return the items to him and pay him 
  an additional $93,000 in compensation and unpaid commissions for design work 
  he allegedly performed on her home pursuant to the first agreement.Â  Hopson 
  refused.
May sued, alleging breach 
  of contract, quantum meruit, and conversion, and the case was referred to a 
  special referee.Â  May amended his complaint to allege breach of contract, breach 
  of contract accompanied by fraudulent acts, unjust enrichment, and negligence.Â  
  Hopson answered and counterclaimed for breach of the partnership agreement and 
  unjust enrichment.Â  
The parties agreed to reserve 
  Mayâ€™s negligence cause of action until Hopsonâ€™s counsel could determine whether 
  her homeownerâ€™s insurance would pay for repairs.Â  If the claims remained unresolved 
  after 90 days, the referee announced he would hold a separate hearing on the 
  issue of Hopsonâ€™s alleged negligent care of the furniture.Â  Consequently, no 
  testimony on this issue was taken at trial.Â  At the close of Mayâ€™s case, the 
  referee directed a verdict for Hobson on Mayâ€™s claim for breach of contract 
  accompanied by a fraudulent act.Â  In the final order, the referee dismissed 
  Mayâ€™s remaining causes of action, including his negligence claim.Â  The referee 
  also dismissed Hopsonâ€™s counterclaims, deeming them abandoned.Â  
May filed a motion to amend, 
  arguing the referee improperly dismissed his negligence cause of action after 
  expressly reserving the issue at trial for later determination, and requested 
  the case be reopened to allow testimony on his claim.Â  In his amended order, 
  the referee agreed the negligence claim should not have been dismissed and deleted 
  the portion of his order dismissing that claim.Â  
DISCUSSION
 May contends 
  the special referee erred in dismissing his breach of contract claim, arguing 
  the referee relied on inadmissible hearsay as the sole basis of determining 
  the partiesâ€™ relative contributions to partnership debts.Â  We disagree.
May misapprehends 
  the essential nature of the refereeâ€™s report.Â  Although billed as an action 
  in quantum meruit, the issue before the court was closely akin to an accounting 
  of a partnership, and the referee hinged his final ruling on the factual finding, 
  â€œHopson fully accounted for and showed the expenditures on Agreement No. 3 were 
  equal and that neither party was owed any money by the other.â€Â  The referee 
  further found that Agreement No. 2 superseded Agreement No. 1, and that both 
  parties fulfilled their obligations under both agreements Nos. 1 and 2.Â  These 
  rulings have not been appealed, and they are therefore the law of the case.Â  
  Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 
  S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (stating an unappealed ruling is the law of the case.).Â  

As a consequence, the only 
  issue remaining before the special referee, and before us on this appeal, is 
  the dispute between the parties as to their financial responsibility under Agreement 
  No. 3.Â  In making his finding that the expenditures pursuant to Agreement No. 
  3 were equal, the special referee referenced an exhibit he had previously ruled 
  could only be marked for identification and not considered as evidence. [2] Â  Although the referee improperly 
  referenced an exhibit not in evidence, his mistake is not fatal to his finding 
  that Hopson fulfilled her obligations under the partnership agreement.Â  Hopson 
  testified the excluded document was merely an itemized summary of figures she 
  supplied to her accountant drawn from her own records and personal knowledge.Â  
  She also testified to the accuracy and proper allocation of the amounts summarized.Â  
  Moreover, based on her testimony of the expenses she paid, the special referee 
  could conclude Hopson contributed at least 50% of the cost of furniture purchased 
  for the model home project.Â  Accordingly, we find there is ample evidence contained 
  in Hopsonâ€™s testimony to support a finding she contributed an equal if not greater 
  share toward satisfying partnership debt.Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 
  301 S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1989) (stating that in an action in 
  equity tried by the judge alone, this court can make findings of facts in accordance 
  with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  However, this does 
  not require us to ignore the fact that the special referee was in a better position 
  to assess the credibility of the witnesses.).
Next, May contends the special 
  referee erred in dismissing his quantum meruit claim, arguing Hopson has been 
  unjustly enriched because she has not sufficiently compensated him for decorating 
  and design services he undertook at her house.Â  May urges the $3200 he received, 
  based on his own submitted invoices, under the partiesâ€™ first agreement and 
  the rent-free office space and administrative services he received under the 
  second agreement are grossly inadequate compensation.Â  He now insists the invoices 
  he submitted covered only an initial 40 hours of work at Hopsonâ€™s house and 
  that he is owed for thousands of subsequent man hours and a 15% commission on 
  nearly a quarter of a million dollars in furniture and art acquisitions for 
  her residence.Â  We disagree.
Only under the terms of 
  the defunct first agreement was May entitled to hourly fees and commissions 
  on purchases and improvements for Hopsonâ€™s home.Â  The refereeâ€™s unappealed finding 
  that neither party had any further obligation to the other under Agreement No. 
  1 disposes of any contention May is entitled to further compensation therefor.Â  

Finally, May requests that 
  we remand the issue of the negligence cause of action with instructions to the 
  referee to hold a hearing and render a decision on this issue.Â  We find it unnecessary 
  to remand for that purpose.
It was agreed between the 
  parties that any negligence claim would be bifurcated, and the dismissal of 
  that claim in the original order was clearly an oversight that was corrected 
  pursuant to the motion for reconsideration.Â  Therefore, that issue is not a 
  subject of this appeal and may be set for a hearing upon the request of either 
  party.Â  See Rule 205, SCACR (â€œNothing in these Rules shall prohibit the 
  lower court, commission or other tribunal from proceeding with matters not affected 
  by the appeal.â€).Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The exhibit, referred to in the final order as â€œDefendantâ€™s 
    Exhibit #15,â€ is a summary of expenses incurred and payments made by both 
    parties for furnishings purchased for the model home.Â  It was prepared by 
    Hopsonâ€™s accountant, at her direction, and based solely upon information she 
    provided.Â  At trial, the referee sustained Mayâ€™s objection to the introduction 
    of the exhibit.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Robbie Milton,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Glen F. Strickland, MD, James D. Givens, MD, and Southern Surgical Group,
LLC,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-126
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  17, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
S. Jahue Moore, of West Columbia, for Appellants.
Michael Parham and William L. Dodson, Jr., both of Greenville, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this medical malpractice 
  action, the trial court granted Robbie Miltonâ€™s motion for voluntary dismissal 
  without prejudice.Â  Doctors Glen F. Strickland and James D. Givens, and their 
  surgical group, Southern Surgical Group, LLC, (collectively â€œDefendantsâ€) appeal, 
  arguing the dismissal causes them legal prejudice and is against public policy.Â  
  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
In August 2003, Milton filed a 
  complaint against Defendants in Lexington County, alleging medical malpractice.Â  
  In paragraph two of the complaint, Milton stated that â€œ[u]pon information and 
  belief, these Defendants are citizens and residents of the County of Lexington, 
  State of South Carolina.â€ In Defendantsâ€™ answer, they admitted the allegations 
  set forth in paragraph two of Miltonâ€™s complaint.Â  Because all Defendants resided 
  in Lexington County when this action commenced, South Carolinaâ€™s general venue 
  statute required Milton to bring suit there.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-30 (1976).
Simultaneous to serving the complaint 
  on Defendants, Milton also served upon them a series of written interrogatories.Â  
  In response to the interrogatories, Defendants submitted Dr. Stricklandâ€™s Curriculum 
  Vitae.Â  On his Curriculum Vitae, Dr. Stricklandâ€™s home address and 
  his childrenâ€™s names were blacked out.Â  The blacking out of Dr. Stricklandâ€™s 
  address piqued Miltonâ€™s interest, and he hired a private investigator to explore 
  the issue of Dr. Stricklandâ€™s residence.Â  After reviewing tax, driverâ€™s license, 
  and voter registration records, the private investigator filed an affidavit 
  with the court, which indicated that Dr. Strickland was actually a resident 
  of Richland County, South Carolina when the medical malpractice action was commenced.
Once this information was discovered, Milton moved 
  for a voluntary dismissal without prejudice pursuant to Rule 41(a)(2), SCRCP, 
  so that he could re-file his claim in Richland County.Â  The trial court granted 
  Miltonâ€™s motion, and this appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A plaintiff is ordinarily entitled to 
  a voluntary non-suit without prejudice as a matter of right unless the defendant 
  shows legal prejudice or important issues of public policy are present.Â  Burry 
  & Son Homebuilder, Inc. v. Ford, 310 S.C. 529, 531, 426 S.E.2d 313, 
  314 (1992).Â  â€œOnce legal prejudice is found, the granting or denial is within 
  the discretion of the trial court.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Defendants first argue the trial court abused its 
  discretion because it granted Miltonâ€™s motion for voluntary dismissal without 
  prejudice based on a mistaken belief that every plaintiff has an absolute right 
  to one voluntary dismissal.Â  Defendants argue that because the trial court failed 
  to consider whether legal prejudice would result or whether public policy concerns 
  would be implicated, the court committed reversible error.Â  We disagree.
To support their argument, Defendants 
  quote from the transcript of the hearing in which the trial court orally ruled 
  that â€œthe law is clear.Â  To me.Â  As I understand . . . I always give them one 
  bite at the apple.Â  Which I think 41(a)(2) gives them . . . .â€Â  While this isolated 
  statement might suggest the trial court did not consider whether the voluntary 
  dismissal would contravene public policy or whether it would cause legal prejudice 
  to Defendants, the transcript as a whole belies that implication.Â  Both attorneys 
  discussed the proper standard in their presentations to the trial court, and 
  the trial court even took a moment to read a case presented by the Defendantsâ€™ 
  attorney.Â  
More importantly, the trial courtâ€™s written order 
  specifically acknowledges that â€œ[a] plaintiff generally has the right to voluntarily 
  dismiss his claim without prejudice absent some â€˜legalâ€™ prejudice demonstrated 
  by the Defendant or some public policy issue of great import.â€Â  It is well-settled 
  that no order is final until it is written and entered.Â  Rule 58(a), SCRCP; 
  see also First Union Natâ€™l Bank of S.C. v. Hitman, Inc., 308 S.C. 
  421, 422, 418 S.E.2d 545, 545 (1992) (â€œ[A] judge is not bound by the prior oral 
  ruling and may issue a written order which is in conflict with the oral ruling.â€).Â  
  Thus, we find the trial court considered the correct standard when it granted 
  Miltonâ€™s motion to voluntarily dismiss his claim without prejudice.
Next, Defendants argue the trial court erred in 
  granting Miltonâ€™s motion for a voluntary dismissal without prejudice because 
  they demonstrated that such a dismissal would legally prejudice them and would 
  contravene public policy.Â  Specifically, Defendants argue that once venue was 
  laid in Lexington County, it cannot be moved to Richland County without depriving 
  Dr. Givensâ€™ of his substantial right to defend the action in the county of his 
  residence.Â  Defendants further argue that because Milton seeks a dismissal so 
  he can re-file in Richland County, Milton is forum-shopping, a practice that 
  is repugnant to the public policy of South Carolina.Â Â Â  We disagree.
Defendants argue the case of Â  Burry 
  & Son Homebuilder, Inc. v. Ford, 310 S.C. 529, 531, 426 S.E.2d 313, 
  314 (1992), supports their argument that once venue was established in Lexington 
  County, dismissal for the purpose of allowing Milton to re-file in Richland 
  would amount to legal prejudice for Dr. Givens.Â  We do not believe the law set 
  forth in Burry is applicable to the factual circumstances of this case.
In Burry, a homebuilder filed a 
  complaint against a homeowner for breach of contract.Â  The homeowner answered, 
  arguing that the homebuilder was not entitled to enforce the contract because 
  he was not a licensed residential builder.Â  Thereafter, the homeowner sought 
  to amend his answer to assert a counterclaim for damages resulting from the 
  homebuilderâ€™s defective workmanship.Â  The homeowner also moved for summary judgment.Â  
  In support of his motion, the homeowner submitted an affidavit from an investigator 
  for the South Carolina Residential Buildersâ€™ Commission who confirmed the homebuilder 
  was not licensed.Â  In response, the homebuilder filed a motion for a voluntary 
  dismissal without prejudice.Â  Id. at 530, 426 S.E.2d at 314.Â  The trial 
  court denied the homebuilderâ€™s motion for voluntary dismissal, finding that 
  legal prejudice would result if the homeowner had to bring his counterclaim 
  to the county of the homebuilderâ€™s residence.Â  Id. at 531, 426 S.E.2d 
  at 314.Â  On appeal, the supreme court affirmed, finding â€œthe loss of proper 
  venue in oneâ€™s county of residence suffices to establish legal prejudice.â€Â Â  
  Id.
Unlike the Burry case, there are 
  multiple defendants in this case.Â  Here, even assuming some degree of legal 
  prejudice would result from Dr. Givensâ€™ losing his ability to defend himself 
  in the county in which he resides, such prejudice would be offset by the opportunity 
  Dr. Strickland is afforded now that he is able to defend himself in his county 
  of residence.Â  Furthermore, the case before us does not involve a counterclaim.Â  
  Thus, there is no danger that Defendants will lose their right to bring a counterclaim 
  in their county of residence as was the concern in Burry.Â Â  
Furthermore, we agree with the trial court 
  that this action is in an early enough stage of litigation that dismissing the 
  case would not cause legal prejudice to Defendants. Â At this point, only minimal 
  discovery has been exchanged and no depositions have been taken. Â Cf. 
  Crout v. S.C. Natâ€™l Bank, 278 S.C. 120, 293 S.E.2d 422 (1982) (finding 
  legal prejudice when the plaintiffâ€™s motion for voluntary dismissal was announced 
  only five days before trial and plaintiff had no compelling reason for making 
  the motion).Â  Moreover, to the extent that the passage of time might affect 
  legal prejudice, we note that if Defendants had not admitted in their answer 
  that Dr. Strickland lived in Lexington County, Milton could have immediately 
  sought to have the case voluntarily dismissed or to have venue changed.Â  Likewise, 
  if the city and state of Dr. Stricklandâ€™s residence had not been blacked out 
  on his Curriculum Vitae, Milton could have taken immediate action.Â  Instead, 
  months had to pass for Milton to hire an investigator and discover Dr. Stricklandâ€™s 
  true county of residence.Â  While the Defendantsâ€™ errors may have been innocent, 
  their mistakes did extend the time between Miltonâ€™s complaint and his motion 
  for voluntary dismissal. 
 Furthermore, under the circumstances of 
  this case, we disagree with Defendantsâ€™ argument that allowing Milton to re-file 
  in Richland County would condone forum shopping.Â  This is not a situation where 
  Milton is attempting to join a sham defendant for the sheer purpose of acquiring 
  a more plaintiff-friendly venue.Â  Rather, Milton is merely attempting to file 
  his medical malpractice action in a county in which he could have filed had 
  he known from the outset where Dr. Strickland lived.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 15-7-30 (1976) (setting forth the rule that certain actions, such as medical 
  malpractice, â€œshall be tried in the county in which the defendant resides at 
  the time of the commencement of the action,â€ and â€œ[i]f there be more than one 
  defendant then the action may be tried in any county in which one or more of 
  the defendants to such action resides at the time of the commencement of the 
  actionâ€).Â  
 Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s grant of 
  Miltonâ€™s motion for a voluntary dismissal without prejudice is 
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

Brandy Lynn Kline Pickelsimer,

Appeal From York County
Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-127
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of

Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy

  W. Elliott, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Brandy Lynn Kline Pickelsimer 
  pled guilty to possession of crack cocaine, possession of a Schedule IV controlled 
  substance with intent to distribute, and trafficking in cocaine.Â  Pickelsimer 
  argues on appeal that her guilty plea did not comply with the mandates set forth 
  in Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969).Â  Her appellate attorney attached 
  to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel, stating she reviewed 
  the record and concluded Pickelsimerâ€™s appeal is without merit.Â  Pickelsimer 
  did not file a pro se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record 
  pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. 
  Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal and 
  grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
 APPEAL DISMISSED. 
  [1] 
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD 
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Discount Auto Center,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Nancy D. Jonas,       
Appellant
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-128
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  18, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Nancy D. Jonas, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
James A. Grimsley, III and Ralph E. Tupper, both of Beaufort, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Nancy Jonas appeals 
  a circuit order denying her motion to dismiss.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
In January 2003, Jonas filed a motion 
  to dismiss in the Beaufort County Circuit Court, apparently with the intention 
  of having a judgment entered against her in 1996 dismissed.Â  A hearing on the 
  motion was scheduled for 10 a.m. on September 15, 2003.Â  Jonas was advised of 
  the date and time of the hearing, and informed the court that she was ready 
  to proceed.
The hearing was called at the scheduled 
  time, but Jonas was not present.Â  The court placed a call to her residence and, 
  after failing to reach her, left a message reminding her of the hearing.Â  As 
  of 10:30 a.m., Jonas had still not appeared.Â  The circuit court denied the motion 
  for lack of prosecution and ordered the â€œcase ended.â€
After contact from Jonas later that afternoon, 
  the circuit court allowed her to file a motion to reconsider the denial of her 
  motion.Â  Following reconsideration, the circuit court again denied Jonasâ€™s motion 
  to dismiss.Â  This appeal followed.
ANALYSIS
Jonas argues the trial court erred 
  in denying her motion due to, among other things, a vast conspiracy of corruption 
  and collusion involving this stateâ€™s circuit and appellate courts and Discount 
  Auto Center.Â  We disagree.
As Jonasâ€™s present appeal and underlying 
  motion attempt to retry issues previously resolved and not properly before the 
  circuit court, we briefly re-cap this caseâ€™s procedural history.Â  In 1996, Discount 
  Auto Center obtained a judgment against Jonas in magistrateâ€™s court for nonpayment 
  of a bill arising from work done to her vehicle.Â  In 1997, Jonas appealed the 
  judgment to the circuit court, which affirmed the magistrateâ€™s decision.Â  She 
  then appealed the circuit courtâ€™s decision to this court.Â  Her appeal was dismissed 
  as untimely.Â  This court did, however, grant Jonas leave to petition the trial 
  court for relief from judgment pursuant to Rule 60, SCRCP.Â  Jonas filed this 
  motion in the magistrateâ€™s court, but specifically requested in the petition 
  that the motion not be decided until future matters concerning her appeal were 
  resolved.Â  Following the resolution of various motions regarding her appeal 
  in this court (e.g. a petition to reinstate), a writ of certiorari was filed 
  with the state supreme court.Â  This petition was denied in September 1998.Â  
  Following this courtâ€™s issuance of remittitur, Jonas filed a motion in the state 
  supreme court to recall the remittitur.Â  This motion was likewise denied.Â  She 
  then appealed to the United States Supreme Court, which finally dismissed her 
  case on December 3, 1999.
More than three years after the United 
  States Supreme Court dismissed her appeal, Jonas filed the present motion, styled 
  oddly as a â€œmotion to dismiss.â€Â  Nevertheless, a hearing was scheduled on the 
  matter.Â  Jonas was properly notified, but did not appear for the hearing.
A trial judge possesses the inherent power 
  to dismiss actions sua sponte for a partyâ€™s failure to prosecute 
  with due diligence.Â  Crestwood Golf Club, Inc. v. Potter, 328 S.C. 201, 
  211-212, 493 S.E.2d 826, 832 (1997); Small v. Mungo, 254 S.C. 438, 442-443, 
  175 S.E.2d 802, 803-804 (1970).Â  On appeal, Jonas raises several matters regarding 
  the substance of her long-resolved case, but only addresses her absence from 
  the hearing by vaguely referencing some alleged filings with our stateâ€™s supreme 
  court.Â  The only evidence in the record of any attempted availment of our supreme 
  courtâ€™s original jurisdiction is dated January 1999, more than three years prior 
  to the scheduled hearing.Â  As Jonas is challenging the trial courtâ€™s denial 
  of her motion, she bears the burden on appeal of producing a record sufficient 
  to illustrate the alleged error.Â  See McElveen v. McElveen, 332 
  S.C. 583, 601 n.4, 506 S.E.2d 1, 10 n.4 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œThis court will not 
  consider facts that do not appear in the transcript of record.â€Â  Windham 
  v. Honeycutt, 290 S.C. 60, 64, 348 S.E.2d 185, 187 (Ct. App. 1986). Â 
Because we find no evidence supporting 
  Jonasâ€™s claim that her absence from the hearing was justified, the circuit courtâ€™s 
  denial of her motion to dismiss is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, 
  JJ., concur. 

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  
  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS 
  PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Albert Clay,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Debbie Holmes Strother,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-129
Heard February 8, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  18, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
H. Fred Kuhn, Jr., of Beaufort, for Appellant.
James Arthur Brown, Jr., of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Debbie Strother appeals from 
  a verdict of $9,000 in favor of Albert Clay on his claim for malicious prosecution.Â  
  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the authorities that follow.
As to Issue I regarding the denial of Strotherâ€™s 
  motions for a directed verdict and a judgment notwithstanding the verdict, although 
  we question whether the issue is preserved, we conclude, in any event, that 
  the record supports the trial courtâ€™s ruling:Â  Rule 50(a), SCRCP (â€œA motion 
  for a directed verdict shall state the specific grounds therefor.â€); Rule 50(b), 
  SCRCP (providing a motion for a judgment notwithstanding the verdict should 
  be made in accordance with the grounds of the motion for a directed verdict); 
  Creech v. South Carolina Wildlife & Marine Resources Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 
  24, 34, 491 S.E.2d 571, 576 (1997) (holding issues not raised in a motion for 
  a directed verdict cannot be argued on appeal); Strange v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 314 S.C. 427, 429-30, 445 S.E.2d 439, 
  440 (1994) (â€œIn ruling on motions for directed verdict and JNOV, the trial court 
  is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn 
  therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motions and 
  to deny the motions where either the evidence yields more than one inference 
  or its inference is in doubt.Â  The trial court can only be reversed by this 
  Court when there is no evidence to support the ruling below.â€ (citations omitted)); 
  McKenney v. Jack Eckerd Co., 304 S.C. 21, 22, 402 S.E.2d 887, 888 (1991) 
  (â€œ[W]here an accused establishes that charges were nolle prossed 
  for reasons which imply or are consistent with innocence, an action for malicious 
  prosecution may be maintained.â€); Kinton v. Mobile Home Indus., Inc., 
  274 S.C. 179, 182, 262 S.E.2d 727, 728 (1980) (observing â€œSouth Carolina has 
  long embraced the rule that a true bill of indictment is prima facie evidence 
  of probable cause in an action for malicious prosecution,â€ but noting this presumption 
  may be overcome by sufficient evidence to the contrary).
As to Issue II regarding the cross-examination 
  of Clay about a prior offense, we find no abuse of discretion in this regard:Â  
  Rule 609(a)(1), SCRE (â€œ[E]vidence that a witness other than an accused has been 
  convicted of a crime shall be admitted, subject to Rule 403, if the crime was 
  punishable by death or imprisonment in excess of one year under the law under 
  which the witness was convicted, and evidence that an accused has been convicted 
  of such a crime shall be admitted if the court determines that the probative 
  value of admitting this evidence outweighs its prejudicial effect to the accused[.]â€); 
  Rule 403, SCRE (â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative 
  value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion 
  of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue delay, 
  waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.â€); Gamble 
  v. Intâ€™l Paper Realty Corp., 323 S.C. 367, 373, 474 S.E.2d 438, 441 (1996) 
  (â€œThe admission or exclusion of evidence is a matter within the sound discretion 
  of the trial court and absent clear abuse, will not be disturbed on appeal.â€).
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Starr Gadson, by her Guardian ad Litem Kathy
Gadson,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
ECO Services of South Carolina, Inc. and Joseph Jenkins,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Jasper County
Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-130
Heard January 12, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  18, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN 
  PART


  
    
      
Deborah H. Sheffield, of Charleston, for Primary Appellant.
Joseph R. Weston, of Mt. Pleasant, for Secondary Appellant.
Daniel E. Henderson, of Ridgeland, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  ECO Services of South Carolina, 
  Inc. (ECO) and Joseph Jenkins, appeal from jury verdicts against them on Starr 
  Gadsonâ€™s claims for negligent entrustment.Â  We affirm as to Jenkins and reverse 
  as to ECO.Â  
FACTS
Jenkins worked for ECO, solid waste contractor 
  that services Beaufort, Jasper, and Hampton counties.Â  As a â€œhelper,â€ Jenkins 
  used ECOâ€™s trucks to go back for missed pickups.Â  On August 6, 1997, Jenkins 
  failed to return ECOâ€™s truck at then end of the day to the Hilton Head office.Â  
  Instead, he drove the truck to Hardeeville.Â  Gadson testified that she saw Jenkins 
  drive the truck to a friendâ€™s house.Â  Jenkinsâ€™s cousin John Jenkins was riding 
  in the front of the truck and Gadsonâ€™s brother and another passenger were riding 
  in the back.Â  Gadsonâ€™s brother climbed out of the truck and went home. Gadson 
  and several other people climbed into the back of the truck and Jenkins drove 
  them to McDonaldâ€™s.Â  After they ate, Jenkins drove them to a store where John 
  bought a cigar and one or two wine coolers, which he shared with another passenger.Â  
  Jenkins then drove them to the Purrysburg Landing, where they talked for about 
  an hour.Â  
When the group started back to Hardeeville, John 
  was driving the truck. [1] Â  He suddenly sped up to around 
  80 miles per hour and then lost control of the vehicle, resulting in the accident.Â  
  Gadson and the other passengers in the back were thrown from the truck.Â  
Gadson, along with others injured in the accident, 
  brought suit alleging negligence and negligent entrustment against ECO, Jenkins, 
  and John. [2] Â  The case was tried to a jury.Â  
  ECO and Jenkins were represented at trial, but Jenkins did not appear.Â  John 
  was not represented and did not appear at trial.Â  The jury returned a general 
  verdict against all three defendants.Â  The jury found, in special interrogatories, 
  as follows:Â  (1)ECO entrusted its vehicle to Jenkins; (2) ECO was negligent 
  in entrusting its vehicle to Jenkins; (3) ECOâ€™s negligence proximately caused 
  the plaintiffsâ€™ injuries; (4) John was the driver of the vehicle; (5) Johnâ€™s 
  negligence proximately caused the plaintiffsâ€™ injuries; (6) Jenkins was not 
  the driver of the vehicle; and (7) Jenkins was negligent in entrusting the vehicle 
  to John.Â  It awarded Gadson $50,000 in actual damages.Â  
ECO and Jenkins both requested and were granted 
  ten days to file post-trial motions.Â  In their motions, ECO and Jenkins asked 
  for JNOV and new trial based on alleged juror misconduct. [3] Â  The trial court initially dismissed both motions 
  finding they were untimely.Â  On remand from this court, the trial court considered 
  both motions on the merits, but denied them.Â  ECO and Jenkins appealed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the denial of a motion 
  for a directed verdict or JNOV, this court uses the same standard as the trial 
  court by viewing the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most 
  favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 299, 
  536 S.E.2d 408, 418 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The motion must be denied when the evidence 
  is susceptible of more than one inference.Â  Id. at 300, 536 S.E.2d at 
  418.Â  Neither this court nor the trial court has authority to decide credibility 
  issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
ECO and Jenkins both argue the 
  trial court erred in denying their motions for directed verdict and JNOV on 
  Gadsonâ€™s claims for negligent entrustment.Â  
â€œThe theory of negligent 
  entrustment provides:Â  â€˜the owner or one in control of the vehicle and responsible 
  for its use who is negligent in entrusting it to another can be held liable 
  for such negligent entrustment.â€™â€ Am. Mut. Fire Ins. Co. v. Passmore, 
  275 S.C. 618, 622, 274 S.E.2d 416, 418 (1981) (quoting 19 A.L.R.3d 1175, 1192).Â  

The Restatement (Second) 
  of Torts Â§ 308 (1965) [4] , provides 
  as follows:

It is negligence to permit a third 
  person to use a thing or to engage in an activity which is under the control 
  of the actor, if the actor knows or should know that such person intends or 
  is likely to use the thing or to conduct himself in the activity in such a manner 
  as to create an unreasonable risk of harm to others.

We will consider Gadsonâ€™s claims 
  against ECO first.Â  
It is undisputed that ECO owned 
  the truck involved in the accident.Â  ECO does dispute that Jenkins had authority 
  to be driving the truck on the night of the accident.Â  Lou Joseph Diaz, general 
  manager for ECO, testified that Jenkins had never taken the truck to Hardeeville 
  after work hours prior to the date of the accident.Â  However, one of the other 
  passengers injured in the truck contradicted this testimony when he said that 
  he had seen Ricky driving the truck around Hardeeville in the evenings for a 
  week before the accident.Â  
Jenkins was suspended twice early 
  in 1997 for unexcused absences from work.Â  Additionally, a note in Jenkinsâ€™s 
  personnel file indicated that Jenkins was terminated for unauthorized use of 
  a company vehicle on July 11, 1997â€”three weeks before the accident occurred.Â  
  When confronted, Diaz testified that the date on the note was probably a typographical 
  error by the personnel office in Charleston.Â  He further testified that the 
  note was probably intended to reflect that Jenkins was fired on August 7, 1997 
  as a result of the accident, and that Jenkins had not been disciplined in July 
  of 1997.Â  Diaz noted that this could be confirmed by the personnel office; however, 
  the ECO employee who inserted the note into the file was never called to testify.Â  
  Hector Calderon, human resource director at ECO, testified that ECO never fired 
  Jenkins in July of 1997.Â  He stated ECOâ€™s payroll records showed Jenkins was 
  working for the company during that time.Â  We agree with ECO that the only reasonable 
  conclusion is that the notation that Jenkins was terminated on July 11, 1997 
  is a typographical error.Â  See Hopson v. Clary, 321 S.C. 312, 
  314, 468 S.E.2d 305, 307 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating that although we are bound 
  to review the record in a light most favorable to respondents, we â€œcannot ignore 
  facts unfavorable to that party.â€)Â  However, even if we accept the notation 
  as evidence ECO had previously terminated Jenkins for unauthorized use of a 
  vehicle, we find the record does not support the juryâ€™s finding of negligent 
  entrustment against ECO.
Gadson asserts that the evidence 
  proves ECO knew that Jenkins was an irresponsible employee, and therefore was 
  likely to cause harm to third parties with the truck.Â  We disagree.Â  The crux 
  of the issue is whether ECO knew or should have known that Jenkins intended 
  or was likely to use the truck in such a manner as to create an unreasonable 
  risk of harm to others.Â  The only inference from the evidence in the record 
  is that Jenkins had attendance problems at work about six months before the 
  accident, and that he was known to take ECOâ€™s trucks home without authorization.Â  
  Jenkinsâ€™s driving record contained no violations, accidents, or suspensions 
  over the three-year period prior to the accident.Â  There is simply no evidence 
  that ECO knew that Jenkins was likely to drive the truck recklessly, or that 
  ECO knew that Jenkins was likely to entrust the truck to someone else who would 
  drive it recklessly.
Gadson attempts to close this 
  gap by using negative inferences from the fact that Jenkins did not testify 
  at the trial.Â  See Duckworth v. First Natâ€™l Bank, 254 S.C. 563, 
  576, 176 S.E.2d 297, 304 (1970) (â€œIf a party knows of an available witness on 
  a material issue and such witness is within his control and if without satisfactory 
  explanation he fails to call him, the jury may draw the inference that the testimony 
  of the witness would not have been favorable to such party.â€)Â  However, this 
  rule is not applicable here because Jenkins was no longer an employee of ECO 
  at the time of trial and thus was no longer under ECOâ€™s control.Â  Id. 
  at 576-77, 176 S.E.2d at 304.Â  
The test for legal sufficiency 
  of the evidence in South Carolina is â€œwhether the evidence serves to prove a 
  fact or permits an inference of fact that would enable an ordinarily intelligent 
  mind to draw a rational conclusion therefrom in support of the right of the 
  plaintiff to recover.â€Â  Mahaffey v. Ahl, 264 S.C. 241, 248, 214 S.E.2d 
  119, 122 (1975).Â  We find insufficient evidence to support the knowledge prong 
  of Gadsonâ€™s negligent entrustment claim against ECO.Â  The evidence presented 
  is simply not enough to permit an ordinarily intelligent mind to rationally 
  infer that ECO knew that Jenkins was likely to entrust the vehicle to another 
  who would drive recklessly.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court erred in denying 
  ECOâ€™s motions for directed verdict and JNOV.Â  
Jenkinsâ€™ liability for negligently 
  entrusting the truck to John is a separate issue.Â  Jenkins did not dispute that 
  he had control of the vehicle, or that he entrusted the vehicle to John.Â  Additionally, 
  Jenkins has not disputed that this entrustment was unauthorized.Â  We find the 
  record supports the inference that Jenkins knew or should have known that Johnâ€™s 
  use of the vehicle was likely to cause harm.Â  Jenkins knew that John had been 
  drinking alcoholic beverages.Â  Jenkins was apparently familiar with Johnâ€™s character, 
  because he was Johnâ€™s cousin.Â  Moreover, because Jenkins did not testify on 
  his own behalf, the jury was permitted to infer that any testimony would have 
  been unfavorable.Â  See McCowan v. Southerland, 253 S.C. 9, 12, 168 S.E. 
  573, 574 (1969) (stating that as to facts that were peculiarly within defendantâ€™s 
  knowledge, the defendantâ€™s unexplained failure to testify raises an inference 
  that his testimony, if it had been submitted, would have been unfavorable to 
  his position).Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not err in denying 
  Jenkinsâ€™s motions for directed verdict and JNOV.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the 
  trial court is
 AFFIRMED in part, and REVERSED in part. 
 HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  The official accident investigation report listed Jenkins as the 
    driver of the truck, but the jury by special interrogatory found the driver 
    at the time of the accident to be John.

 
   
    [2]  The other cases have been settled and are no longer a part of this 
    appeal.Â  In addition, John did not appeal the judgment against him.Â  

 
   
    [3]  After the trial, Jenkinsâ€™ attorney spoke to one of the jurors and 
    discovered that several of the jurors either knew of Jenkins and John or knew 
    of their reputations.Â  Additionally, one of the jurors had a cousin who worked 
    for ECO.Â  The attorney prepared an affidavit testifying to what he heard.Â  
  

 
   
    [4]  In Lydia v. Horton, 343 S.C. 376, 540 S.E.2d 102 (Ct. App. 
    2000), this court adopted the Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§Â§ 308 and 390 
    as the standard for negligent entrustment in South Carolina.Â  Lydia 
    involved a first party cause of action for negligent entrustment.Â  The South 
    Carolina Supreme Court reversed this courtâ€™s opinion, holding that the plaintiff 
    could not recover on a first party negligent entrustment cause of action because 
    â€œ(1) South Carolinaâ€™s modified comparative negligence scheme would bar recovery 
    for this type of claim, and (2) the public policy considerations addressed 
    . . . in Tobias v. Sports Club, Inc., 332 S.C. 90, 504 S.E.2d 318 (1998).â€Â  
    Lydia v. Horton, 355 S.C. 36, 39, 583 S.E.2d 750, 752 (2003).Â  The 
    supreme court also â€œdecline[d] to adopt sections 308 and 390 of the Restatementâ€ 
    based on the facts of that case.Â  Id. at 43, 583 S.E.2d at 754.Â  We 
    do not find the supreme courtâ€™s ruling in Lydia would prevent application 
    of section 308 of the Restatement under the facts of the present case as the 
    question addressed in Lydia was whether South Carolina recognizes a 
    first party negligent entrustment claim.Â
