THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD 
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Herbert Drucker and Marilyn R. Drucker,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Ralph F. Witt and Deborah Witt; Gordon Plastering Company, Inc.; European 
        Stucco, Inc.; and Parex Inc.,        Defendants,
Of Whom, Ralph F. Witt and Deborah Witt are,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-131
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  18, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert B. Phillips, of Columbia, for Appellants.Â  
Paul Collins, of Columbia, for Respondents.Â  
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Herbert and Marilyn Drucker 
  appeal the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of their negligence claims against the original 
  owners who built their house.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In 1989, Ralph and Deborah Witt built 
  a house on property they owned in Richland County, South Carolina.Â  The Witts 
  hired Gordon Plastering Company to clad the new house with Exterior Insulation 
  Finishing System (EIFS), a synthetic stucco material manufactured by Parex.Â  
  On November 20, 1997, the Witts sold their house to the Druckers.Â  Five 
  years later, the Druckers had the house inspected in preparation for putting 
  it up for sale. Â The inspection revealed several problems with the application 
  of the EIFS cladding, resulting in damage to the house.Â  
The Druckers filed a complaint against 
  the Witts, Gordon Plastering, Continental Stucco Products, and Parex, alleging 
  five causes of action against the Witts, including negligence, breach of express 
  warranties, breach of the implied warranties of habitability and workmanlike 
  service, and unfair trade practices.Â  All causes of action were predicated on 
  the alleged defective application of the EIFS cladding to the house. 
  [2] 
The Witts filed a 12(b)(6) motion as to all causes 
  of action, arguing the Druckers failed to allege sufficient facts to constitute 
  a cause of action.Â  In a brief form order, the trial court dismissed the Druckersâ€™ 
  claims for negligence, breach of express warranties, and unfair trade practices, 
  stating â€œmotion to dismiss as to causes of action one, two, and eight is granted.â€ 
  [3] Â  The Druckers did not file a Rule (59)(e) motion requesting the trial 
  court provide specific grounds for its rulings.
DISCUSSION
The Druckers contend the trial court erred by dismissing 
  their negligence claims against the Witts, arguing the court improperly relied 
  on a factual predicate outside of the pleadings to reach its decision and committed 
  an error of law by determining an original builder and owner of a house, who 
  is not a house builder by trade, owes no duty to protect a subsequent purchaser 
  from negligent construction.Â  We disagree.
First, the Druckers allege the trial court improperly 
  based its dismissal of their negligence claims on the assumption the Witts were 
  not in the business of building houses.Â  Even though the complaint alleged, 
  â€œthe Witts built the Property [and] were responsible for hiring the subcontractor 
  who clad the Property with EIFS,â€ there is no allegation in the complaint the 
  Witts were in the business of building houses.Â  The Druckers contend the improper 
  basis for the courtâ€™s ruling was revealed at the motion hearing when the trial 
  judge stated, â€œ[the Witts] built it, you know, they lived in it, they sold it, 
  then this stucco problem occurred.Â  I mean, you got the wrong person to do that, 
  unless they build houses all the time.Â  If they built it, moved into it, the 
  homeowner, Iâ€™m sorry.â€Â  
This issue is not preserved for our review.Â  
  The courtâ€™s statement at the motion hearing is not conclusive proof the court 
  utilized an improper basis for its final ruling.Â  The court provided no specific 
  grounds for its ruling, and we are unable to determine what particular facts 
  the court relied upon in dismissing the Druckersâ€™ negligence claims. The Druckers 
  could have requested the court provide more specific or complete grounds for 
  its ruling in a 59(e) motion.Â  Because they did not, the trial court was deprived 
  of the opportunity to explain its analysis of this issue, and we may not now 
  consider it on appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 
  76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (It is axiomatic that an issue must be raised 
  to and ruled upon by the trial court before the issue is preserved for appellate 
  review.).Â  
Next, the Druckers assert the trial court erred 
  as a matter of law by dismissing their negligence claims against the Witts, 
  arguing South Carolina recognizes a duty in an individual who builds a house, 
  lives there, and later sells it to protect a subsequent buyer from negligent 
  construction and may be liable to the buyer in tort for selling a defective 
  home.Â  We disagree.
The cases relied upon by the Druckers recognize a duty from 
  a commercial builder of a new house to a buyer, or from a seller to a buyer 
  on implied warranties of fitness and habitability but not on negligence claims.Â  
  See Lane v. Trenholm Bldg. Co., 267 S.C. 497, 500, 229 S.E.2d 
  728, 729 (1976) (holding a real estate developer has a duty to a buyer of a 
  house because â€œwhen a new building is sold there is an implied warranty of fitness 
  for its intended use which springs from the sale itself.â€); see also 
  Arvai v. Shaw, 289 S.C. 161, 164, 345 S.E.2d 715, 717 (1986) (holding 
  a subsequent owner of a house cannot claim the original commercial builder breached 
  the implied warranty of habitability where the house had been occupied by earlier 
  owners); Kennedy v. Columbia Lumber & Mfg. Co., 299 S.C. 335, 346, 
  384 S.E.2d 730, 737 (1989) (holding a builder of a new house has a duty to construct 
  the house in conformity with current building codes and industry standards if 
  â€œhe knows or should know [the house] will later be sold by a party to an innocent 
  buyer.â€).Â  We find no law creating a duty in tort on the part of a homeowner 
  who builds his own house running to a subsequent buyer.
Because in a negligence action there can be no recovery without 
  a breach of duty, the ruling of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.Â  

 
   
    [1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.Â  

 
    [2] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The record 
    also includes the Druckersâ€™ amended complaint correcting the name of one defendant.Â  
    The Witts contend the amended pleadings were never served on them, but since 
    both complaints assert the same causes of action, that is inconsequential. 
  

 
   
    [3] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Druckersâ€™ causes of action against the Witts for breach 
    of the implied warranties of habitability, merchantability, workmanlike service 
    and fitness for a particular purpose survive the trial courtâ€™s grant of the 
    12(b)(6) motion.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James Bruce Saxon, Jr.,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Curtis Stokes, M.D.,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-132
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  22, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James H. Moss, of Beaufort, for 
  Appellant.
Stephen L. Brown, John Hamilton 
  Smith, and Matthew K. Mahoney, all of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this medical malpractice 
  action, we must decide whether the trial court erred in seating two jurors, 
  one of whom identified herself as a current patient of the Respondent physician 
  and the other who identified himself as a former patient of another physician 
  in the Respondentâ€™s medical practice.Â  Over Appellantâ€™s objection, the trial 
  judge impaneled these jurors.Â  We find no abuse of discretion and affirm the 
  trial judgeâ€™s ruling.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Appellant James Bruce Saxon, Jr., brought 
  this medical malpractice action against Respondent Curtis Stokes, M.D.Â  At the 
  time this case was brought to trial, Dr. Stokes was one of six doctors practicing 
  general medicine at Walterboro Family Practice, P.A., in Colleton County.Â  Walterboro 
  Family Practice, however, was not a party to this action.Â  
During jury venire, the trial judge asked 
  the pool of potential jurors whether they had any connection with Dr. Stokes 
  or the other physicians or employees of Walterboro Family Practice.Â  Twenty-nine 
  jurors responded affirmatively.Â  When individually questioned by the trial judge, 
  some jurors indicated they were current or longstanding patients of Dr. Stokes 
  or the other physicians in his practice, while others responded they were treated 
  only once or twice by these doctorsâ€”in some cases, years ago.Â  
Saxon requested that all jurors who were 
  being treated by Dr. Stokes and his associates be stricken for cause, arguing 
  this doctor-patient relationship would unavoidably hinder these jurorsâ€™ ability 
  to view the case impartially. The trial judge disagreed, finding all but one 
  of the twenty-nine affected jurorsâ€”based on their responsesâ€”could serve fairly 
  and impartially. 
As the jury was being drawn, Saxon used 
  all four of his peremptory strikes to excuse jurors who had identified themselves 
  as having a connection to Dr. Stokes or his medical practice associates.Â  However, 
  two of the affected jurors were drawn after all of the peremptory strikes had 
  been exhausted.Â  These two jurorsâ€”juror number 125 and juror number 158â€”were 
  both impaneled on the jury despite Saxonâ€™s general objection that any juror 
  who had been treated by Dr. Stokes or his associates be struck from the jury. 

During the initial jury venire, both juror 125 
  and juror 158 were individually questioned by the trial judge.Â  Juror 125 identified 
  herself as a current patient of Dr. Stokes:

JUROR: My name is Robertson, 
  125.
THE COURT: Thank you.Â  Ms. Robertson, 
  whom is it that you recognize?
JUROR: Dr. Stokes and also Dr. 
  Hyatt.
THE COURT: And are they your 
  family physicians?
JUROR: Yes, sir.
THE COURT: And are you -- have 
  you seen them in the last six months?
JUROR: Yes, sir.
THE COURT: And as a result of 
  that type of relationship you have with those doctors, can you be fair and impartial 
  to both the Plaintiff and Defendant in connection with this case?
JUROR: Yes, I can.

Juror 158 identified himself as a former patient 
  of another physician practicing with Dr. Stokes:

THE COURT: Yes, sir?
JUROR: James Walker, Number 158.
THE COURT: Yes, sir, Mr. Walker. 
  Whom do you recognize?
JUROR: Dr. Johnson used to be 
  my doctor many years ago.
THE COURT: And as a result of 
  that type of relationship, can you be fair and impartial to the Plaintiff and 
  to the Defendant?
JUROR: Yes.Â 

Both of these jurors were impaneled on 
  the twelve-member jury that decided the caseâ€”finding in favor of Dr. Stokes.Â  
  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision to disqualify a potential juror for 
  bias is committed to the sound discretion of the trial judge and that decision 
  will not be overturned absent an abuse of discretion. Abofreka v. Alston 
  Tobacco Co., 288 S.C. 122, 125, 341 S.E.2d 622, 624 (1986); Palmetto 
  Bank v. Rowland, 275 S.C. 38, 40, 267 S.E.2d 426, 426 (1980). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Saxon claims the trial judge abused his 
  discretion in failing to disqualify juror 125 and juror 158 from serving on 
  the jury.Â  Saxon makes two legal arguments here: first, that this court should 
  adopt a per se rule that all ongoing patients of a physician involved 
  in a medical malpractice action be disqualified from serving on the jury, and, 
  alternatively, absent a per se rule, juror 125 and juror 158 should 
  nevertheless have been disqualified in this case.Â  Dr. Stokes, however, claims 
  that Saxon failed to preserve these issues for appeal.
I.Â  Preservation of Issues for Appeal
We first address the questions raised 
  concerning issue preservation.Â  
Respondent argues that Saxon failed to specifically 
  raise an objection to the qualification of jurors 125 and 158, thereby waiving 
  any right to appeal the trial judgeâ€™s decision to allow these jurors to serve. 
  [1] Â  We agree in part.
After carefully reviewing the transcript 
  of the jury selection process contained in the record before us, it is clear 
  that Saxonâ€™s objection regarding juror disqualification focused primarily on 
  those jurors who had identified themselves as current patients of Dr. Stokes.Â  
  Saxon voiced much less concern about those jurors who had been treated many 
  years ago or were treated by the other physicians of Walterboro Family Practice. 
Arguably, therefore, Saxon abandoned his request 
  to disqualify all but the current, ongoing patients of Dr. Stokes.Â  However, 
  despite this almost exclusive focus on the current patients of Dr. Stokes in 
  argument to the trial judge, Saxonâ€™s counsel did, by way of caveat, add: â€œI 
  mean, we think that all former or current patients of the 
  firm should be stricken, but . . . â€ (emphasis added).Â  While a close 
  question is presented, we find this statement preserves Saxonâ€™s general objection 
  to any of the twenty-nine affected jurors being allowed to serve on the juryâ€”whether 
  they were current or former patients of the defendant or any other physician 
  in his practice.
Part of Saxonâ€™s argument to this court, 
  however, is that the trial judge was unable to reach a fully informed decision 
  about the ability of jurors 125 and 158 to serve impartially because he failed 
  to â€œreexamineâ€ those two jurors individually as he had done with other jurors 
  specifically identified by Saxon.Â  We find this particular argument is 
  not preserved.Â  
The judge requested from Saxon a list 
  of the jurors in question.Â  Saxon furnished the list, and the judge agreed to 
  reexamine those jurors on the list.Â  Jurors 125 and 158 were not included on 
  the list, and they were not reexamined.Â  Following the judgeâ€™s reexamination 
  of those jurors identified on Saxonâ€™s list, and just prior to jury selection, 
  the judge asked, â€œAnything else we need to do, as far as the plaintiff is concerned 
  prior toâ€ the preparation of the strike sheet?Â Â Â  Saxon, through counsel, responded, 
  â€œNo, sir, your honor.â€Â  We find Saxonâ€™s current challenge to the trial judgeâ€™s 
  failure to reexamine jurors 125 and 158 is not preserved.Â  
II.Â  Qualification of Jurors 125 
  and 158
Turning to the merits of Saxonâ€™s broader 
  appeal, and in the application of current law, we find no abuse of discretion 
  by the trial judgeâ€™s qualification of jurors 125 and 158.
The circumstances of this case mirror 
  those in the case ofÂ  Roof v. Kimbrough, 297 S.C. 156, 375 S.E.2d 318 
  (Ct. App. 1988).Â  In Roof, the appellants claimed the trial judge erred 
  in â€œfailing to strike for cause . . . any prospective juror who was being or 
  had been treated, or whose family members were treatedâ€ by the respondent physicians 
  in a medical malpractice action.Â  During voir dire, several members of the venire 
  responded that they themselves or a close relative had been treated by the respondents.Â  
  The trial judge, however, individually questioned these jurors, and each responded 
  that his or her connection to the physicians being sued in that case would not 
  prejudice or prevent him or her from reaching a true and just verdict in the 
  case.Â  On appeal, this court found no abuse of discretion by the trial court 
  in impaneling those jurors. Id. at 158, 375 S.E.2d at 320.
We find the case at hand is squarely on point with 
  Roof.Â  As noted above, the trial judge included both jurors 125 and 158 
  individually in his initial questioning regarding the nature of their relationship 
  with Dr. Stokes and Walterboro Family Practice.Â  Both jurors responded unequivocally 
  that their respective connections to Dr. Stokes or his associates would not 
  prevent them from being fair and impartial.Â  Saxon cites no evidence indicating 
  these jurors were harboring any prejudice or otherwise being less than honest 
  in answering the trial courtâ€™s questions.Â  
Additionally, we must reject at this level 
  Saxonâ€™s suggestion that such prejudice should be presumed and that we adopt 
  a per se rule barring any patient of a defendant in a medical 
  malpractice case from serving on the jury. 
  [2] Â Â  Our supreme court has signaled no intention to divest the trial courts 
  of the discretion to address the qualification of a juror in a medical malpractice 
  case as the circumstances of the individual case and the ends of justice require.Â  
  We, as a mere error correction court, decline Saxonâ€™s invitation to deviate 
  from precedent and adopt the suggested per se rule in medical 
  malpractice actions.Â  While we recognize the special relationship that exists 
  between patient and physician, policy matters such as this lie exclusively within 
  the supreme court.
CONCLUSION
Under existing law, we find no abuse of 
  discretion by the trial judge in denying Saxonâ€™s request to disqualify jurors 
  125 and 158 from jury service in this case.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, 
  JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

 
  Â Â Â Â  
    [1] See United Student Aid Funds, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of 
    Health and Envtâ€™l Control, 356 S.C. 266, 273, 588 S.E.2d 599, 602 (2003) 
    (holding that an issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial 
    court to be preserved for appellate review).Â  

 
  Â Â Â Â  
    [2] Saxon argues the circumstances of the present case are analogous to those 
    of Alston v. Black River Electric Cooperative, 345 S.C. 323, 548 S.E.2d 
    858 (2001), in which our supreme court adopted a rule that cooperative members 
    should per se be disqualified to serve on a jury where the cooperative 
    was a party.Â  The ruling in Alston was rooted in the courtâ€™s recognition 
    that cooperative members have an â€œinherent pecuniary interest in the caseâ€ 
    which would unavoidably hinder their ability to view the case impartially. 
    Id. at 331, 548 S.E.2d at 862.Â  Whether an Alston-type exception 
    should be recognized in a medical malpractice actionâ€”excusing for cause those 
    potential jurors who are current or former patients of the defendant physicianâ€”is 
    beyond the purview of this error correction court.Â  Â Â Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Aundray Livingston,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-133
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  22, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert William Mills, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  and Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Randolph Murdaugh, III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from a felony driving 
  under the influence conviction.Â  The primary issue is whether a hospital employee 
  who obtained a urine sample from the defendant was properly trained and qualified 
  under the provisions of our stateâ€™s implied consent law governing the collection 
  of blood and urine samples from DUI suspects.Â  We affirm the trial courtâ€™s determination 
  that the hospital employee was adequately qualified.Â  
Appellant also claims the trial court improperly 
  admitted hearsay testimony.Â  We do not reach the merits of this issue, finding 
  it was not preserved for our review.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL 
  HISTORY
While driving down Highway 21 
  in Beaufort County, Aundray Livingston crossed the median and collided head-on 
  with an oncoming car, killing its driver.Â  Livingston was injured, but he survived 
  the crash and was taken to Beaufort Memorial Hospital for treatment.Â  The Highway 
  Patrol officer investigating the accident requested a sample of Livingstonâ€™s 
  urine. [1] Â  Harry Jenkins, an 
  employee of the hospital, collected the sample from Livingston.Â  Laboratory 
  analysis by SLED revealed the urine sample contained significant levels of THC, 
  the pharmacologically active component of marijuana.Â  Livingston was later charged 
  with felony DUI. 
At trial, Livingston moved to 
  exclude evidence of the urine test results, claiming the State failed to establish 
  that Jenkins had the proper medical training prescribed under the implied consent 
  statute (S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950) to obtain urine samples. The trial court 
  denied this motion and admitted the test results.Â  Livingston was subsequently 
  convicted of felony DUI and sentenced to twenty-five years imprisonment.Â  
On appeal, this court found the 
  record did not provide a sufficient factual basis to determine whether Jenkins 
  was qualified to obtain the sample.Â  We remanded the case to the circuit court 
  for a determination of whether Jenkins had the training required under the statute. 

On remand, the State presented 
  testimony from Geraldine Charlesworth, the former Director of Education at Beaufort 
  Memorial Hospital.Â  Charlesworth testified she was responsible for clinical 
  education of the hospitalâ€™s nursing and clinical staff.Â  She described the â€œcompetency 
  and credentialingâ€ process that each hospital employee must pass through after 
  they are first hired and the system of evaluations all employees must undergo 
  regularly thereafter.Â  With regard to Harry Jenkinsâ€™ qualifications, she testified 
  that she had specifically and individually trained Jenkins, and that he was 
  skilled in a number of competency areas, including specimen collection. [2]  Charlesworth specifically noted that Jenkinsâ€™ training included 
  instruction on the proper procedures for obtaining urine samples.Â  Based on 
  this testimony, the trial court found as fact that Jenkins did have the requisite 
  medical training to take Livingstonâ€™s urine sample.Â  The present appeal followed. 

STANDARD OF 
  REVIEW
A trial judgeâ€™s decision to admit or exclude evidence 
  is within his discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse 
  of discretion. Elledge v. Richland/Lexington Sch. Dist. Five, 352 S.C. 
  179, 185, 573 S.E.2d 789, 792 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Jenkinsâ€™ Qualification 
  to Obtain the Urine Sample
Livingston first argues the trial 
  court erred in finding Harry Jenkins was qualified to obtain a urine sample 
  under the provisions of the implied consent statute.Â  We disagree.
Under the implied consent statute, 
  an arresting officer may direct that a urine sample be collected from a person 
  arrested for DUI if that person is unable to submit to a breathalyzer test for 
  medical reasons.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 (Supp. 2004).Â  The statute requires, 
  however, that these samples be collected by qualified medical personnel: â€œBlood 
  and urine samples must be obtained by physicians licensed by the State Board 
  of Medical Examiners, registered nurses licensed by the State Board of Nursing, 
  and other medical personnel trained to obtain the samples in a licensed medical 
  facility.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a).Â  This requirement that blood and urine 
  samples be obtained by qualified medical personnel serves the clear purpose 
  of ensuring that a specimen collected is free from contamination that would 
  diminish the accuracy or reliability of any test results obtained from the sample.
We find sufficient evidence supports 
  the trial court determination that Jenkins was adequately trained to obtain 
  a urine sample under section 56-5-2950.Â  As noted above, Geraldine Charlesworth 
  presented detailed testimony regarding the competency and credentialing requirements 
  all hospital employees must satisfyâ€”skills that not only must be demonstrated 
  at the outset of their employment, but must be reassessed on a regular basis 
  by the hospitalâ€™s senior staff.Â  Moreover, Charlesworth testified specifically 
  that Jenkinsâ€™ had demonstrated competency with regard to the proper procedures 
  for collecting urine samples. [3] Â  Contrary to Livingstonâ€™s argument on appeal, there is no requirement 
  that Jenkins be a licensed medical professional, as the statute specifically 
  includes within its ambit â€œother medical personnel trained to obtain the samples 
  in a licensed medical facility.â€
II.Â  Hearsay Objection
Livingston also argues 
  the trial court erred in admitting Charlesworthâ€™s testimony regarding Jenkinsâ€™ 
  employment records because it was hearsay.Â  We find this issue is not preserved.
Geraldine Charlesworth 
  testified during the initial hearing on remand in June 2002.Â  Her testimony 
  regarding Jenkinsâ€™ training and qualifications was based in part on her review 
  of Jenkinsâ€™ employment files.Â  When the hearing was reconvened in September 
  2002, Livingston objected to Charlesworthâ€™s testimony regardingâ€”and reliance 
  onâ€”the employment records of Jenkins.Â  The trial court overruled this objection, 
  finding it was far too late raise the matter and that Livingston had therefore 
  waived any objection. 
We concur in the circuit courtâ€™s 
  assessment.Â  A contemporaneous objection is required at trial to preserve an 
  issue for appellate review. State v. Johnson, 324 S.C. 38, 41, 476 S.E.2d 
  681, 682 (1996). The issue must be raised to and ruled on by the trial judge. 
  State v. Williams, 303 S.C. 410, 411, 401 S.E.2d 168, 169 (1991). Failure 
  to object when the evidence is offered constitutes a waiver of the right to 
  object. State v. Black, 319 S.C. 515, 521-22, 462 S.E.2d 311, 315 (Ct. 
  App. 1995).Â  Thus, Livingston is procedurally barred from raising this issue 
  on appeal.
CONCLUSION
We find there is sufficient 
  evidence to support finding that Harry Jenkins was qualified under section 56-5-2950 
  to obtain a urine sample from Livingston.Â  We do not address Livingstonâ€™s hearsay 
  objection as it is not preserved for appellate review.Â  The order of the circuit 
  court is therefore
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, KITTREDGE, 
  and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  Â 

 
  Â Â Â Â  
    [1] See State v. Livingston, 327 S.C. 17, 488 S.E.2d 313 (1997) 
    (reciting the facts relating to the accident).

 
  Â Â Â Â  
    [2] Charlesworth specifically noted that Jenkins had been trained in the â€œuniversal 
    cautionsâ€ of specimen collection, which includes the procedures to be followed 
    in order to â€œprotect[] the specimen against any contamination.â€ 

 
  Â Â Â Â  
    [3] Livingston further claims that Charlesworthâ€™s testimony was insufficient 
    because it referenced â€œHarry Jenkinsâ€ rather than the â€œHenry Jenkinsâ€ discussed 
    in this courtâ€™s earlier opinion, State v. Livingston, Op. No. 2001-UP-475 
    (S.C. Ct. App. 2001).Â  This courtâ€™s reference to â€œHenry Jenkinsâ€ was clearly 
    a scrivenerâ€™s error.Â  Indeed, the trial court noted at the hearing on remand 
    that the â€œHarry Jenkinsâ€ referred to in Charlesworthâ€™s testimony was â€œthe 
    individual referred to in [the Court of Appealsâ€™] decision as Henry Jenkins.â€

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Donnie Hildreth,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
County of Kershaw,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-134
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  22, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Andrew F. Lindemann, David L. Morrison, of Columbia, for Appellant.
J. Charles Ormond, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Donnie Hildreth brought 
  an inverse condemnation action against the County of Kershaw alleging its excavation 
  of a trench near his property proximately caused damage to his property and 
  residence.Â  A jury trial was held and the jury returned a verdict in the amount 
  of $125,000 in favor of Hildreth.Â  The County appeals.Â  We affirm.1
FACTS
In the fall of 1998, the 
  County excavated a trench to install a sewer line across the road from Hildrethâ€™s 
  property.Â  Hildreth alleged after the County dug the trench, his property began 
  to settle.Â  The settling caused extensive damage to his house.Â  
Hildreth brought an inverse condemnation action 
  against the County claiming the trench proximately caused damage to his property 
  and his residence.Â  The case was tried before a jury.Â  During the trial, Hildreth 
  presented the expert testimony of Burton Wells, a civil engineer, who testified 
  that within a reasonable degree of engineering certainty and based on the data 
  he collected, the digging of the trench caused a change in the water regime, 
  which resulted in the settlement of Hildrethâ€™s property.Â  The County made a 
  motion to strike this testimony due to lack of evidentiary support for Wellsâ€™ 
  opinion.Â  The trial court denied this motion.Â  
At the close of Hildrethâ€™s case and at the close 
  of all of the evidence, the County moved for a directed verdict based on Hildrethâ€™s 
  failure to prove the trench proximately caused the alleged damage to his property.Â  
  The trial court denied these motions.Â  The case was presented to the jury, which 
  returned a verdict for Hildreth in the amount of $125,000.Â  The County made 
  a motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict, new trial nisi, and new trial 
  absolute.Â  The trial court denied these motions.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Motion to Strike
The County argues the trial court erred 
  in denying its motion to strike Wellsâ€™ testimony.Â  The County alleges because 
  Wells could not opine as to whether a perched water table existed, his opinion 
  was based on conjecture, speculation, and supposition.Â  Therefore, the County 
  asserts his opinion lacked a sufficient basis and was improperly admitted by 
  the trial court.Â  We disagree.
The admissibility of evidence is within the discretion 
  of the trial court and will not be reversed on appeal absent a showing of abuse 
  of discretion.Â  Elledge v. Richland/Lexington Sch. Dist. Five,
352 S.C. 179, 185, 573 S.E.2d 789, 792 (2002).Â  Rule 703, SCRE, provides: 


The facts or data in the particular case upon which an expert bases an opinion 
  or inference may be those perceived by or made known to the expert at or before 
  the hearing.Â  If of a type reasonably relied upon by experts in the particular 
  field in forming opinions or inferences upon the subject, the facts or data 
  need not be admissible in evidence.


  â€œWhere the expertâ€™s testimony is based upon facts sufficient to form the basis 
  for an opinion, the trier of fact determines its probative value.â€Â  Berkeley 
  Elec. Coop., Inc. v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 304 S.C. 15, 20, 402 S.E.2d 674, 677 (1991).Â  
We find the trial court did not abuse its discretion 
  in allowing Wellsâ€™ testimony.Â  The County did not object to Wellsâ€™ qualifications 
  as an expert on civil engineering.Â  The County only argues Wells did not have 
  a sufficient basis to render his opinion as to the cause of the subsidence.Â  
  We find the record does establish a sufficient basis forWellsâ€™ opinion.Â  
Wells testified he visited Hildrethâ€™s property several 
  times, made soil borings, and considered the type of soil according to the Kershaw 
  County Soil Report.Â  He reviewed and considered a report generated by another 
  engineer who examined the property.Â  He personally inspected the manhole associated 
  with the trench and saw it contained water and was rusted and stained, indicating 
  the water flowed from the inside of the manhole to the outside.Â  As a result 
  of his observations, Wells asked Hildreth to construct wells on his property 
  in order to determine the flow of water after significant rain.Â  Wells also 
  instructed Hildreth to report the water level in the wells to him, and based 
  on these reports, he determined the trench had a connection to the subsidence.Â  
  Wells also determined the soil around the trench was not compacted as evidenced 
  by the fact it had settled by at least a foot.Â  Based on these facts, he determined 
  the ground water took the path of least resistance and â€œwas most probably intercepted 
  by the drain.â€Â  
In addition, Wells considered the timing of when 
  the County excavated the trench and when the subsidence began, and that no previous 
  incidences of subsidence occurred.Â  He noted as time progressed, the subsidence 
  did not worsen, indicating the soil compacted naturally, and the movement of 
  water stabilized.Â  Wells also ruled out other possible causes for the subsidence, 
  including a problem with Hildrethâ€™s pool, his septic drain field, drought or 
  other weather conditions, or old tree stumps.Â  Therefore, we find this evidence 
  established a proper basis for Wellsâ€™ opinion that to a reasonable degree of 
  engineering certainty, the most probable cause of the soil subsidence was the 
  digging of the trench, which provided a more efficient outlet for subsurface 
  water.Â  Accordingly, the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying 
  the Countyâ€™s motion to strike Wellsâ€™ testimony.Â  
II.Â  Directed Verdict and JNOV
The County argues the 
  trial court erred in denying its motions for directed verdict and JNOV.Â  The 
  County asserts Hildreth failed to present evidence that his damages were proximately 
  caused by the excavation of the trench.Â  We disagree. 
In considering a directed verdict or a JNOV motion, 
  the appellate court, like the trial court, is required to view the evidence 
  and the inferences that can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to 
  the nonmoving party.Â  Sabb v. South Carolina State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 
  427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  The motions must be denied when the evidence 
  yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  Id.Â  Neither 
  the trial court nor the appellate court has authority to decide credibility 
  issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 
  350 S.C. 303, 308, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002).
We find evidence does exist to support the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling.Â  Although Wells could not identify the exact mechanism, he determined 
  the trench provided a more efficient outlet for the ground water, and therefore, 
  it changed the water regime and caused the subsidence in the property.Â  This 
  testimony provides a basis upon which the jury could determine the trench proximately 
  caused Hildrethâ€™s property to subside.Â  
In addition to Wellsâ€™ testimony, Hildreth also provided 
  other evidence that the trench caused the damage to his property.Â  Hildreth 
  testified he did not notice any problems with his property until after the excavation 
  of the trench.Â  Hildrethâ€™s ex-wife, in her testimony, confirmed Hildrethâ€™s observation 
  that the problems did not begin until after the excavation of the trench.Â  Hildreth 
  also introduced photographs during his testimony depicting his property before 
  and after the excavation of the trench and the subsidence of the earth surrounding 
  the manhole associated with the trench.Â  Therefore, we find evidence does exist 
  to support the juryâ€™s determination and accordingly, the trial court properly 
  denied the Countyâ€™s motions for directed verdict and JNOV. 
III.Â  Motion for New Trial Absolute 
The County argues the trial judge erred 
  in denying its motion for new trial absolute.Â  We disagree.Â  
The trial court alone has the power to 
  grant a new trial nisi when it finds the amount of the verdict to be 
  merely inadequate or excessive.Â  Oâ€™Neal v. Bowles, 314 S.C. 525, 526, 
  431 S.E.2d 555, 557 (1993). The denial of a motion for a new trial nisi 
  is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion and will not be reversed on appeal absent 
  an abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  On appeal of the denial of a motion for 
  a new trial nisi, this court will reverse only when the verdict is grossly 
  inadequate or excessive requiring the granting of a new trial absolute.Â  Id.Â  

The trial courtâ€™s decision to deny a motion for 
  new trial absolute is within its discretion and will not be reversed absent 
  an abuse of discretion.Â  Cock-N-Bull Steak House, Inc. v. Generali Ins. Co., 
  321 S.C. 1, 9, 466 S.E.2d 727, 731 (1996).Â  When deciding a motion to grant 
  a new trial, the court must look at the testimony and inferences raised in favor 
  of the nonmoving party.Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 302-03, 536 
  S.E.2d 408, 420 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œThe trial court must set aside a verdict 
  only when it is shockingly disproportionate to the injuries suffered and thus 
  indicates that passion, caprice, prejudice, or other considerations not reflected 
  by the evidence affected the amount awarded.â€Â  Id. at 302, 536 S.E.2d 
  at 420.Â  A juryâ€™s determination of damages is entitled to substantial deference 
  by this court.Â  Knoke v. S.C. Depâ€™t. of Parks, Recreation & Tourism, 
  324 S.C. 136, 141, 478 S.E.2d 256, 258 (1996).
 Viewing the testimony in the light most 
  favorable to Hildreth, we find the verdict returned by the jury within the scope 
  of the evidence.Â  The measure of damages in an inverse condemnation action is 
  the diminution in the market value of the property.2Â  Ravan v. Greenville County, 315 S.C. 447, 
  465, 434 S.E.2d 296, 307 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  In response to a question regarding 
  the value of his home and property without the damage, Hildreth stated:Â  â€œI 
  probably figure maybe $180,000.â€Â  When questioned about its value with the damage, 
  he stated:Â  â€œWith the damage and the repair and everything, probably $100,000 
  or less.â€Â  From this testimony, the jury could infer the current value is actually 
  less than $100,000 and, therefore, the diminution in value was greater than 
  $80,000.Â  Hildreth also testified he previously spent two to three thousand 
  dollars on repairs.Â  The jury may have considered this amount in increasing 
  the diminution in value amount.Â  Hildreth also presented the testimony of his 
  contractor, V.C. Rabon, who estimated the cost to repair the house at $74,000.Â  
  However, the costs to repair were not limited solely to Rabonâ€™s $74,000 estimate.Â  
  Specifically, Rabon noted on cross-examination by the Countyâ€™s attorney that 
  he did not include the cost to correct any problems with the footings under 
  the house.Â  Furthermore, Hildreth presented evidence that not only was his house 
  damaged, but his yard was also damaged by the subsidence, with large indentions 
  in the yard and buckles and cracks in his cement walkway and cracks in the patio.Â  
  Thus the repairs by Rabon would not alleviate the diminution in value to the 
  property itself.Â  Considering the record as a whole we do not find the juryâ€™s 
  verdict of $125,000 â€œshockingly disproportionate to the injuries suffered and 
  thus indicat[ing] that passion, caprice, prejudice, or other considerations 
  not reflected by the evidence affected the amount awarded.â€Â  Thus, under our 
  limited standard of review, we are constrained to hold the trial court did not 
  abuse its discretion in denying the Countyâ€™s motion for a new trial absolute.Â  

 AFFIRMED.Â  
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ. concur.Â  
  

 
  1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
  2 
    This court has also recognized prejudgment interest as recoverable in an inverse 
    condemnation action.Â  Vick v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp.,
  347 S.C. 470, 481, 556 S.E.2d 693, 699 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  However, 
    as the jury was not charged that it could award such interest as damages, 
    we will not consider prejudgment interest in determining whether the trial 
    court erred in denying the Countyâ€™s motion for a new trial absolute.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Brenda L. Wooldridge,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Greenwood Mills, Inc.,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-135
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  23, 2005 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Theo W. Mitchell, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Joel S. Brandon and Melegia Lee Daniels, Jr., both of Greenville, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Brenda Wooldridge appeals the 
  trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Greenwood Mills, Inc. in 
  her action for wrongful termination.Â  We affirm.1Â  
Facts
Wooldridge worked for Greenwood Mills from 1994 
  until June 5, 2001.Â  While Wooldridge was working in the early morning hours 
  of June 4, she ran out of a material called roving.Â  She asked her supervisor 
  Linda Rush to obtain some for her.Â  As she was accompanying Rush to obtain the 
  roving, Wooldridge became involved in an altercation with Sarah Tate, a fellow 
  employee, in the post alley between their jobs.Â  Wooldridge testified in her 
  deposition that Tate approached her, shaking her finger in Wooldridgeâ€™s face, 
  and accusing Wooldridge of â€œhogging the roving.â€Â  Wooldridge told Tate, â€œ[G]et 
  your hand out of my face.â€Â  Tate continued pointing her finger at Wooldridge 
  so Wooldridge again instructed her to get her hand out of Wooldridgeâ€™s face.Â  
  Rush then told both employees to go home.Â  Wooldridge gathered her purse, told 
  her sister she was leaving, and left the plant.Â  Wooldridge acknowledged that 
  she was upset, Tate appeared angry, and they both had been speaking loudly.Â  
  She stated she never heard Rush tell them to stop arguing or to return to their 
  jobs.Â  
The next morning Wooldridge returned to the plant 
  and spoke with Frankie Wells, the spinning room supervisor, and Pierce Sullivan, 
  the human resources manager.Â  They informed her Rush had told them that during 
  the argument she had asked Wooldridge and Tate to return to their positions.Â  
  Sullivan told her he was going to investigate the matter.Â  He asked her to return 
  the next day.Â  She met with Wells and Sullivan again on June 5.Â  Wells told 
  her then she was being discharged for creating a disturbance in the workplace.Â  
  She met with Warren Moore, the vice president of Human Resources, the following 
  day.Â  He affirmed that her employment was terminated for creating a disturbance 
  in the workplace.Â  Tate was also discharged for the same reason.Â  
Wooldridge applied for unemployment benefits 
  and was initially disqualified.Â  She appealed this decision and appeared at 
  a hearing before a hearing officer of the Employment Security Commission.Â  Rush, 
  Sullivan, and Wells testified at the hearing for Greenwood Mills.Â  The hearing 
  officer held Wooldridge was disqualified from receiving benefits for thirteen 
  weeks because she was discharged for cause.Â  Wooldridge did not appeal this 
  ruling.
Wooldridge brought this action against 
  Greenwood Mills for wrongful termination.Â  She asserted Greenwood Mills acted 
  wrongfully by terminating her for exercising a legal right and terminating her 
  without adhering to its own policies and procedures.Â  Greenwood Mills moved 
  for summary judgment.Â  After a hearing, which Wooldridgeâ€™s counsel failed to 
  attend, the trial court granted the motion for summary judgment.Â  This appeal 
  followed.Â  
Standard of Review
â€œThe purpose of summary 
  judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases which do not require the services 
  of a fact finder.â€Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 
  438 (2003).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue 
  as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter 
  of law.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â  
  The evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light 
  most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  â€œIt is well established 
  that summary judgment should be granted â€˜. . . in cases in which plain, palpable 
  and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ.â€™â€Â  Anders 
  v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 307 S.C. 371, 373, 415 S.E.2d 406, 407 
  (Ct. App. 1992) (quoting Main v. Corley, 281 S.C. 525, 526, 316 S.E.2d 
  406, 407 (1984)); see Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 425, 529 
  S.E.2d 710, 714 (2000) (finding where a verdict is not reasonably possible under 
  the facts presented, summary judgment is proper).Â  
Discussion
Wooldridge argues a genuine 
  issue of material fact exists as to whether Greenwood Mills wrongfully discharged 
  her.Â  We disagree.Â  
South Carolina recognizes 
  the doctrine of employment at will in wrongful termination actions.Â  Prescott 
  v. Farmers Tel. Coop., Inc., 335 S.C. 330, 334, 516 S.E.2d 923, 925 (1999).Â  
  Although some exceptions have been recognized, the doctrine of employment at-will 
  remains in South Carolina as a longstanding economic incentive that provides 
  the marketplace its necessary flexibility.Â  Id. at 335, 516 S.E.2d at 
  925.Â  At-will employment may be terminated by either party at any time, for 
  any reason or for no reason at all.Â  Id. at 334, 516 S.E.2d at 925.Â  
  The general rule is that termination of an at-will employee normally does not 
  give rise to a cause of action for breach of contract.Â  Conner v. City of 
  Forest Acres, 348 S.C. 454, 463, 560 S.E.2d 606, 610 (2002).Â  
However, an employer and 
  employee may choose to contractually alter the general rule of employment at-will.Â  
  Prescott, 335 S.C. at 335, 442 S.E.2d at 925.Â  A contract of employment 
  may arise from oral or written words or by conduct.Â  Id. at 335, 442 
  S.E.2d at 926.Â  An employee handbook may create such a contract. Small v. 
  Springs Indus., 292 S.C. 481, 485, 357 S.E.2d 452, 455 (1987).Â  The court 
  in Small explained, â€œIt is patently unjust to allow an employer to couch 
  a handbook, bulletin, or other similar material in mandatory terms and then 
  allow him to ignore these very policies as â€˜a gratuitous, nonbinding statement 
  of general policyâ€™ whenever it works to his disadvantage.â€Â  Id.Â  
Wooldridge contends that 
  her status as more than an at-will employee is disputed.Â  Greenwood Mills presented 
  a copy of Wooldridgeâ€™s application.Â  On this application a disclaimer is written 
  in bold print:

I UNDERSTAND THAT THIS 
  APPLICATION AND ANY OTHER COMPANY DOCUMENTS ARE NOT CONTRACTS OF EMPLOYMENT, 
  AND ANYONE WHO IS HIRED MAY VOLUNTARILY LEAVE EMPLOYMENT, AND MAY BE TERMINATED 
  BY THE EMPLOYER AT ANY TIME FOR ANY REASON. Â I UNDERSTAND THAT ANY ORAL OR WRITTEN 
  STATEMENTS TO THE CONTRARY ARE EXPRESSLY DISAVOWED AND SHOULD NOT BE RELIED 
  UPON BY ANY PROSPECTIVE OR EXISTING ASSOCIATE.Â  

Wooldridge testified that she understood this provision 
  when she signed her application.Â  She acknowledged that after she was hired, 
  no one told her anything different from the provision.Â  However, she also testified 
  that when she was hired, a secretary told her that employees received one write-up 
  and then would be fired if they did not follow the rules.Â  She could not recall 
  the secretaryâ€™s name.Â  When asked if anyone else had told her about the write-up, 
  she stated, â€œYour supervisor tell you on the job.â€Â  She failed to identify the 
  supervisor who gave her this information.Â  The trial court did not address whether 
  these statements could be construed as an oral contract of employment.Â  Wooldridge 
  failed to request the trial court rule on this issue in a Rule 59, SCRCP motion.Â  
  Accordingly, this issue is not properly before this court.Â  See Summer 
  v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 43, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997) (where trial judge 
  did not rule on issue at trial and party did not make a Rule 59, SCRCP, motion 
  for a ruling, issue is not preserved for appellate review).Â  Furthermore, Wooldridge 
  failed to present any evidence that the unnamed secretary and supervisor had 
  authority to alter the stated policy of at-will employment found on the application.Â  
  The disclaimer in Wooldridgeâ€™s application clearly provided that any statements 
  contradictory to employment at will were disavowed.Â  When opposing a summary 
  judgment motion, the nonmoving party must do more than â€œsimply show that there 
  is a metaphysical doubt as to the material facts but must come forward with 
  specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for trial.â€ Baughman 
  v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 115, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  
  We find Wooldridge failed to meet this burden.Â  
Wooldridge claims the handbook she received when 
  she came to work for Greenwood Mills creates a genuine issue of material fact 
  concerning her employment status.Â  However, she failed to produce this handbook.Â  
  In an affidavit, Warren Moore, the Vice President of Human Resources for Greenwood 
  Mills stated that when Wooldridge was hired in 1994, the company did not have 
  any type of employee handbook in place.Â  He explained the company had withdrawn 
  a prior handbook in 1988 and that handbook was no longer used by the company.Â  

Wooldridge furthermore failed to recall any provisions 
  of the alleged handbook that would alter her status as an at-will employee.Â  
  The mere existence of a handbook does not automatically create a contract of 
  employment.Â  See Horton v. Darby Elec. Co., 360 S.C. 58, 67, 599 
  S.E.2d 456, 460-61 (2004) (stating employerâ€™s manual exemplified the appropriate 
  manner in which to give employees a guide regarding their employment without 
  altering the at-will employment relationship where the manual contained conspicuous 
  disclaimers, which the employee understood and the disciplinary procedure contained 
  permissive language and did not provide for mandatory progressive discipline).Â  
  In fact, Wooldridge admitted her understanding of the handbook was that â€œif 
  you do anything wrong, you know, youâ€™ll get fired.â€Â  Thus, she admitted her 
  own understanding of the handbook was that employees could be discharged without 
  any special procedures.Â  Thus, even if we assume Wooldridge was given an employee 
  handbook, she has failed to present any evidence to support her assertion that 
  this handbook altered her at-will status.Â  See Baughman, 306 S.C. 
  at 115, 410 S.E.2d at 545 (stating party opposing summary judgment must present 
  specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for trial).Â  
Wooldridge next argues that even if her 
  employment was at-will, Greenwood Mills wrongfully discharged her in violation 
  of public policy.Â  She relies on Ludwick v. This Minute of Carolina, Inc., 
  287 S.C. 219, 337 S.E.2d 213 (1985).Â  In Ludwick, the supreme court adopted 
  a public policy exception to the employment at-will doctrine and held: â€œWhere 
  the retaliatory discharge of an at-will employee constitutes violation of a 
  clear mandate of public policy, a cause of action in tort for wrongful discharge 
  arises.â€Â  Id. at 225, 337 S.E.2d at 216.Â  This exception â€œclearly applies 
  in cases when an employer requires an employee to violate the law or the reason 
  for the employeeâ€™s termination was itself a violation of criminal law.â€Â  Lawson 
  v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 340 S.C. 346, 350, 532 S.E.2d 259, 260-61 (2000).Â  
  In addition, an at-will employee may not be terminated for exercising a constitutional 
  right.Â  Moshtaghi v. The Citadel, 314 S.C. 316, 322, 443 S.E.2d 915, 
  919 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  Wooldridge asserts the legal right Greenwood Mills interfered 
  with was â€œher right to tell Tate to get her hand out of her face, and her right 
  to work in an environment without getting offended, hurt, or threatened by a 
  co-worker.â€Â  Wooldridge acknowledged Tate never physically harmed her or threatened 
  her with a violent act.Â  She also admitted her own voice was loud during the 
  altercation.Â  Wooldridge failed to present any law to the trial court or this 
  court that she had a â€œright to tell Tate to get her hand out of her faceâ€ so 
  that Greenwood Millsâ€™ discharge of her based on her participation in the altercation 
  with Tate was a violation of public policy.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial 
  court did not err in granting Greenwood Mills summary judgment on this issue.Â  

Conclusion
We hold Wooldridge has failed to establish 
  a genuine issue of material fact that her employment with Greenwood Mills was 
  other than at-will.Â  We furthermore hold she has failed to establish her discharge 
  was in violation of public policy.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s grant of 
  summary judgment on her claim for wrongful discharge is 
 AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.Â  
  

 
  1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Marion T. Burnside, Jr., Marion T. Burnside, III, and David B. Burnside,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Mary Clare
Matthews,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-136
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert L. Widener and Celeste T. Jones, both of 
  Columbia, for Appellants.
Donald W. Harper, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This case arises from a dispute 
  over hunting rights reserved by Appellants in a deed to a large tract of land 
  they sold.Â  Appellants brought this action for trespass and conversion, claiming 
  the present owner of the property infringed upon these hunting rights.Â  The 
  circuit court dismissed these claims on grant of summary judgment, finding the 
  Appellants had forfeited their hunting rights.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
The property at issue in this case is an 875 acre 
  tract of undeveloped land in Fairfield County.Â  Appellant Marion Burnside, Jr., 
  and the Burnside family had owned the property for many years and enjoyed using 
  it for hunting recreation.Â  In May 1980, Marion Burnside and two other family 
  members sold the property to the Catawba Newsprint Company, a timber company 
  later known as Bowater. [1] Â  The Burnsides, however, wanted to retain the 
  familyâ€™s right to continue hunting and fishing on the land.Â  To this end, the 
  deed to Bowater included terms specifically reserving the hunting rights on 
  the property to the Burnsides:

Hunting rights on the above described 
  property are RESERVED by Marion T. Burnside, Jr. and his two sons, David B. 
  Burnside and Marion T. Burnside, III, and Ken Richmond for a period of 10 years 
  from the date of this deed; thereafter, Marion T. Burnside, Jr. and his two 
  sons reserve the right to lease the hunting rights on a year to year basis.Â  
  The consideration for the lease shall be equal to the amount of the previous 
  yearâ€™s property taxes. 

As provided in the deed, the Burnsides 
  held the hunting rights for the first ten years at no cost.Â  After this ten 
  year period expired in 1990, Bowater began the practice of annually sending 
  notice of the amount of property tax due to the Burnsides in April or May along 
  with a year long lease that would generally run from July 1st to June 30th.Â  
  Each year the Burnsides would execute the lease and return it with the rent 
  payment. Â Often, this task was handled by John Jernigan, who served as 
  the agent of Marion T. Burnside, Jr., for purposes of managing the hunting rights 
  and wildlife on the property.Â  Jernigan would execute the yearly leases under 
  the name â€œBurnsides Hunt Clubâ€ or â€œJohn Jernigan Hunt Club.â€ 
In December 1997, Respondent Mary Clare 
  Matthews purchased the property from Bowater.Â  Matthews was aware of the Burnsidesâ€™ 
  hunting rights, and, without success, sought relinquishment of those rights.Â  
  At the time Matthews purchased the property, it remained subject to a hunting 
  rights lease between Bowater and the Burnsides (via the â€œJohn Jernigan Hunt 
  Clubâ€), which expired in June 1998. 
In May or June of 1998, Jernigan contacted 
  Bowater to inquire about the property tax due in order that the hunting rights 
  lease could be executed for the next year.Â  Bowater informed Jernigan of the 
  sale to Matthews.Â  Appellants claimed Jernigan attempted to contact Matthews 
  about entering into a new lease for the 1998-1999 hunting season prior to the 
  expiration of the 1997-1998 lease with Bowater.Â  Matthews denied receiving any 
  such communication.Â  It is undisputed, however, that in May 1999â€”nearly one 
  year after the previous lease expiredâ€”Jernigan mailed Matthews a check for $1,486 
  to cover the taxes due on the property.Â  Matthews refused to accept the payment.Â  
  Matthews eventually changed the locks on the gates that provided access to the 
  property, and she also allowed others to hunt on the property. 
The Burnsides later brought this action 
  against Matthews alleging trespass and conversion of the Burnsidesâ€™ hunting 
  rights.Â  Matthews denied these allegations and counterclaimed for trespass and 
  slander of title.Â  The circuit court subsequently granted Matthewsâ€™ motion for 
  summary judgment on all claims, finding, inter alia, the Burnsides 
  had forfeited their hunting rights by failing to give notice of their intent 
  to exercise the lease option.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, 
  this court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 
  56(c), SCRCP.Â  Nexsen v. Haddock, 353 S.C. 74, 77, 576 S.E.2d 183, 185 
  (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œSummary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue 
  as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a 
  matter of law.â€Â  Kirkman v. Parex, Inc., 356 S.C. 525, 527-28, 590 S.E.2d 
  36, 37 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Rule 56, SCRCP, and South Carolina Prop. & 
  Cas. Guar. Assâ€™n. v. Yensen, 345 S.C. 512, 518, 548 S.E.2d 880, 883 (Ct. 
  App. 2001)).Â  In determining whether summary judgment was proper, the court 
  views the evidence and the inferences that can be drawn therefrom in a light 
  most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 
  452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, the Burnsides assert several 
  alternative grounds they claim warrant a reversal of the circuit courtâ€™s grant 
  of summary judgment in favor of Matthews.Â  For the reasons detailed below, we 
  reject all of these arguments.
I.Â  Exercise of Hunting Rights Under 
  the Terms of the Deed
The Burnsides first argue that, assuming 
  they failed to give timely notice to Matthews of their intent to lease the hunting 
  rights on the property at the end of their existing lease with Bowater, such 
  failure did not forfeit all future hunting rights under the deed.Â  We disagree.
The Burnsides contend the language in 
  the deed granting them the right to lease the hunting rights â€œon a year to year 
  basisâ€ meant they had the option to lease the hunting rights every year, or 
  they could not lease one year but then lease the next yearâ€”in effect allowing 
  them to skip any year or years of their choosing, after which they could resume 
  the lease arrangement upon notice to the property owner.Â  Therefore, failure 
  to give notice for any one particular year would not operate to forfeit the 
  right for future years.Â  According to the Burnsides, even if this interpretation 
  were found to be incorrect by the fact finder at trial, their argument points 
  to an ambiguity in the terms of the lease that, at a minimum, gives rise to 
  a question of material fact sufficient to overcome Matthewsâ€™ motion for summary 
  judgment.Â  Looking, however, to the plain meaning of the hunting rights lease 
  and applying the well settled rules for construing restrictions in deeds, we 
  find no such ambiguity and no support for the interpretation of the lease terms 
  urged by the Burnsides.
â€œThe construction of a clear 
  and unambiguous deed is a question of law for the court.â€Â  Gardner v. Mozingo, 
  293 S.C. 23, 25, 358 S.E.2d 390, 392 (1987); see also Shipyard 
  Prop. Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n v. Mangiaracina, 307 S.C. 299, 308, 414 S.E.2d 795, 
  801 (Ct. App. 1992). The court will neither limit a restriction in a deed nor 
  will the court enlarge or extend it by construction or implication beyond the 
  clear meaning of its terms even to accomplish what it thinks the parties would 
  have desired if they had foreseen the development of a particular situation.Â  
  Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 4, 498 S.E.2d 862, 864 (1998).Â Â  

It is still the settled rule 
  in this jurisdiction that restrictions as to the use of real estate should be 
  strictly construed and all doubts resolved in favor of free use of the property, 
  subject, however, to the provision that this rule of strict construction should 
  not be applied so as to defeat the plain and obvious purpose of the instrument. 


Id.Â  Further, â€œâ€˜[a] 
  restriction on the use of property must be created in express terms or by plain 
  and unmistakable implication, and all such restrictions are to be strictly construed, 
  with all doubts resolved in favor of the free use of property.â€™â€Â  Id. 
  at 5, 498 S.E.2d at 864 (quoting Hamilton v. CCM, Inc., 274 S.C. 152, 
  157, 263 S.E.2d 378, 380 (1980)).Â  In interpreting options or rights to extend 
  a lease, our courts have consistently held that such options or rights are to 
  be strictly construed against the party claiming the option. See 33 
  Flavors Stores of Virginia, Inc. v. Hoffmanâ€™s Candies, Inc., 296 S.C. 37, 
  40, 370 S.E.2d 293, 295 (Ct. App. 1988) (holding that â€œbecause of its unilateral 
  nature, an option to renew a lease is strictly construed against the party claiming 
  the optionâ€) (citing Southern Silica Mining & Mfg. Co. v. Hoefer, 
  215 S.C. 480, 56 S.E.2d 321 (1949)).
We find no provision 
  in the lease termsâ€”explicit or impliedâ€”suggesting the Burnsides could unilaterally 
  choose to exercise their option to lease the hunting rights to the property 
  any year of their choosing for perpetuity.Â  The terms of the deed granting the 
  Burnsides the right to lease the hunting rights on a â€œyear to yearâ€ basis plainly 
  mean that the Burnsides could renew or extend their right to hunt on the property 
  in consecutive years following the expiration of the initial ten year period 
  reserving the hunting rights.Â  To hold otherwise would place a severe encumbrance 
  upon the use and alienability of the property for an indefinite period of time.Â  
  Absent explicit language in the terms of the deed indicating the parties intended 
  such an expansive encroachment upon the rights of the immediate grantee and 
  all future owners of the underlying fee, we decline to adopt such an interpretation.
II.Â  Purported 
  Questions of Fact Concerning Timely Notice
The Burnsides alternatively 
  argue that they did in fact provide Matthews with sufficient notice of their 
  intent to extend or renew their hunting rights lease prior to the expiration 
  of their existing lease with Bowater for the 1997-1998 hunting season.Â  In support 
  of this argument, the Burnsides rely upon three pieces of evidence that they 
  claim establish their attempts to give timely notice to Matthews: the deposition 
  and affidavit of John Jernigan and the check for the property tax payment Jernigan 
  mailed to Matthews in May 1999.Â  At a minimum, they claim this evidence created 
  a question of material fact not ripe for disposition at the summary judgment 
  stage.Â  We address the sufficiency of each of these items separately.Â  
A.Â  Jerniganâ€™s Deposition
The Burnsides argue Jerniganâ€™s deposition, when 
  viewed in a light most favorable to them, creates an issue of fact as to timely 
  notice.Â Â  We disagree.Â  Contrary to the Burnsidesâ€™ characterization of Jerniganâ€™s 
  deposition testimony, we find no statement in this testimony indicating Jernigan 
  contacted Matthews prior to mailing the check for the property tax payment in 
  May 1999â€”approximately ten months after the last existing lease had expired.Â  
  Accordingly, even when viewing Jerniganâ€™s deposition in a light most favorable 
  to the Burnsides as we must, we cannot discern from this testimony any genuine 
  issue of material fact regarding timely notice. 
B.Â  Jerniganâ€™s Affidavit
The Burnsides submitted an affidavit of John Jernigan 
  to the circuit court in which Jernigan states that he â€œattempted to call Ms. 
  Matthews over a three-to-four month time span, without success.â€Â  The circuit 
  court found the submission of the affidavit to be untimely and refused to consider 
  it.Â  The Burnsides contend this refusal was an abuse of discretion.
We find no error in the 
  circuit judgeâ€™s rejection of this affidavit. Rule 56(c), SCRCP specifies that 
  when filing papers in response to motions for summary judgment, â€œ[t]he adverse 
  party may serve opposing affidavits not later than two days before the hearing.â€ 
  Our supreme court has ruled that the trial court may, in its discretion, â€œrefuse 
  to consider materials that were not timely served such that the opposing party 
  had no time to prepare a response.â€ Black v. Lexington Sch. Dist. No. 2, 
  327 S.C. 55, 60, 488 S.E.2d 327, 329 (1997) (holding that the trial court did 
  not abuse its discretion in refusing to consider an affidavit filed on the date 
  of the hearing when the appellantâ€™s lawyer admitted he failed to serve the affidavit 
  within the time required by Rule 56 and failed to assert any good excuse for 
  that failure).Â  
In the present case, the 
  affidavit was submitted two weeks after the summary judgment hearing.Â  
  Indeed, the affidavit was submitted after the circuit court had notified 
  the parties by letter that it intended to grant Matthewsâ€™ summary judgment motion.Â  
  As the circuit court explained in denying the Burnsidesâ€™ motion to alter or 
  amend judgment, the Burnsidesâ€™ attorney neither offered to submit nor requested 
  leave to submit the affidavit.Â  Moreover, we concur in the circuit courtâ€™s assessment 
  that the Burnsides were clearly aware that the matter involved in the affidavit 
  was a basis for Matthewsâ€™ summary judgment motion, rendering the delay in producing 
  the affidavit without any legitimate explanation or excuse.Â  Accordingly, we 
  find no abuse of discretion in the circuit courtâ€™s refusal to consider the affidavit. 

C.Â  May 1999 Check to Matthews
The Burnsidesâ€™ next argue that the check Jernigan 
  sent to Matthews in May 1999 was sufficient to create a genuine issue of material 
  fact as to timely notice.Â  This argument, however, rests upon the premise that 
  the terms of the deed entitle the Burnsides to exercise their right to lease 
  the hunting rights in any year of their choosing, even after the expiration 
  of the existing lease.Â  As discussed in Section I, supra, we reject this 
  interpretation of the deed language.Â  Accordingly, the claim that a check mailed 
  over ten months after the expiration of the existing lease could serve as effective 
  notice of the exercise of the hunting rights lease is without merit.Â  Thus, 
  the circuit court properly determined the check raised no genuine issue of material 
  fact as to whether notice was timely provided.
III.Â  Course of Dealing
The Burnsides also argue 
  the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment because Matthews owed a 
  duty to the Burnsides to notify them of the lease amount based on a course of 
  dealing between Bowater and the Burnsides under the deed.Â  
This argument was not raised to the circuit court.Â  
  No mention is made of it in the complaint, in the Burnsidesâ€™ memorandum in opposition 
  to summary judgment, or in their motion to amend or alter the judgment.Â  To 
  be preserved for appellate review, an issue must have been raised to and ruled 
  upon by the trial court.Â  United Student Aid Funds, Inc. v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Health and Envtâ€™l Control, 356 S.C. 266, 273, 588 S.E.2d 599, 602 
  (2003).Â  Because the Burnsides failed to raise this argument prior to appeal, 
  this issue is not properly before us.Â  
IV. Additional Issue Raised on Appeal
In its order granting Matthewsâ€™ motion 
  for summary judgment, the circuit court held: 

Even if the Court construes the 
  deed to create a year to year lease rather than a right or option to lease, 
  the failure of the Plaintiffs to pay or tender rent for a period of ten months 
  constitutes a material breach of the lease resulting in a forfeiture even under 
  the stringent requirements of Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, 
  312 S.C. 271, 440 S.E.2d 364 (1994).Â  

On appeal, the Burnsides 
  assert this finding of the circuit court was error.Â  However, we find summary 
  judgment was properly granted on the grounds that notice was insufficient and 
  no lease relationship was created between the Burnsides and Matthews.Â  Accordingly, 
  we need not reach this alternative ground regarding whether the Burnsidesâ€™ actions 
  constituted a material breach in the event such a lease was found to exist. 

CONCLUSION
We find the circuit court properly determined 
  that the Burnsides failed to notify Matthews of their intent to extend, renew, 
  or otherwise exercise their option to lease the hunting rights to the property 
  and therefore forfeited their right to do so in the future.Â  Concomitantly, 
  we find that no genuine issue of material fact precluded this determination 
  at the summary judgment stage.Â  Appellantsâ€™ other arguments concerning the legal 
  effects of a purported course of dealing between the parties and material breach 
  of the lease are either unpreserved or unnecessary to our decision today.Â  Accordingly, 
  the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment is
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

 
  Â Â Â Â  
    [1] For clarity and ease of reference we will refer to the company as Bowater 
    throughout this opinion.
